Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VJY-K8N1-DY0W-41D0-00000-00President Trump Advancing 'America First' Agenda in Davos; North Korea Calls for Unification; Companies Invest in America; Tax Reform2018-01-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:28ZLexisNexisPresident Trump Advancing 'America First' Agenda in Davos; North Korea Calls for Unification; Companies Invest in America; Tax ReformLanhamFULL TEXT

TRISH REGAN, "THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT" HOST: I love that. I really do. It's great to see because I think so many people were so pessimistic about this, and you're right.

CAVUTO: Amazing.

REGAN: They could pay for themselves, wouldn't that be great, but you're also right on that spending front. Neil, thank you.

Breaking right now, everyone, President Trump and several Cabinet members are meeting with global business leaders right now in Davos, Switzerland. They're discussing the success of America's tax plan and why businesses should be investing in the United States of America. All of this as we see again, another record day on Wall Street, up 169 there on the Dow.

I'm Trish Regan. Welcome, everyone to "The Intelligence Report."

President Trump, taking his America first message right to the world stage. Tomorrow morning, the President is going to be delivering what many are calling the most important economic speech of his presidency. And in that speech, the President is also expected to pressure world leaders to do more to stop Kim Jong-un and his nuclear ambitions.

You know, I said it over and over and over again and I'm going to say it again, we have not even scratched the surface when it comes to economic pressure, economic pressure on China.

Senator Cory Gardner has been leading the charge on this effort and he's going to join me in just a few minutes.

But first, let's go to Blake Burman in Davos where the President is wrapping up his first full day at the economic forum. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: And he's not even done. As we just saw there, he is sitting down for dinner, 8:00 here in the evening local time with European business leaders. Quite the crowd that he has with him here in Davos.

You just saw a little bit of that play out. The President is sitting down with leaders, for example, of Adidas, Bayer, Nokia, Nestle, Volvo, Deloitte, just to name a few. This is really been a two-fold message, really a two-fold reasoning for the President coming here to Davos.

The first you just hit on it, security issues that the United States and the world is dealing with, but also the economic message that the President wants to get across and the trade message he and his administration want to get across. Sitting down with those business leaders, those CEOs moments ago, here is President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I just want to say that there has been a lot of warmth, a lot of respect for our country and a lot of money, billions and billions of dollars is coming into the U.S. and people are very happy with what we've done, not only on the tax bill, but also cutting of regulations. And I think also being a cheerleader for our country. You know, if you're not a cheerleader for your company or for your country, no matter what happens, it is not going to work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: So the President got into town today. His delegation has been here for a couple days though. And the commerce secretary, Wilbur Ross made some headlines yesterday when he said that trade wars are happening every single day and U.S. troops, as he put it, are just starting to gear up.

On this very set earlier this morning when he spoke with Maria Bartiromo, the Commerce Secretary said it is not that he feels that there is going to be a race to the bottom, but he also clarified by saying the reality of it is there are trade abuses happening every day.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILBUR ROSS, SECRETARY OF COMMERCE: What I meant was this, every time someone violates trade rules, that to me, is act of war. Dumping steel is an act of war. Dumping aluminum is an act of war, dumping anything. Forcing technology transfers, same thing. That is what I had in mind.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: All right, so back to the President. He is at that dinner right now with European business leaders that will wrap up his day once he is done. He also met today, by the way, with the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu and the British Prime Minister, Theresa May. Tomorrow he has two more meetings with the presidents of Rwanda and Switzerland separately.

And then, of course, Trish, 8:00 Eastern, 2:00 p.m. in the afternoon here in Davos, the President will give that widely anticipated speech before the huge forum and really before the world. Trish?

REGAN: I'm looking forward to it. You know where I am going to be, watching FBN at 8:00 a.m. tomorrow morning, tune in. Maria is there in Davos as well. Thank you soy much, Blake.

Joining me right now, former Economic Advisor to President Ronald Reagan, Mr. Art Laffer. Art, good to see you. I know you have a good mood today.

ARTHUR LAFFER, FORMER ECONOMIC ADVISOR TO PRESIDENT RONALD REAGAN: Great to see you.

REGAN: Did you hear Neil as we went into0 this program? He was pointing out to the viewer exactly what you have said all along when you said, you know, in a couple years, if this continues, if we get four percent growth, if we see a real significant upturn in the economy, tax revenues, well, they will go up and this whole thing will pay for itself.

LAFFER: It is the Laffer curve, isn't it? It's my profile, Trish. And it should be called the Cavuto or the Regan curve by the way. But --

REGAN: No, no. You --

LAFFER: -- it's wonderful, it's fun.

REGAN: -- you coined it back in the Reagan years.

LAFFER: Yes.

REGAN: And, you know, it is the Laffer curve and it will always be known as such, sir.

LAFFER: Thank you.

REGAN: But walk as through. Do you think it's --

LAFFER: It happens. It happens --

REGAN: -- it's realist to think that that is in fact the going to be the case? No one thought.

LAFFER: -- I know, I'm very certain it is the case, Trish. Not only will we get higher growth, but it is more than just growth because you get all the personal behavior things. There is going to be less tax evasion, there's going to be less tax sheltering. They're going to be people are going to go back to c-corporations.

Corporate headquarters are going to move back to the U.S. There going to be secondary and tertiary tax revenues from income taxes, from payroll taxes, Medicare and Medicaid, all of this is going to have and state and local governments are going to do really well with this tax bill. And we're not only get it paid for, Trish, we are going to make a huge amount on this net.

I have never seen a surplus in the U.S. budget that does not come along with rapid growth and tax cuts. It just doesn't happen. So this is the --

REGAN: Wow.

LAFFER: -- this is the way to do it and Trump's done it and God bless him. I take my hat off to him. It's the best economic program I have seen by any president of the United States in his first year in office.

REGAN: Wow.

LAFFER: It is just incredible what he has done.

REGAN: That is a big endorsement from you, Art. Let me ask you this.

LAFFER: It's huge. Yes, please, yes.

REGAN: Democrat after Democrat is saying, well, you know, this was going to happen anyway. These companies would have given out bonuses, they would have raised wages. That was all in the works before this tax plan ever came into being. What do you say to them?

LAFFER: Well, I don't know what to say to them. I feel very sorry for them that they're playing catch-up. This was Democratic Party policy when Kennedy was president. They were the big tax cutters, pro-growers. There's budget surpluses and revenue raisers by cutting tax rates.

And now, these people are stuck in this alternative universe where they are the big naysayers. They want to hold up the budget. They want to raise taxes. They want to do all the wrong things. And I'm very sorry for them. But then, you know, they're wrong and we're right, and we won, and they lost, and now, they're trying to claim credit for what we won.

And if it had been done, Trish, they would have done it under Obama, but they didn't. And we did and it's going lead to prosperity. I'm very sorry, that they want to take credit for it, but they don't deserve it.

REGAN: They, you know, they certainly didn't have (INAUDIBLE) as obstructionist as they possibly could be, Art.

LAFFER: They have been totally obstructionist.

REGAN: And this thing through.

LAFFER: They voted against everything. Everything, they voted against. And this is the not the Democratic Party any of us ever knew in our histories. This is the antigrowth Democratic Party, which is brand new and really unpleasant.

REGAN: You know, and, Art, the other thing about the Democratic Party right now is they are out there saying, oh, this is nothing. A 1000 bucks, Nancy Pelosi says is crumbs, Art.

LAFFER: Yes, I know. I know.

REGAN: Yes, I don't know. But I think a lot of Americans would like to have an extra thousand dollars. Those are not crumbs.

LAFFER: Of course. I mean, these people --

REGAN: This is real money. This is significant.

LAFFER: They are desperate. They can see they're losing and they're desperate. And I wish they wouldn't. I wish they just come and join us and we can work out the stuff together just the way we did with Reagan under the '86 Tax Act.

You know, we passed the '86 Tax Act, Trish, with 97-3 on the vote. All the Democrats were with us to cut tax rate and provide growth. Al Gore told me, you know, a year-and-a-half ago, the best bill he ever voted for in economics. I mean, this is cool, cool stuff. And they should be with us, not against us.

REGAN: The Laffer curve at work. Thank you so much, Art.

LAFFER: Thank you. You know, Trish, that's lovely. Thanks.

REGAN: Let's turn to another big story. North Korean calling for unification of the Koreas, this as President Trump is expected to do warn world leaders at Davos tomorrow that they got to do more to stop North Korea's nuclear ambitions.

Joining me right now is the Chairman of the Foreign Relation Subcommittee on East Asia. He is the point man on all things North Korea and he has been leading this charge on tougher North Korean sanctions. Here with me right now, Senator Cory Gardner. Senator, good to have you here.

CORY GARDNER (R), SENATOR, COLORADO: Thanks for having me.

REGAN: All right. I know your lead charge on North Korean sanctions. What about sanctioning China?

GARDNER: I think that's where we have to turn to. And we know that China has over 5000 businesses who are doing business with North Korea toy. They're in violation of our sanctions laws.

We know that the China has 10 businesses where at one point were responsible for 10 percent of North Korea's total economy. It has got to stop, and they've got to do more. If China wants to be a responsible global power, they need to make a choice, either do business with us or do business with them. You can't do it both ways.

REGAN: Well, you know, they signed on to the sanctions, sir, both Chinese and the Russians did, right? And then we have video of them out there trading with the North Koreans.

GARDNER: Yes.

REGAN: Despite what they promised us. We've seen that North Korean GDP, their economy has grown.

GARDNER: Yes.

REGAN: The only way it is grown is if they're trading with China. So that tells us China --

GARDNER: Exactly right.

REGAN: -- and here is the video that we have.

GARDER: Exactly right.

REGAN: So, China has not living up to what it promised us.

GARDNER: Yes. And what we're hearing is China is doing a little bit more than they have in the past. They didn't stop the new U.N resolutions that passed recently. That is more than they have done. But the problem is there is so much more to do and we don't have that much time.

As North Korea builds its nuclear program, they get further and further advanced. At some point, they cross that red line that is unacceptable to the United States. And China needs to step up to do more. They continue to send a crude to China -- North Korea, it's got to stop.

REGAN: I agree with you. But here is my question for you, sir. The markets at an all-time high, 26,418 right now on the Dow.

GARDNER: Right.

REGAN: And there is a lot of fear about a kind of trade war that it would destabilize our economy. Is that a risk you're willing to take?

GARDNER: We need to build trust with China. And trust with China that we don't want to have U.S. troops deployed on the Yalu River. But we need to build that trust and say, hey, we're interested in denuclearizing Kim Jong- un and his regime, let's build that trust. But we also have to make sure we look at the past, in the past, when we have taken strong steps toward China, whether it is Iran or other sanctions, they have came to the table.

They stepped up to the brink. And they actually behave in the way that was helped us solved problem in Iran. Now, we still have some a long ways to go in Iran but we have gotten even further way to go in North Korea.

REGAN: You know, I bring it up because I think we actually have a lot of ammunition here. And I'm not talking about military ammunition. I am talking about economic ammunition. And I say all the time, the viewer knows I would much rather be in a situation where we are losing dollars, Senator, as opposed to lives. And so, before we make a commitment to go to all-out war, --

GARDNER: Right.

REGAN: -- shouldn't we be doing everything possible, everything we can economically to be at war before we're actually losing lives?

GARDNER: I can't agree with you more. Look, this is a situation where we have plenty of room left on the diplomatic and economic runway to increase our pressure, increase our sanctions, increase the isolation diplomatically of the regime. Before any action is taken military, we have to be prepared for that alternative. We have to be prepared for the outcome. We will protect our allies, hundreds of thousands of U.S. citizens in Korea. But we have to ramp up that pressure to turn those dials so they move from the forth most sanctioned country in the world, to the first most-sanctioned country in the world, that being North Korea

REGAN: Senator Gardner, thank you very much. It's good to have your perspective here.

GARDNER: Thanks for having me.

REGAN: I do want to just to mention to the viewer, you know, this has come up over and over again on the show, Ambassador Bolton, let's see if we can play a clip here. He doesn't think that we would go to an actual trade war. He sees the military option happening first. Here he is with me a short time ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN BOLTON, UNITED STATES AMBASSADOR TO THE UNITED NATIONS: The American business community is not going to sign on willing to cutting off access -- sanctions on steroid, as you put it, to the Chinese market. Look, on your show next week, call in the head of JPMorgan, Goldman Sach ans ask them how they would like to cult off banking access to the Chinese market.

REGAN: Well, I don't care about them. I care about the country and I care about the fact there could be a nuclearized North Korea.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

REGAN: And I also asked why would Jamie Dimon at JPMorgan or Goldman Sachs be calling the shots when it comes to our foreign affairs? In other words, who cares what they think. Who cares what the CEO's think. What we need to do is what's best for our people. So with that in mind, maybe we need to be looking long and hard at how we can better influence China economically.

Anyway markets soaring today on strong earnings. About a quarter of all S&P 500 companies have reported in about 80 percent have beaten earnings, and they have beaten revenue estimates. This is great news happening on a day.

Home Depot joins hundreds of companies that are spreading the wealth out there. They're handing out bonuses to employees. And you know why? One after another tells us because of President Trump's tax reform. So why won't the left give him any credit at all? Why are they trying to say that this is related to President Obama's economic policies of which he had none? We're on it next

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Stock surging right now, up triple digits, 119 we're higher on the Dow. The Dow is hitting new all-time high. You never get tired of it, right? Now on the pace for its 10th record close of the year, and guess what? It's only January.

This as Home Depot, Northrop Grumman, all jump on this wave of American companies given away bonuses and wage hikes as a result of the Republican tax bill. But get this? The mainstream media is still absolutely, positively refusing to give the Donald Trump administration any credit at all for this economic success and for our now booming labor market.

Here is Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross speaking with Maria Bartiromo earlier today in Davos, Switzerland. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROSS: They have no alternative but to make up fiction but, eventually, facts overcome fiction. And I think the fellow who just got $1000 check, doesn't care what the left-wing media says. Then the person who gets a tax cut in the next withholding he is also -- he/she is also not going to care what the left-wing media says.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

REGAN: Joining me right now, Money Map Press Chief Investment Strategist, Keith Fitz-Gerald. Keith, you know, let's forget politics for a minute here. Let's just look at what is happening.

You get the market hitting high after high after high. You've got unemployment moving lower, record low. You've got wages moving higher. And I can't wait to see the numbers next month on wage inflation because we haven't had any wage inflation for -- well, the last 30 years or longer, adjusted for inflation.

So, this is an opportunity for to us be happy about things for a change, right? To be happy about the economy and happy about the markets, and yet, the Democrats and the media they won't go there. Why?

KEITH FITZ-GERALD, CHIEF INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, MONEY MAP PRESS: You know, this is kind of like a bunch of children on the playground. They're all going, not me or I wish I had. Political strategists of course are going to seize on a moment like this because the logic is irrefutable.

They're going to try to play the card that says well, we would have done it, this would have happened anyway. But the reality is it wouldn't have because that requires the cash that is coming from the tax cut. So, again, taking the politics out of it, the reality of money is you can't spend what you don't have unless you accrue debt. But if you have it you can spend it and that's what corporate America is doing. More than 200 corporations have jumped on bandwagon at this point.

REGAN: Well, you know, the left would say, well just because of the great policies of President Obama and now they're finally catching up to the economy. What do you say to that?

FITZ-GERALD: Well, if that were true, then the words hope and confidence would have been a critical part in the American lexicon the last year, last decade, last 20 years. But the reality was uncertainty and hesitation was the bell word. That's why corporations kept the money overseas.

Now that they're bringing it home that reflects a change in sentiment. And CEOs are not dingalings. CEOs are very credible, intelligent people and they're moving their money where it is going to be treated best. And this time around is right here at home.

REGAN: So does that mean this rally continues for foreseeable future? I mean, what do you think? Jamie Dimon saying four percent GDP growth, is he right?

FITZ-GERALD: I think Jamie Dimon is one of the smartest individuals on the planet and I think he is possibly the only individual over there who truly understands how to make money in today's complex financial markets, from financial perspective. And a lot of other managers do from manufacturing perspective. But yes I think he is absolutely correct.

REGAN: So are you still buying this market, Keith?

FITZ-GERALD: I'm buying very selectively. Obviously you don't do anything, like bet the ranch or putting your inheritance. I mean, you do it intelligently, big medicine, big tech (ph), big resources, big defense, those are all things that the world must have. That's the intelligence place you can put your money because you know those things are never going to go away no matter what happens on Wall Street, no matter what the Fed does next or no matter what politicians decide on either side of the aisle.

REGAN: Well, it's a good time to be an investor I think, Keith Fitz- Gerald, thank you very much. Good to see you.

FITZ-GERALD: Yes it is.

REGAN: A recently leaked White House infrastructure plan outlines what they're calling value-capturing financing. Basically means that -- and this is crazy, a private landowner's property gains in a particular project, that may have come because of a public works project belongs in part to the government. Sounding a little Venezuelan to me but we're going through it all with Adam Shapiro, coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We are also work to go rebuild our crumbling infrastructure by stimulating a $1 trillion investment and that'll actually probably end up being $1.7 trillion.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

REGAN: President Trump addressing the nation' mayors offering more details on his long-awaited infrastructure plan which he says is going to be hart of Tuesday's State of the Union Address. This as leaked documents released this week call the White House's plan -- well, potentially problematic.

The White House is saying that this is actually largely accurate and they're pointing to $10 billion in cost-sharing payments, 50 billion-dollar for world project, $50 billion for transformative projects. But here is the sticking point. This is what is very concerning to a lot of people right now. There's something tucked in there called the value capture financing.

And Adam Shapiro has more on it but basically my concern about this --

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Right.

REGAN: -- and if I'm understanding your reporting right here Adam, you know, people's property rights wouldn't be the same.

SHAPIRO: Depending on where you live and what your city or state intends to do. Value capture financing, it sounds very wonky. We do it already in the United States through tax increment financing, have been doing for decades. This doesn't really affect individual homeowners.

Going forward, if the proposal as it's written for infrastructure, 200 billion in federal dollar to leverage a trillion in infrastructure projects they would require -- the federal government would require cities like say, let's just say New York, for instance, to have a value capture financing mechanism in place in order to get the federal tax dollars. So cities like New York would have to come up with what the rules would mean.

And what value capture financing tries to do is capture the value from increase in property values after a public work's project. So conceivably, Trish, you can say to the people who live along, say, Second Avenue in New York City whose apartment value all went up because they built that subway. You will going to have to give us a little bit of the sup side in gain in property value to help fund the subway.

Now, it's -- no one is doing it that way.

REGAN: I'm sorry. It kind of sounds Venezuelan to me, Adam. I don't like this one bit. So you're the person that buys the apartment, say, 10 years ago on Second Avenue and just because they decide to put a train there, and by the way, you go through 10 years of major discomfort and --

SHAPIRO: Right.

REGAN: -- you know what came with that, there were rats, right, on Second Avenue as a result of all that digging.

SHAPIRO: There are rats all over New York City.

REGAN: -- had to live with that. Yes, that's true. But they had to live with that for nearly 10 years, so shouldn't they, in fact, get that upside whatever comes with it. That's their property.

SHAPIRO: That's for the people of New York City and leaders of New York City to determine, but keep in mind that nobody is doing that yet. What's been proposed is that the federal government if they pass that proposal that was leaked as it is in order to get tax dollars from the federal government for future transit projects, cities like New York or say San Francisco or Cleveland, Ohio would have to have a value capture financing mechanism in place to get those federal tax dollars.

REGAN: OK, I see what they are saying.

SHAPIRO: Then, it would be up to the city to decide. It would be up to the city to decide if they were going to do it the way you and I just discussed. Nobody is doing it that way yet. Nobody is doing like that yet.

REGAN: Right. Because that would be pretty onerous and I think that there would be a lot of legal ramifications, shall we say, to that? But Adam, what's interesting here is, he is basically saying, OK, New York City, we will give you $300 million or --

SHAPIRO: $5 billion for subway.

REGAN: $5 billion whatever, but you're going to have to give us something back in return, the city of New York. I mean, they are going after a lot of these cities and municipalities and states big time. I mean, it's a salt.

SHAPIRO: Again, remember the federal government has always required cities like New York or cities like South Bend, Indiana to match in some form federal tax dollars. The change in this would be the value capture financing portion of it and it would be up to these individuals cities and states to determine how they would do that, nobody has said --

REGAN: OK.

SHAPIRO: -- what the battle on Capitol Hill is going be -- is if you're going to do this, what parameters do you put in place to make sure that a city like South Bend, Indiana, if they wanted to do a new light rail line didn't charge the tax home owner for the upside in t property value. Unless the people of South Bend wanted to do that.

REGAN: OK. Wow. All right, Adam Shapiro, thank you very much.

SHAPIRO: Just a proposal right now.

REGAN: Fortunately, Fortunately.

Joining me right now, Peter Suderman, he's managing editor for Reason.com. Peter, what do you think of this?

PETER SUDERMAN, MANAGING EDITOR, REASON.COM.: Well, I think the most interesting and maybe the most worrying part about this is that it's mandatory, is that what the federal government is saying that if states want to get this federal money as part of this proposed infrastructure package which again is still a proposal, Trump hasn't even announced the full details, and we are talking about leaked information here. So it's -- this is not -- either a final proposal.

REGAN: Yes, I know. It's not perfect all the information we have and so we are just talking about this a bit in theory right now.

SUDERMAN: Right. So this is all theoretical --

REGAN: And the idea that cities would effective have to pay the government for any upside their property has and the question is would that wind up being individuals or just taxpayers as a whole?

SUDERMAN: I suspect that in a lot of cases it would wind up being developers and businesses. And so if you've ever flown over Washington, D.C., you can't see the subway because it's underground but you can tell exactly where it is because you can see the pockets of tall build that are lining the subway lines right and where all the stops are because people have built up around those stops and so the theory here -- and I'm not saying, I think it's a good one, but the theory here is, OK, those are pockets of economic activity, let's leverage that and in part this is because if you listen to the clip that President Trump earlier he said, we want to stimulate a trillion dollars in infrastructure spending. The idea is to take $200 billion and to turn it into trillion and so part of what that means is they're going to try to extract value out of the economy, out of the economic boom that they hoped that comes out of the 200 billion in infrastructure spending that they are potentially proposing here. I think that somebody is going to lose out of that.

REGAN: Well, let me jump in here and just point out that -- look, you know if you say, Mr. President, I really want you to build this new train or this new highway stop near my business, that's one thing, but if you just happened to be the land owner that winds up having a new highway exit in your part of town, how can the government come back to you and say, all right, you going to pay up because we put that exit and now your property is worth more?

SUDERMAN: I think the government is going to be -- can and often does say to property owners, look, you own property as a result, you are going to have to pay us, just for the privilege of owning property within the borders that --

REGAN: Well, then you don't really own it, do you, Peter? What happened to property rights?

SUDERMAN: I'm a home owner in Washington, D.C. And I often feel like I don't own my house. The district government exerts an awful lot of concern. And I think that this is -- like I said, I think it's worrying that not only is this something that is being proposed, it is being proposed as requirement in order to participate in the infrastructure plan.

REGAN: All right. Well, we will see what happens on Tuesday, of course, at the state of the union, but we are on it, you know that. Peter, thank you very much.

SUDERMAN: Thank you so much for having me.

REGAN: Markets probably in the green right now, although cutting earlier gains that we saw on President Trump comments about wanting a strong dollar, we'll going to have more on these markets and where they're heading next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Pairings (ph) and gains here, up just 92 now. And you can see we've reversed course there on the S&P and the Nasdaq, just negative territory slightly and it's all coming as the President makes some comments on the strength of the U.S. dollar.

Let's go to Nicole Petallides, who is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Look at those comments and how it's affecting traders. Hey, Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Hey, Trish. So right now we've seen a mix buy, you can see the S&P and the Nasdaq or to the downside, the Dow is higher by 92 points, had been up over 200, we had a lot of talk about the U.S. dollar, weaker U.S. dollar might help trade and that's very different than what we heard from prior administrations, that's something that's been front and center.

But big picture, the market has been running up to new record highs on the obvious and that is, a better economy and good corporate earnings.

We are seeing some of the winners here on the Dow Jones Industrial average, three at Boeing, United Technology, Johnson & Johnson, Goldman Sachs, (INAUDIBLE) so far have been hitting new all-time highs on the Dow Jones Industrial average

I wanted to focus on both Caterpillar and 3M both of which actually had their quarterly reports, Caterpillar reported loss in the quarter, however the earnings including the tax charge and other items did top the analyst estimates. And the 3M, which actually hit a new high, that is the maker of Scotch Tape and bandages, post-it notes. They raised forecast as well. So that's a real winner. But ultimately, we've digested a few different pieces of information such as home sales today, home sales dropped, but why was that? In fact, it was because people had more in the labor market, they are doing better with their jobs. It was more demand for home and it wasn't the supply in decades. So that's the big picture on the market overall.

And we have come back, some people are really just taking money off the table and extensive conversation with one trader who said, having the best month of his career and he's selling, he's just saying, I don't want to lose it. So some people are right near the top and feeling pretty great and saying, let me take them off of the table.

REGAN: Nicole, thank you very much.

All right, oil prices, everyone, harboring a three year high as U.S. crude closest $65.51 a barrel. Our own Jeff Flock is live at the CME with more on this surge in oil prices. Hey, Jeff.

JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS REPORTER: Well, it had been a surge, up until I think maybe the President's comments on the dollar. You know, look, part of the run up, the most recent, yesterday at least, had been talking about a weak dollar which obviously is bullish for oil, now we're in the after hours down even farther than we were at the close, we are now trading 65.10. Just about $65 and, again, strong dollar, weaker oil prices which is not necessarily a bad thing. We've had a huge run-up here as you point out, Trish, and that on the strength of 10 consecutive weeks of draw down and U.S. supply.

There's much supply out there as we did, and maybe as much as people think, you know, we are swimming in oil. Indeed, we are making more oil in the country than we ever have in part thanks to the administration's policies but we still, you know, we are still part of the world marketplace and we still net import oil, so we are not at energy independence yet. But anyway, I think largely on the strength of the President's comments about the dollar, we are now trading down 50 cents from yesterday's -- or from the open this morning at 65.11, the last trade here at the CME in Chicago.

REGAN: All right, thanks very much, Jeff.

The Teamsters union playing ball with UPS in contact negotiations demanding the company not use drones, not use driverless trucks, nor make drivers work past 9:00 p.m. Nice life they might have, huh. Look, you know, you can't stop the future even though the unions are trying, so where is this going end up, details next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Teamsters labor union wants to ban UPS from using drones and delivering trucks to deliver packages. The union is entering contract negotiations with a whole long list of demands that include hiring 10,000 more workers and stopping all deliveries after 9:00 p.m. But with online retail creating a lot of demand for delivery companies, how can UPS actually agree to all of this and still compete with rivals like FedEx and -- well, the U.S. Postal Service?

Joining me right now Independent Women's Forum Senior Policy Analyst Patrice Lee Onwuka. Good to see you, Patrice.

PATRICE LEE ONWUKA, SENIOR POLICY ANALYST, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S FORUM: Good to see you too.

REGAN: So the unions are up at, at it again?

ONWUKA: They are. So I think they're actually speeding against the wind. Technology, automation, drone delivery is going to be really important for the transportation delivery industry in part because there's a huge shortfall of drivers, qualified drivers out there something like 48,000 shortfall jobs and in terms of jobs. And that's going to -- well, it's over 175,000 over probably the next decade.

So you need more drivers but you also need to make those drivers efficient particularly when they are delivering out in rural areas and that's why technology can really come in.

REGAN: You know, driverless cars are on the way, I was talking to Carlos Ghosn recently who said, you know, look just few years away, this is a very real possibility for our country that, you know, will all be in driverless cars which is good news for me since I hate to drive but between that and drones and you know how much Amazon has been investing in the drone industry, if these companies like UPS can't keep up with technology and if their workers are so resistant to that, you know, at some point, they're going to be out of business.

ONWUKA: I think so. I mean, realistically, I think the Teamsters are using this as a bargaining chip. I don't think they really expect that UPS would not allow for drone delivery. And by the way, there are also regulation that don't permit it and like a full commercial space, but, you know, it is important for us to be able to embrace technology, that also means, though, we need to start preparing our workforce for what that means, it may mean that we don't have as many drivers delivering trucks. But, you know, what are the other opportunities and the other jobs they're going to be available.

Technology is not something we should be running from. It's something we need to embrace but be smart about it.

REGAN: Yeah, I mean, and this -- we have an -- I would argue, had the right economic policies in place to be smart about it because, you know, I think about when I was a kid on the highway and you had to pay your toll, you gave it to -- you gave your money to someone, someone there at the toll booth, just doesn't exist anymore. And in some cases the tolls themselves don't exist because it's just all automated and they get your car going by. So these are jobs, right? These are actual jobs so we need to be transitioning our workforce, and it's a much bigger broader, I think, conversation, Patrice, because it gets back to a lot of things like education. It gets back to things like immigration. There's a lot that fold into it.

ONWUKA: There is. I mean, reaching (ph) the workforce for the future I think is one of those topics that people are afraid of and I think unfortunately you have some folks on the left who are using it as a political chip and a political ploy which they really shouldn't be, but we do need to think about from a policy perspective how do we bring together business, our higher education system, our K-12 education system and with like these technology companies to say, what are the skills, you know, what are the types of jobs that are not going to be automated that can't be replicated by a computer or Rosie the Robot, you know, that we can really start to prepare young people for.

You know, driverless cars, they are great, they're going to take some jobs away, sure but they also deliver us as consumers, you know, faster options, better options and cheaper options. So, you know, technology, I'm not one of those doom and gloom type of people out there.

REGAN: Right. We have to think differently.

ONWUKA: I think we need just to be smart. Exactly.

REGAN: Patrice, it's good to see you. Thank you so much.

ONWUKA: Good to see you too.

REGAN: All right, Nancy Pelosi is doubling down on her comments that bonuses that companies are handing out right now due to tax reform are simply crumbs.

Well, now Debbie Wasserman Schultz is joining the act saying, "One thousand dollars doesn't go very far." How on earth can the Democrats look at anybody with a straight face and say things like this? This is nothing but a let them eat cake message, they're just wanting to try to win mid-term elections and they cannot admit that anything good is happening in our economy. I'll tell you one thing, a thousand bucks is a lot of money and it's a lot of money to a lot of people, Debbie, Nancy, maybe not to you, but to a lot of people. We will debate this, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Nancy Pelosi dismissing once again those bonuses that companies are giving because of tax reform and saying they are crumbs, that's it, just crumbs, a thousand bucks is nothing. Take a listen to Debbie Wasserman Schultz today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DEBBIE WASSERMAN SCHULTZ (D), FLORIDA CONGRESSWOMAN: Frankly, if you look at the bonuses, I mean, which, I haven't heard of a corporate bonuses more than a thousand dollars so far. But, I'm not sure that a thousand dollars which is taxable goes very far for almost anyone.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

REGAN: Actually I have heard bonuses of more than a thousand dollars by some companies. Anyway, even if it's just $500, or a thousand dollars, I mean, this is real money, why don't the Democrats get that. I thought that they were the party representing the people, hard working Americans to whom a thousand dollars matters to.

Donald J. Trump for President Advisory Board Member Gina Loudon is here and Democratic Strategist Robin Biro, they're joining right now.

Gina, you know, this is not chump change. I mean, maybe for Nancy Pelosi it is but for most Americans this matters.

GINA LOUDON, DONALD J. TRUMP PRESIDENT ADVISORY BOARD MEMBER: This is the single most, elitist statement I've ever heard. I think Debbie Wasserman Schultz is thinking in her mind, well, hey, I have a perm that costs more than a thousand dollars. But you know what? To your average minimum wage worker out there that they claim to champion who makes upward of $15,000 a year, that's 1/15th of their income. I don't care who you are or what your income is but if somebody told you we're going to get a 1/15th increase in your income this year, I know about you, I would be pretty excited.

So to say that it's chump change or to refer to it as chump, well, first of all, she is minimalizing it, because as you said, it's more you add on the parental leave that result to the bonuses, the stock options, the list goes on and on. They look like elitist losers, Trish, who have no concepts on how to reach their voters anymore.

REGAN: I think it's a big, big mistake, Robin, I think that this is suicide for them because Americans are looking at that -- thank goodness, you know, a little extra money. A lot of Americans, they are one car payment away from not being able to feed their family, that's the reality of the economy out there and I realize that Nancy Pelosi and Debbie Wasserman Schultz don't get that, they live in a different reality but they ought to get out of their cocoon now and then and see how people really are struggling.

ROBIN BIRO, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: You better believe it. And, you know, that's mighty rich coming from Nancy Pelosi whose net worth is $39.3 million. So I do have a problem with her being the messenger of that statement. My problem with it, though, is that it's emotional.

You know, this Money is money. I've said this before. And it makes a difference to everyday Americans. They should have pointed out the disparity and maybe the hypocrisy that Donald Trump himself said that he won't benefit from this tax plan, when in fact we know that he will from the corporate pass throughs, the alternative minimum tax and the estate tax.

REGAN: I'll tell you, Robin, I've given them their talking point. You've heard me on the private equity carried interest loophole which was basically a big give away for real estate investors benefit from the private equity investors are benefiting from this and, you know, I will tell you, private equity investors they actually shouldn't. I've said before, this is nearly criminal when you think about it because they are calling their income an investment and I can't do that, you can't do that, Gina can't do that. Income is income, investment is investment. I digress.

But in other words, you're right, the Democrats, they could do so much more, there are opportunities to go after what maybe makes the administration vulnerable and the Republicans vulnerable but they're not taking them, they don't get it, do they not understand it?

BIRO: No, They really don't. I agree with GINA, this seems elitist to me on its face and I'm fearful that we are losing the message. We already had lost so much with the middle class and the Rust Belt, the far (ph) state. We can't put out statements like this.

REGAN: Gina, look, you know, it's good for the Republicans, I will tell you that because come midterms the economy is doing well and people have a little more in their pocket each week and Nancy Pelosi and Debbie Wasserman Schultz and Chuck Schumer and the rest of them keep saying this is nothing but crumbs, they will become, the let them eat cake party.

LOUDON: Absolutely. It's like the dying bray of a donkey or something where you can't believe like it's literally saying this because it's only digging its own grave. And that is exactly how I saw this when I heard it, because I think that you're average person out there who was enjoying the benefits of the economy is going to be really tired of all of the class warfare going on and frankly just all of the identity politics in general.

The Democrats have got to get another message if they're ever going to win again, because that one is tired and old, and the American people are seeing what happens when we can all rise up. And you know what? Most people don't care if Donald Trump himself does benefit in some way as long a t rest of America is benefiting in big ways too. That's what the President was talking about when he said we can all rise up. I want you all to be as rich as me. That's the message.

REGAN: Yes, look, we're all very aspirational, as we should be. It's part of what has made. This nation is so great. Thank you so much, Gina and Robin.

We're off the highs of the session but still up 70 right there on the Dow. Liz has got you.

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes, but Trish, did you see this. We're looking at a snapback reversal at this hour --

END

urn:contentItem:5VJY-K8N1-DY0W-41D4-00000-00President Trump Advancing 'America First' Agenda in Davos; North Korea Calls for Unification; Companies Invest in America; Tax Reform2018-01-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:27ZLexisNexisPresident Trump Advancing 'America First' Agenda in Davos; North Korea Calls for Unification; Companies Invest in America; Tax ReformLanhamFULL TEXT

TRISH REGAN, "THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT" HOST: I love that. I really do. It's great to see because I think so many people were so pessimistic about this, and you're right.

CAVUTO: Amazing.

REGAN: They could pay for themselves, wouldn't that be great, but you're also right on that spending front. Neil, thank you.

Breaking right now, everyone, President Trump and several Cabinet members are meeting with global business leaders right now in Davos, Switzerland. They're discussing the success of America's tax plan and why businesses should be investing in the United States of America. All of this as we see again, another record day on Wall Street, up 169 there on the Dow.

I'm Trish Regan. Welcome, everyone to "The Intelligence Report."

President Trump, taking his America first message right to the world stage. Tomorrow morning, the President is going to be delivering what many are calling the most important economic speech of his presidency. And in that speech, the President is also expected to pressure world leaders to do more to stop Kim Jong-un and his nuclear ambitions.

You know, I said it over and over and over again and I'm going to say it again, we have not even scratched the surface when it comes to economic pressure, economic pressure on China.

Senator Cory Gardner has been leading the charge on this effort and he's going to join me in just a few minutes.

But first, let's go to Blake Burman in Davos where the President is wrapping up his first full day at the economic forum. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: And he's not even done. As we just saw there, he is sitting down for dinner, 8:00 here in the evening local time with European business leaders. Quite the crowd that he has with him here in Davos.

You just saw a little bit of that play out. The President is sitting down with leaders, for example, of Adidas, Bayer, Nokia, Nestle, Volvo, Deloitte, just to name a few. This is really been a two-fold message, really a two-fold reasoning for the President coming here to Davos.

The first you just hit on it, security issues that the United States and the world is dealing with, but also the economic message that the President wants to get across and the trade message he and his administration want to get across. Sitting down with those business leaders, those CEOs moments ago, here is President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I just want to say that there has been a lot of warmth, a lot of respect for our country and a lot of money, billions and billions of dollars is coming into the U.S. and people are very happy with what we've done, not only on the tax bill, but also cutting of regulations. And I think also being a cheerleader for our country. You know, if you're not a cheerleader for your company or for your country, no matter what happens, it is not going to work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: So the President got into town today. His delegation has been here for a couple days though. And the commerce secretary, Wilbur Ross made some headlines yesterday when he said that trade wars are happening every single day and U.S. troops, as he put it, are just starting to gear up.

On this very set earlier this morning when he spoke with Maria Bartiromo, the Commerce Secretary said it is not that he feels that there is going to be a race to the bottom, but he also clarified by saying the reality of it is there are trade abuses happening every day.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILBUR ROSS, SECRETARY OF COMMERCE: What I meant was this, every time someone violates trade rules, that to me, is act of war. Dumping steel is an act of war. Dumping aluminum is an act of war, dumping anything. Forcing technology transfers, same thing. That is what I had in mind.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: All right, so back to the President. He is at that dinner right now with European business leaders that will wrap up his day once he is done. He also met today, by the way, with the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu and the British Prime Minister, Theresa May. Tomorrow he has two more meetings with the presidents of Rwanda and Switzerland separately.

And then, of course, Trish, 8:00 Eastern, 2:00 p.m. in the afternoon here in Davos, the President will give that widely anticipated speech before the huge forum and really before the world. Trish?

REGAN: I'm looking forward to it. You know where I am going to be, watching FBN at 8:00 a.m. tomorrow morning, tune in. Maria is there in Davos as well. Thank you soy much, Blake.

It gets back to things like immigration. There's a lot that fold into it.

ONWUKA: There is. I mean, reaching (ph) the workforce for the future I think is one of those topics that people are afraid of and I think unfortunately you have some folks on the left who are using it as a political chip and a political ploy which they really shouldn't be, but we do need to think about from a policy perspective how do we bring together business, our higher education system, our K-12 education system and with like these technology companies to say, what are the skills, you know, what are the types of jobs that are not going to be automated that can't be replicated by a computer or Rosie the Robot, you know, that we can really start to prepare young people for.

You know, driverless cars, they are great, they're going to take some jobs away, sure but they also deliver us as consumers, you know, faster options, better options and cheaper options. So, you know, technology, I'm not one of those doom and gloom type of people out there.

REGAN: Right. We have to think differently.

ONWUKA: I think we need just to be smart. Exactly.

REGAN: Patrice, it's good to see you. Thank you so much.

ONWUKA: Good to see you too.

REGAN: All right, Nancy Pelosi is doubling down on her comments that bonuses that companies are handing out right now due to tax reform are simply crumbs.

Well, now Debbie Wasserman Schultz is joining the act saying, "One thousand dollars doesn't go very far." How on earth can the Democrats look at anybody with a straight face and say things like this? This is nothing but a let them eat cake message, they're just wanting to try to win mid-term elections and they cannot admit that anything good is happening in our economy. I'll tell you one thing, a thousand bucks is a lot of money and it's a lot of money to a lot of people, Debbie, Nancy, maybe not to you, but to a lot of people. We will debate this, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Nancy Pelosi dismissing once again those bonuses that companies are giving because of tax reform and saying they are crumbs, that's it, just crumbs, a thousand bucks is nothing. Take a listen to Debbie Wasserman Schultz today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DEBBIE WASSERMAN SCHULTZ (D), FLORIDA CONGRESSWOMAN: Frankly, if you look at the bonuses, I mean, which, I haven't heard of a corporate bonuses more than a thousand dollars so far. But, I'm not sure that a thousand dollars which is taxable goes very far for almost anyone.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

REGAN: Actually I have heard bonuses of more than a thousand dollars by some companies. Anyway, even if it's just $500, or a thousand dollars, I mean, this is real money, why don't the Democrats get that. I thought that they were the party representing the people, hard working Americans to whom a thousand dollars matters to.

Donald J. Trump for President Advisory Board Member Gina Loudon is here and Democratic Strategist Robin Biro, they're joining right now.

Gina, you know, this is not chump change. I mean, maybe for Nancy Pelosi it is but for most Americans this matters.

GINA LOUDON, DONALD J. TRUMP PRESIDENT ADVISORY BOARD MEMBER: This is the single most, elitist statement I've ever heard. I think Debbie Wasserman Schultz is thinking in her mind, well, hey, I have a perm that costs more than a thousand dollars. But you know what? To your average minimum wage worker out there that they claim to champion who makes upward of $15,000 a year, that's 1/15th of their income. I don't care who you are or what your income is but if somebody told you we're going to get a 1/15th increase in your income this year, I know about you, I would be pretty excited.

So to say that it's chump change or to refer to it as chump, well, first of all, she is minimalizing it, because as you said, it's more you add on the parental leave that result to the bonuses, the stock options, the list goes on and on. They look like elitist losers, Trish, who have no concepts on how to reach their voters anymore.

REGAN: I think it's a big, big mistake, Robin, I think that this is suicide for them because Americans are looking at that -- thank goodness, you know, a little extra money. A lot of Americans, they are one car payment away from not being able to feed their family, that's the reality of the economy out there and I realize that Nancy Pelosi and Debbie Wasserman Schultz don't get that, they live in a different reality but they ought to get out of their cocoon now and then and see how people really are struggling.

ROBIN BIRO, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: You better believe it. And, you know, that's mighty rich coming from Nancy Pelosi whose net worth is $39.3 million. So I do have a problem with her being the messenger of that statement. My problem with it, though, is that it's emotional.

You know, this Money is money. I've said this before. And it makes a difference to everyday Americans. They should have pointed out the disparity and maybe the hypocrisy that Donald Trump himself said that he won't benefit from this tax plan, when in fact we know that he will from the corporate pass throughs, the alternative minimum tax and the estate tax.

REGAN: I'll tell you, Robin, I've given them their talking point. You've heard me on the private equity carried interest loophole which was basically a big give away for real estate investors benefit from the private equity investors are benefiting from this and, you know, I will tell you, private equity investors they actually shouldn't. I've said before, this is nearly criminal when you think about it because they are calling their income an investment and I can't do that, you can't do that, Gina can't do that. Income is income, investment is investment. I digress.

But in other words, you're right, the Democrats, they could do so much more, there are opportunities to go after what maybe makes the administration vulnerable and the Republicans vulnerable but they're not taking them, they don't get it, do they not understand it?

BIRO: No, They really don't. I agree with GINA, this seems elitist to me on its face and I'm fearful that we are losing the message. We already had lost so much with the middle class and the Rust Belt, the far (ph) state. We can't put out statements like this.

REGAN: Gina, look, you know, it's good for the Republicans, I will tell you that because come midterms the economy is doing well and people have a little more in their pocket each week and Nancy Pelosi and Debbie Wasserman Schultz and Chuck Schumer and the rest of them keep saying this is nothing but crumbs, they will become, the let them eat cake party.

LOUDON: Absolutely. It's like the dying bray of a donkey or something where you can't believe like it's literally saying this because it's only digging its own grave. And that is exactly how I saw this when I heard it, because I think that you're average person out there who was enjoying the benefits of the economy is going to be really tired of all of the class warfare going on and frankly just all of the identity politics in general.

The Democrats have got to get another message if they're ever going to win again, because that one is tired and old, and the American people are seeing what happens when we can all rise up. And you know what? Most people don't care if Donald Trump himself does benefit in some way as long a t rest of America is benefiting in big ways too. That's what the President was talking about when he said we can all rise up. I want you all to be as rich as me. That's the message.

REGAN: Yes, look, we're all very aspirational, as we should be. It's part of what has made. This nation is so great. Thank you so much, Gina and Robin.

We're off the highs of the session but still up 70 right there on the Dow. Liz has got you.

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes, but Trish, did you see this. We're looking at a snapback reversal at this hour --

END
