urn:contentItem:5RY2-S6Y1-DXH2-60F0-00000-00President Trump Appeared To Be Not So Happy After Signing The $1.3 Trillion Spending Bill; The Stock Markets Were Hit Hard This Week After Announcement Of New Tariffs On China; China Also Retaliates With $3 Billion On U.S. Goods; Media Says That With John Bolton's Position In The Trump Administration It Is More Likely That The U.S. Will Face Potential Wars; Nine Iranian Nationals And One Iranian Entity Facing Sanctions Today From The Treasury Department; More And More Cities In California Are Following The Footsteps Of Los Alamitos Who Chose To Opt Out From Sanctuary State Law Last Week; Attorney General Jeff Sessions Officially Announce The New Regulation That Effectively Bans Bump Stocks; Tesla Founder Elon Musk Hit Mark Zuckerberg With The Delete Facebook Movement, Encouraging People To Delete Their Account On Facebook For Zuckerberg's Negligence To Protect Its Users2018-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:28ZLexisNexisRISK & REWARD5:00 PM ESTTom Reed, Thomas McInerney, Michelle Steel, Patrice Lee Onwuka, Eric SchifferNEWSFinancial032301cb.233President Trump Appeared To Be Not So Happy After Signing The $1.3 Trillion Spending Bill; The Stock Markets Were Hit Hard This Week After Announcement Of New Tariffs On China; China Also Retaliates With $3 Billion On U.S. Goods; Media Says That With John Bolton's Position In The Trump Administration It Is More Likely That The U.S. Will Face Potential Wars; Nine Iranian Nationals And One Iranian Entity Facing Sanctions Today From The Treasury Department; More And More Cities In California Are Following The Footsteps Of Los Alamitos Who Chose To Opt Out From Sanctuary State Law Last Week; Attorney General Jeff Sessions Officially Announce The New Regulation That Effectively Bans Bump Stocks; Tesla Founder Elon Musk Hit Mark Zuckerberg With The Delete Facebook Movement, Encouraging People To Delete Their Account On Facebook For Zuckerberg's Negligence To Protect Its UsersConnell McShane, Nicole Petallides, Steve Hilton

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: My highest duty is to keep America safe. Therefore, as a matter of national security, I've signed this omnibus budget bill. There are a lot of things I'm unhappy about in this bill. There are a lot of things that we shouldn't have had in this bill, but we were in the sense forced if we want to build our military. We were forced to have.

There are some things we should have in the bill, but I say to Congress, I will never sign another bill like this again. I'm not going to do it again. Nobody read it. It's only hours old. Some people don't even know what -- $1.3 trillion. It's the second largest ever. We need to take care of our military.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN HOST: All this on a day when the markets went down. The Dow, S&P, NASDAQ suffering their worst week in more than two years. The Dow shedding more than 1100 points in two sessions. Trade jitters have been rocking Wall Street.

Then, after that veto tease you saw, President Trump did indeed sign the $1.3 trillion, 2200-page spending bill today. He says he's not happy about it taking aim at the Democrats saying never again and calling them out for wasteful spending on personal projects and for not extending legal protections for the DREAMers.

Tonight we'll break it all down. Also tonight, the White House cracking down on Iran. Nine Iranian nationals and one Iranian entity facing sanctions today from the Treasury Department.

Tonight, we have a guest who says it's more proof the Iran deal is just a bad deal. Also more Facebook data leak fallout. The billionaire Tesla founder Elon Musk hitting Mark Zuckerberg hard, jumping on the delete Facebook movement, deleting his own page and the SpaceX and Tesla pages as well.

Tonight, a guest who recommends that do you the same.

It is an all-star guest line up. The Republican Congressman Tom Reed here on that spending bill. Retired lieutenant general Thomas McInerney says it's about time the military got some salary hikes. Former British Prime Minister David Cameron adviser, Steve Hilton on the prospect of a trade war with China.

More California cities looking to reject the state's sanctuary status. Orange County supervisor Michelle Steel on her new push. It's all here and it's all tonight.

Politics and money, we've got you covered. Good to be with you on a Friday. I'm Connell McShane. Risk & Reward starts right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We have tremendous opposition from the Democrats. So if we take something for the military, they want something for, in many cases, things that are really a wasted sum of money. It's not right, because we need to take care of our military, and because the Democrats, who don't believe in that, added things that they wanted in order to get their votes.

DACA recipients have been treated extremely badly by the Democrats. We wanted to include DACA. We wanted to have them in this bill. Eight hundred thousand people, and actually it could even be more, and we wanted to include DACA in this bill. The Democrats would not do it.

To prevent the omnibus situation from ever happening again, I'm calling on Congress to give me a line-item veto for all government spending bills, and the Senate must end, they must end the filibuster rule and get down to work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: President Trump calling out the Democrats as we wrap up what was the worst week on Wall Street in more than two years. The Dow shedding more than 1100 points here over the course of two days. And we're going to talk a lot about that tonight.

First, though, President Trump signing that $1.3 trillion spending bill after threatening to veto because his border wall wasn't fully funded and there was no fix, he said for DACA. President signing what was a monster piece of legislation, reluctantly saying in order to secure a necessary increase in military spending he had to give money to Democratic projects that he called a, quote, "wasted sum of money."

Let's talk more though, about these markets. Boy, it was a brutal week and just a terrible two days. We have fears of a trade war on Wall Street, maybe some questions about the Fed as well.

We bring in Nicole Petallides who's live this evening on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, and more than anything, Nicole, just another, just another terrible finish to the day in that final hour, right?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, you make a great point, Connell. Because we saw much of the same yesterday. We started off to the downside and drifted lower only to finish down over 700 points. And there was hope for somewhat of a bounce back today, you can see in our intraday chart here that we're showing, that you did see some green in the morning, so there was some hope for those tech and financial groups that really have gotten hit hard lately but they just couldn't keep them out there, so many elements that are hitting these markets.

The Dow finishes down 424 points, today at 1.7 percentage. It's down about 1500 points for the week. Worst week for stocks since January of 2016. The Dow took out the February 9th, the February lows, the S&P 500 did not, but it got close.

Taking a look at some of the big losers for the week. We saw 3M, G.E., Goldman Sachs down between 8 and 10 percent, and then we saw the defense stocks. That was one group that did well on the heel of the spending bill and more military support.

Facebook was a big issue, it hit tech stocks, and that was down about 13 percent for the week and drop box was the winner. That was a new IPO in the technology sector and was well received. It was up about 35 percent. Big picture, there are still worries and we saw some rotation. Defense stocks and energy did all right. Back to you.

MCSHANE: Yes. It was rough. Get out of there, Nicole. Thanks a lot. We appreciate. Have a good weekend.

Let's get to this massive spending bill now. The New York Republican Congressman, Tom Reed (AUDIO GAP) who voted against it. He joins us now. Quite a day, congressman. We're looking at the president who was thinking he said about a veto, but he signed it, your thoughts?

REP. TOM REED (R), NEW YORK: Well, you know, obviously, I voted against it, and I shared the concern that was expressed by the president about the fact that it wasn't in a position to be read and digested.

But on top of that, the massive amount of spending, I totally appreciate the defense side of the equation.

MCSHANE: Yes.

REED: But the amount of spending overall is just mind-boggling to me. And we have to get this national debt and the debt crisis under control.

MCSHANE: I'm going to get to that defense in a moment. Are you disappointed though, in the president's decision?

REED: Well, you know, obviously I understand where he's at. He was in a very difficult situation.

MCSHANE: Right.

REED: Shutting down the government versus signing that bill. It's incumbent upon us on Congress to lead on the issue. I appreciate the president sending the message, we need to do better in Congress and that's why I'm hopeful the next go around.

MCSHANE: He used the argument, to your point, that he had, basically no choice if he wanted the money for the military than to sign this. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: While we're very disappointed in the 1.3 trillion, nobody more disappointed than me because the number is so large, it will start coming down. We had no choice but to fund our military because we have to have, by far, the strongest military in the world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: I was down in Washington all week and I heard Paul Ryan make that same exact argument a number of times. So it's the idea, congressman, that I guess you're never going to get a chance like this again if you don't sign this. Is there something to that, that you would never have a chance to have this type of an increase for military spending?

REED: Well, I think we just we definitely were on a position on the defense side. We needed to make those investments because our men and women were being put in harm's way where we were.

MCSHANE: Right.

REED: But at the end of the day, it shows exactly what was negotiated here. They went more on the defense side in order to get the nondefense number where they need because they needed those 10 Democrats plus or minus to come over to support the bill. That's why going to 51 votes on the Senate, at least on the appropriation the spending bills, to me is a reform the Senate should strongly consider at least going down that path. Maybe not blowing it up for anything, but at least for the appropriation spending bills.

MCSHANE: Right. Boy, I wonder if they'll do that. It doesn't seem like this any kind of movement, right, to go in that direction?

REED: No, it doesn't.

MCSHANE: Yes.

REED: It's been very clear us to that they don't want to change that threshold. They want the Senate wants to continue that archaic rule but that's up to the Senate to decide. All I can do is vote my conscience, which is a no.

MCSHANE: Right.

REED: This debt crisis is upon us. We need to get the spending under control, and if we don't, our children and grandchildren are going to be saddled with such debt and this county is threatened by this debt crisis today is going off as we speak.

(CROSSTALK)

MCSHANE: One quick political question, Congressman on this, I know you say you voted your conscience and voted no. But how worried are you about the midterms at this point and the blowback from a bill like this, the effect it could have on Republicans?

REED: You know I think if we just continue as individual members to go out and work hard and put our voice and our positions out there, we're going to be fine on the Republican side. We have tax reform, we're seeing the benefits in the economy.

Jobless numbers, the president hasn't been given credit for, in my humble opinion, you know, low unemployment numbers, lowest levels for Hispanic and African-American unemployment, we got to send that message and sell that message to the American people and I think they'll be with us at the end of the day.

MCSHANE: I want to get your thoughts on one of the story before we let you go, just on Iran, nine Iranian nationals today, one Iranian entity facing sanctions also the prospect of federal charges. Let's take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROD ROSENSTEIN, UNITED STATES DEPUTY ATTORNEY GENERAL: Federal grand jury in the southern District of New York indicted nine Iranians for conspiring to hack into computers and to defraud American and foreign universities, businesses and government agencies. This indictment alleges that the defendants worked on behalf of the Iranian government, specifically the Islamic revolutionary guard corps.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: The charges you heard that these Iranians essentially, you know, like they hacked into hundreds of universities and other organizations and stole information on behalf of the government of Iran, so it comes at a time, we're getting a new national security adviser, Iran is in the news anyway, in particular the future of the Iran nuclear deal. Your thoughts.

REED: Absolutely. I support the actions taken by the Justice Department as well as treasury in regards to going after Iran for these actions of hacking into our systems and stealing our information and putting real American interests at risk.

And this is the right thing to do and I hope they continue to increase the message that we're not going to put up with this anymore and we're going to hold people accountable for these actions against our interests.

MCSHANE: And what about the Iranian nuclear deal?

REED: You know, I think with the new -- with John Bolton coming into the administration, I think what you're going to see is what we all advocated for when we strongly oppose that agreement. We need to hold Iran accountable. You can't buy peace through appeasement.

We need to send the message we want peace through strength and that's what you're going to get out of the new administration direction I think coming down the pipeline.

MCSHANE: You think they'll rip it up?

REED: I think absolutely. I think at a minimum, it will hold them extreme -- hold them accountable to each and every corner of that agreement, if not destroy it and move forward and hold Iran accountable for its actions on nuclearization.

MCSHANE: All right. Congressman, good to see you tonight. Thank you very much for coming on. We appreciate it all the time.

REED: Pleasure to be with you.

MCSHANE: Congressman Reed, upstate New York.

Now, President Trump with that announcement about John Bolton we just mentioned briefly that the ambassador would come and take the place of H.R. McMaster's national security adviser, that was last night big story, right? Our next guest thinks it's a great choice. Former Air Force assistant vice chief of staff, there he is, the retired lieutenant general Thomas McInerney. He'll tell us why next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN BOLTON, FORMER UNITED STATES AMBASSADOR TO THE UNITED NATIONS: I think the consensus would be that the national security adviser among whatever functions he or she might have has two critical roles. Number one, making sure that the president has the full range of options presented to him to make the decisions that only the president can make.

And the other side of the coin is when the president makes a decision, the national security adviser is, among others, but certainly one of the leading implementers of the decision, making sure that the bureaucracies out there get the decision and implement it, and I've been in lots of bureaucracies, and I've seen the way that bureaucracies that don't like decisions sit on them.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Former Ambassador to the United Nations John Bolton is set to take the place of H.R. McMaster as national security adviser to the president, and he laid out there how he might handle the office.

We're joined by former air force assistant vice chief of staff, retired lieutenant general Thomas McInerney with us tonight. Good to see you, general. Thank you very much for coming on.

THOMAS MCINERNEY, RETIRED UNITED STATES AIR FORCE: Thanks for having me, Connell.

MCSHANE: You know, we've had I think 23 hours or something like that to digest this, I think maybe not the announcement, but the timing of this caught just about everybody including maybe Ambassador Bolton off-guard last night. But now that we've thought about it a little bit what do you make of the move by the president?

MCINERNEY: I think it's the most brilliant selection of a national security adviser that I've seen in the last 50 years, and at least three of the last 50 years became secretary of state. But John Bolton has more experience than those three including Henry Kissinger.

MCSHANE: Right.

MCINERNEY: So I think it is a great tribute to President Trump that he had the courage to select such a strong national security adviser who is so articulate, can present the issues and as John pointed out, his job is to give a balanced presentation, all the options to the president.

MCSHANE: Right.

MCINERNEY: And then ensure implementation. He knows how to do both base on his experience, so I couldn't think of a finer person and a more capable person, Connell.

MCSHANE: Kissinger, Powell and I guess one other, right, that went to be secretary of state.

MCINERNEY: Rice.

MCSHANE: Rice, of course, yes, that's right, Condoleezza Rice was secretary of state and was in this position. I read a lot about it today and even seen some of our colleagues in the media talking about it, and you'll be surprised, general, not everybody agrees with your assessment.

Let's take a listen to a little bit of that then you can you react. Here's some media reaction to the appointment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This may be the worst thing he's done. He said to them no more stupid wars. Now he brings in the godfather of stupid wars, John Bolton!

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think that the risk of a war, of a shooting war with Iran and North Korea are substantially greater than they were this morning. I think it dramatically increases the risk that a lot of Americans and Koreans, perhaps Japanese end up dead.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: John Bolton, he is the hammer and everything is a nail.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Just throwing all the toys at Iran, I'm mad! I'm getting rid of everything.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: All right, general. So, the idea obviously that we're more likely to go to war now than we were before this appointment.

MCINERNEY: Yes, Connell, we're less likely to go to war with this appointment than if others. It's like if we still had Curtis LeMay who dropped two atomic bombs on Japan, if he became the chairman or joint chiefs of staff, now you brought him back, the fact is that is a signal of peace through strength.

John is a brilliant negotiator. He understands it. But he's not afraid to make hard decisions. I think there's a much higher possibility of peace in the resolution in both Korea and Iran being solid without war with John Bolton there.

MCSHANE: Interesting. Peace through strength. I want to ask you about Defense Secretary Jim Mattis while I have you here, general. Because this came up with the president's comments today about the spending bill, which he did sign, we're talking earlier about why he signed it because he could help the military. Here is Secretary Mattis.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAMES MATTIS, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF DEFENSE: In 1790 in George Washington's first annual address to Congress, he stated to be prepared for war is one of the most defective means of preserving the peace.

As the president noted today, we received the largest military budget in history. Reversing many years of decline and unpredictable funding. And together, we are going to make our military stronger than ever.

We, in the military are humbled and grateful to the American people for their sacrifices on behalf of this funding.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: We take a quick look at some of the defense-related stocks in the trade today, remember it was a big time down day on Wall Street but the likes of Lockheed Martin, Raytheon, Northrop Grumman all faring quite well. Even with the Dow down 400 plus points all of those.

All right. General, what, how did you view this, because part of it was, we talk about earlier in the show, is that there are a number of people who are conservatives who are quite upset that the president ended up signing this bill and they don't like the runaway spending. But those who argue in favor of it are using the military to make their arguments. What's your take?

MCINERNEY: Well, I think it's correct. I don't like that spending bill either. I don't think they should have caved on all those domestic programs that have been flush with money the last eight years. People don't realize it, Connell, but Barack Obama left a hollow military. Now I was on active duty when Jimmy Carter, just before Reagan came in and left a hollow military, but the media has elected not to discuss it and point it out.

MCSHANE: Well, the president talks about it a lot. Tell us how specifically. What does that mean?

MCINERNEY: Well, it means like our in commission rates are at 50 percent. They were 80 and 90 percent, this is for aircraft.

MCSHANE: Right.

MCINERNEY: There were 80 and 90 percent when I was in active duty and commanding. We used to have 155 tactical fighter wings and the squadrons in the air force. Today we've got 50. The fact is not only are we smaller but they're less capable. The maintenance problem we had.

MCSHANE: Right.

MCINERNEY: We had two very serious accidents in the Pacific on destroyers at sea, and all these things have come to, I think, a very critical tipping point. And what worry--

(CROSSTALK)

MCSHANE: Right, and that's the point. It's critical enough that, you know, you would make that argument, then we're not crazy about all the other things maybe in a spending bill but we just need this that badly. That's essentially the argument.

MCINERNEY: Exactly, Connell.

MCSHANE: Yes.

MCINERNEY: And it takes a while to build that industrial buildup to get those spare parts and those new airplanes and all those things. So there's lag time in front of us and it must be done now and I would accept what Secretary Mattis said that we need it now and that the president had to make this decision.

MCSHANE: Well, your argument did win the day, and the bill was signed. General, good to see you, sir. Thank you very much.

MCINERNEY: Good seeing you, Connell.

MCSHANE: Markets, boy, the Dow shedding 1100 plus points just over a couple of sessions. President Trump with the China tariffs. China with its response, its own tariff threat that we'll talk about. In fact, our next guest says it's smaller than expected which could be a sign of progress.

He's the former senior adviser to the former U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron, that's Steve Hilton. He's coming up after a quick break. We'll be right back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: China is going to end up treating us fairly, for many years, they had free reign, they don't have free reign anymore. We're very friendly with China. We have great relationships with China, and look, it's time. It's time. Last year we lost $500 billion on trade with China. We can't let that happen.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: All right, President Trump today saying he's making progress on the China trade negotiation following his announcement that the administration will impose tariffs on about $50 billion worth of Chinese imports.

Now China did have a response of its own here on this Friday with its own tariff threat. The Chinese said they are planning to slap taxes on three billion of U.S. goods. This affects only about 2 percent of China's imports from the United States compared to roughly 10 percent of trade in the opposite direction.

So let's talk about it, we're joined by the former senior adviser to David Cameron, we know him as the host of the Next Revolution of the Fox News Channel, Steve Hilton is with us. You know, a lot of people saw that, it came out last night and Friday in China, and they said here we go, trade war. But what do you say?

STEVE HILTON, HOST, FOX NEWS: I think we need -- I think it's a good start, basically. I think we need to be much, much tougher with China than we've been for many years, and I think that you're seeing this administration get to that tough position, not just with this measure but also previously not long ago, they announced that CFIUS the committee on foreign investment in United States would take a much tougher line on foreign investments.

They blocked that really big tech deal where one of our most important tech companies, Qualcomm, the key to the future of mobile technology is going to be bought by a company that they thought was a security risk to China. I think it's that transfer of technology to China who wants to use it for their plans that they stated for world domination. That's what we've got to watch out for.

And it looks to me like the tariffs are part of that. But the other thing the administration are doing are actually more important.

MCSHANE: Now what about the Chinese response, though? I mention the three billion that they've talked about, you say a drop in the bucket or the start of something that could be much bigger and far more dangerous. Certainly there are concerns whether they're justified or not on Wall Street, the market since this protection is talked has started is not -- has not done well. The last couple of days down 1100 plus on the Dow, so.

HILTON: This is a much bigger and more long-term question than even these tariffs. It's about how are we going to handle a really aggressive nation like China that has set out to beat America on every important front and they said that they're going to do that using the latest technology.

I think a little fight over tariffs is really beside the point. (Inaudible) this even if the trade between the U.S. and China went to zero, we'd still have a massive problem, not economically but militarily, the way that they're using technology to hack into our government and steal data and influence all sorts of things around the world.

MCSHANE: Yes.

HILTON: Look at the way that they're spending so much on infrastructure to try and control countries all around the world. That's the big issue.

MCSHANE: I want to ask you we have another topic, so I just request a short answer on this. But if -- because you have experience obviously working on other governments. Some say there would have been a better way, either, a, you go to the WTO or at least you build an alliance with other countries and go after China altogether as opposed to kind of one on one.

HILTON: I think that may be right in the small area of the trade imbalance. But they're not going to listen to all those other countries or the WTO on the big question of the strategic move they're making to become the dominant nation in the world in the 21st century. Only America can resist that.

MCSHANE: OK, we'll get back to this. But let me go to another topic, former California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger saying that the Republicans in California are going down. Let's take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER, FORMER GOVERNOR OF CALIFORNIA: Our politics must be the politics of solutions and substance. Today we are the Titanic after it hits the iceberg, but before the last bit of the ship submerged.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Now you have an interview out there in California on your very fine program that I mentioned earlier, the Next Revolution, Sunday on the Fox News Channel. I don't know if he responds to this, but tell us a little bit about it.

HILTON: Well, actually, I was there for that event with former Governor Schwarzenegger. And that's where I sat down with him for the interview. Look, the thing is that he's not wrong about the political position of the Republican Party here in California where I'm speaking to you from today.

MCSHANE: Yes.

HILTON: California -- the Republicans in California haven't won statewide office for years, over a decade. They're complete -- they're losing more and more seats in the state legislature so the Democrats are in complete control of California politically.

And you see the result in the terrible policies that are really harming business and society throughout the state. So, you got to get back in there somewhere that he was a winner in California, so I think it's important to listen to his message.

MCSHANE: It's always interesting to listen to him no matter what. So we look forward to that. All right. We'll watch on Sunday, Steve. Thanks for joining us tonight, we appreciate it.

HILTON: Great to see you.

MCSHANE: We have Steve Hilton Next Revolution 9 p.m. Sunday evenings on Fox News Channel. So don't miss that with Mr. Schwarzenegger.

In a moment, we've been hot on tracking the California cities ditching the state sanctuary policies and after Los Alamitos voted to opt out. Tonight, another California administrator here to say her area too may vote to quit California sanctuary policies.

The Orange County supervisor, just ahead, Michelle Steel here to speak out.

MCSHANE: We do have some Friday evening breaking news here as the Attorney General Jeff Sessions has just made it official announcement. A new regulation that effectively bans bump stocks, as they're known. We thought this might be coming and now this is the way the administration is going about it, they asked for bump stocks to fall within the definition of machine guns under federal law which will make them illegal.

Presidential tweet just before the announcement from Attorney General Sessions, here it is. "Obama administration legalized bump stocks. Bad idea. As I promised, the president writes, today the Department of Justice will issue the rule banning bump stocks with a mandate comment period. We will ban all devices that turn legal weapons into illegal machine guns."

So the president said he would take care of that on his own. Remember he told members of Congress meeting at the White House that that's how he would handle it. Apparently this is the method of doing so. More on that to come.

In the meantime, President Trump signing that spending bill today after threatening a veto. Once again, take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I say to Congress I will never sign another bill like this again. I'm not going to do it again. Nobody read it. It's only hours old. Some people don't even know, $1.3 trillion. It's the second largest ever.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: As he walks away, some members of the media did press the president after the announcement. Here it is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Thank you, thank you.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Mr. President, why the veto threat if you know you had to sign the bill?

TRUMP: Well, we'll figure it out in about 20 minutes after you look at it. We're going to figure that out. You're going to figure that out. We looked at it to veto. I looked very seriously at the veto. I was thinking about doing the veto, but because of the incredible gains that we've been able to make for the military, that overrode any of our -- any of our thinking.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: All right, let's bring our panel in and see whether they have figured it out by this evening. Patrice, Patrice Lee Onwuka is with us, the Independent Women's Forum, Washington Times contributor Eric Schiffer is here as well. Thanks to you both.

I know, Eric, I'll start with you on this. There are a number of conservatives who are not happy that the bill was signed and not vetoed. What are your thoughts this evening?

ERIC SCHIFFER, CONTRIBUTOR, WASHINGTON TIMES: I think this was a giant strategic mistake by the president, and I think he's going to regret it. To not have vetoed this is inconsistent with everything that he's done so far.

I mean, he's been so consistent in keeping promises with the base on almost everything but in this situation you're basically abandoning immigration and that was a core issue, the wall, immigration.

MCSHANE: Yes.

SCHIFFER: So--

(CROSSTALK)

MCSHANE: He said he had to for the military. He said he had to.

SCHIFFER: Well, look, I'm a proponent of the military. There's no question. But that's the window dressing. I think that the, and I'm glad they got it but not to the extent that it just throws away immigration. That's the core of his presidency was immigration, and that's what the base was so excited about, and he's just ignored it.

MCSHANE: I started Patrice, with Eric on purpose. I know the base, the Trump base, and we've heard from, you know, whether it's Twitter or whatever it is throughout the day today and many other shows that preceded ours that people in the president's base are not happy with his decision. What do you make of that?

PATRICE LEE ONWUKA, SENIOR FELLOW, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S FORUM: Well, I mean, I think people recognize that, you know, they elected Republicans from top to bottom, from the White House all the way to Congress, expecting that there would be fiscal responsibility.

Looking at the national debt, looking at the driver of debt, and expecting that, you know, once in power, Republicans would hold their -- would hold their own and continue to do what they're supposed to do, but the political realities here were you know that you're in an imperfect situation, where you needed some sort of Democratic support and they felt that, you know, this is the only way to avert a government shutdown. With the second or third within this year alone, so, you know, this is what they had to do.

I do think though, that when we look at our big drivers of national debt--

MCSHANE: Right.

ONWUKA: -- you know, it's really not even just a domestic spending that increased, it's really those entitlement, those mandatory spending and that unfortunately no one is talking about.

MCSHANE: No one is talking about. I was going to say, yes, we haven't even, you know, started to talk about that one yet. One of the olive branches I guess that the president tried to throw out today and we'll talk in a moment about whether there is any political reality in terms of this coming to fruition, but he talked about a line-item veto, right, for all of government spending bills. Let's take a listen once again to the president.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: To prevent the omnibus situation from ever happening again, I'm calling on Congress to give me a line-item veto for all government spending bills, and the Senate must end, they must end the filibuster rule and get down to work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: All right, here's the problem with that, Eric, among other things. And that would require a constitutional amendment, two-thirds vote in both Houses of Congress. I don't think I need to tell you that that's not very likely, is it?

SCHIFFER: Well, conservatives don't need a line-item veto, they need a president that keeps his word. Period.

MCSHANE: All right.

SCHIFFER: And that's what anger so many people that immigration has just been thrown out the door, and that he has ignored the people that brought him to this level of power, he's just completely ignored them. It's so strange because up to this point he's been consistent, it's as if he's just not, he's like he's lost his focus. He lost what he ran on and he's deserted so many millions of people who really have counted on him.

MCSHANE: The president knew that he would take a hit from his base on this just by the tone he was using today. Because that was a somber president for a bill signing ceremony as it was billed.

SCHIFFER: That's right.

MCSHANE: Patrice, we're going to come back to you and get much more from you. Eric, as well, a little bit later in the program. I do have to take a break now. As we've been talking, Liz has been hot on this topic, tracking the California cities ditching the state sanctuary policies, and you know, Los Alamitos I mentioned this earlier, opted out.

Tonight another California administrator is here to say her area too may quit the sanctuary policy coming from the state. It's Michelle Steel, the Orange County supervisor and she will speak out on that topic next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TROY EDGAR, MAYOR, LOST ALAMITOS, CALIFORNIA: I'm really excited. I've been completely thrilled with the outpouring of all the city council members and mayors across the state that have been communicating, saying they were waiting for somebody to come out and do this.

DAVE HARRINGTON, MAYOR OF ALISO VIEJO, CALIFORNIA: I think that's the shot heard around the state of California. So it absolutely inspired me. And I reached out to them right away not only to congratulate them but also, you know, tap into what their experience was and how they managed to get it done.

This makes us less safe. It makes my citizens less safe. I'm responsible for the safety of 50,000 people, so I view this as primary responsibility. You know, government has pretty much two jobs, roads and bridges, public safety. And this erodes that second part which is public safety. So I'm going to fight against it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: All right. Well, this is certainly been a very big topic on this very program. And now more California towns and cities are looking to follow the lead of Los Alamitos and rejecting the state's sanctuary law. Buena Park, Fresno, Thousand Oaks, Aliso Viejo and all of Orange County may now opt out of the sanctuary policy.

We're joined by the Orange County supervisor Michelle Steel. Thank you for joining us this evening. We appreciate it, or this afternoon out in California.

How does all this affecting your city. Tell us about it.

MICHELLE STEEL, SUPERVISOR, ORANGE COUNTY: Well, you know what, actually our city of Los Alamitos, and they started it, I'm just like so proud of them, you know, what they did. So now all Orange County cities are coming out and they want to come out, opt out against this California bad law, and I thought we had to do something about it, so I'm actually asking my colleagues on this coming Tuesday to add the lawsuit at the same time the resolution goes out. So I want people to hear it.

MCSHANE: Right.

STEEL: And make everything--

(CROSSTALK)

MCSHANE: What's the response been ahead of that from your colleagues?

STEEL: Actually everybody is supporting it.

MCSHANE: OK.

STEEL: And I got couple of bad e-mails. Other than that, my colleagues are all supportive.

MCSHANE: Couple of bad e-mails. Let me go to the California governor for a moment. We'll listen together to Jerry Brown. He's dismissed this policy, the sanctuary policy fight. He says the administration's lawsuit that we had from the Department of Justice is nothing but a political stunt. Here's the governor.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JERRY BROWN, GOVERNOR OF SOUTH CAROLINA: This is really unprecedented for the chief law enforcement of the United States to come out to California and act more like Fox News than a law enforcement officer.

This is a political stunt. It's more like Fox News and what's going on in Washington, and it's not about the truth. It's not about protecting our state. It's about dividing America.

What Jeff Sessions said is simply not true, and I call upon him to apologize to the people of California, to bringing the mendacity of Washington to California and trying to insert discord and division, and I might add, dysfunctionality in a state that's really working.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: All right, Michelle, what do you say to the governor?

STEEL: You know, government duty, the first thing comes public safety, and then you know what, he's not thinking about the safety. We are not talking about here that President Trump and ICE are going after first generation immigrants or any immigrant family. They are going after the criminal aliens.

And you know, I get a lot of support especially from Congressman Dana Rohrabacher in my district that he supported me that, you know, me too.

MCSHANE: Right.

STEEL: So we are talking about this. Public safety comes down to it. This has nothing to do with a stunt. This has nothing to do with racism. This has nothing to do with, you know, what he thinks it's a show. So Jeff Sessions did the right thing because it's unconstitutional, and actually this law ties our sheriffs and that, you know, local police officers' hands because they have to follow different laws from the federal government and state government.

MCSHANE: Right.

STEEL: So it's not really safe on the streets. So we have to do something about it.

MCSHANE: Well, that's the issue and speaking of relationship between state and local officials in the federal government. The Oakland mayor, as you know, has really become the face of all this as well. Her name is Libby Shaaf, and she was the person who had warned the illegal immigrants of impending raids from immigration officials.

Well, anyway, she has hit back at the president. I want to bring up a quote from the mayor of Oakland. "It is continued destruction, it's a continued perpetration of a racist lie that immigrants were not valued members of our society. We in Oakland know better. We in Oakland have a community that welcomes and honors all people no matter where they come from no matter where how they got here."

Your response to the mayor of Oakland's latest comments.

STEEL: Isn't it amazing? Because you can hear it. I'm a first generation immigrant. At the same time, in Orange County, we have 3.2 million people living in Orange County, and we are the third largest county in the state.

At the same time, we have a lot of large immigrant communities in our county. At the same time we embrace everybody's diverse cultures. So this has nothing to do with the -- you know, racism. This has things to do that we are going against that law.

MCSHANE: Right.

STEEL: And especially you cannot really go against federal law that he would try to save that, you know, protect its own citizens.

MCSHANE: OK. Michelle Steel, keep us up to date, OK. Next Tuesday she says is the big day. Thanks for coming on tonight.

STEEL: We'll do that. Thank you.

MCSHANE: OK. This Facebook story, there's more fallout over the leaks and billionaire Tesla founder Elon Musk got involved today. He really hit Mark Zuckerberg with the delete Facebook movement. Taking shape as it is he deleted his Facebook page, took the SpaceX page down, took the Tesla page down as well.

So, what does it all mean for Facebook? Our panel is back after a quick break.

MCSHANE: Elon Musk, the CEO of a couple of company Tesla and SpaceX, well, he erased his own page from the world's most popular social media platform responding to calls for support of the hash tag delete Facebook movement.

He took the company's pages down as well after 50 million users had their personal info harvested by the political analytics firm Cambridge Analytica.

The Facebook stock price it's been down heading, it was down again today. Facebook down just over 3 percent, worst week since August of 2012. it's wiped out the gains for the year this week.

Let's bring our panel back. Patrice Lee Onwuka, Eric Schiffer. Patrice, let me start with you on this topic.

ONWUKA: Sure.

MCSHANE: Boy, it took Facebook a long time I think especially in our world here, you take five days to respond to something like this, if you're Zuckerberg or even Sheryl Sandberg. What do you make of the way they've handled it and what the fallout will be from here?

ONWUKA: I think they've handled it in a way that shows that they have no clue what they want to do or can do in the situation. You know, hearing from Zuckerberg, you know, at this point it's not a question whether there should be regulations--

MCSHANE: Right.

ONWUKA: -- but that, hey, they welcome it is disconcerting.

I mean, it's concerning because, you know, Facebook will probably weather this but they're going to have a heavy hand at any sort of regulation that comes out and what happens with regulation -- with regulating technology is that it limits -- probably will limit competition so and even use the social media platform--

(CROSSTALK)

MCSHANE: Well, you're saying, I get that, but you're saying, Patrice, that Facebook will have too much influence in that? Is that your point?

ONWUKA: It's very possible that they'll be able to guide whatever regulations come out of this, and any new competition, you know, will start from a position of disadvantage, frankly, and then we don't know how innovation is going to develop as a result of any new regulations.

MCSHANE: It's funny, Eric, I don't think Facebook has a friend in the world now politically, if you think about it, I mean, Republicans are not, you know, the biggest fans of everybody up in Silicon Valley to begin with, and you're not going to get a Democrat defending kind of the behavior here. So, nowhere to turn if you are Zuckerberg or Sandberg, is there?

SCHIFFER: Well, I think we have to remember that there still are tens of millions of users of Facebook, there's even more of Instagram.

MCSHANE: More, yes.

SCHIFFER: So they're not going to get eviscerated from the planet today. They're going to be around. They will make it through this. But it's a wake-up call. They got slapped in the face for disrespecting so many Americans and people around the world with their data.

MCSHANE: Yes.

SCHIFFER: I still don't think they get it. I still think that there's an arrogance that somehow this was OK. I mean, their initial response was one of the worst responses in the history of modern day crisis management. I mean, it was terrible. But they have a war chest. Let's not forget. I mean, they have millions, tens of billions of dollars of potential to be able to spend. That's a--

(CROSSTALK)

MCSHANE: And by the way, as a final point -- that's funny the hacker way we're looking at now -- the final point, Patrice, this is not just a Facebook issue, this whole data thing.

ONWUKA: No, it's a broader issue for the technology industry to think about. But as users, I mean, we have given up a tremendous amount of information about ourselves from our messages to our phone calls to our photos and the question is how do we retain or regain some control over that.

MCSHANE: Right.

ONWUKA: And I think that's a conversation for society for public policy and for technology to be having.

MCSHANE: I think a lot of people wanted their Facebook settings started deleting the access to some of the apps this week. Eric and Patrice, good to see both of you. Have a good weekend.

ONWUKA: You, too.

SCHIFFER: It's good to see you.

MCSHANE: All right. Quick break, we'll be right back after this.

MCSHANE: All right. Business alert for you. Boy, what a week. We said that every week but we have made it to Friday night which is a big night here on the Fox Business Network. Maria has her Maria Bartiromo's Wall Street program this evening. That's 8 p.m. Eastern. You don't want to miss that. The great Mario Gabelli is on tonight. So miss super Mario and Maria.

We thank you for watching. I'm Connell McShane. It's time for Charles Payne. He's here now with Making Money.

urn:contentItem:5X1M-81B1-JB20-G3SR-00000-00President Trump Attacks The Federal Reserve Arguing Rates Should Be Lower; The Hong Kong Stock Exchange Makes A $39 Billion Bid For The LSC; Apple Slices Prices On iPhones And Streaming. Aired 9-10a ET2019-09-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:28ZLexisNexisFIRST MOVE WITH JULIA CHATTERLEY9:00 AM ESTArt Hogan, Dan Ives, Alex AdelmanNEWSInternational091101cb.k41President Trump Attacks The Federal Reserve Arguing Rates Should Be Lower; The Hong Kong Stock Exchange Makes A $39 Billion Bid For The LSC; Apple Slices Prices On iPhones And Streaming. Aired 9-10a ETJulia Chatterley, Christine Romans, Clare Sebastian, Matt Egan, Seth Fiegerman, Anna Stewart

President Trump tweeted this morning, saying the Federal Reserve should get our interest rates down to zero or less, that we should then start to refinance on debt, and that interest costs could be brought way down. Hong Kong Exchange is making a bid for the London Stock Exchange. Apple is banking on fresh models to reverse a year of sunken sales.

[09:00:19]

JULIA CHATTERLEY, CNN INTERNATIONAL ANCHOR: Live from the New York Stock Exchange, I'm Julia Chatterley. This is FIRST MOVE and here is your need to know.

Boneheads: President Trump attacks the Federal Reserve arguing rates should be lower. Exchange Trades: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange makes a $39 billion bid for the LSC, and Apple slices prices, relatively -- relatively cheaper iPhones, and certainly cheaper streaming. It's Wednesday, it's also September the 11th. And we remember, let's make a move.

Welcome to FIRST MOVE once again. Glad to have you with us, as always. As I mentioned there, it is September the 11th. And we will be observing a minute of silence here at the New York Stock Exchange to remember those who lost their lives and those that were impacted 18 years ago with members of the Emergency Services, as well, as you can probably see behind me, are going to be ringing the opening bell this morning, too, and we will bring that to you live as always.

For now, though, let me give you a look at what we're seeing for the U.S. markets -- premarket this morning. We are a little bit higher, but we are well and truly, as we've been saying all week, in wait-and-see mode right now.

An easy thing to do, perhaps we could argue here with major stock markets, sitting just one and a half percent away from record highs, though those figures belie underlying shifts going on within the sectors and we'll discuss that later on in the show, but lots of risk events coming up in the coming days.

The European Central Bank, of course, tomorrow potentially announcing a return to bond buying though Goldman Sachs warning overnight that fresh stimulus might not be forthcoming, given the divisions in the ECB leadership right now. So that will keep investors guessing.

I'll tell you what though, one man who isn't second guessing the need for more stimulus is President Trump. He has been tweeting this morning. Let me show you what he said, "The Federal Reserve should get our interest rates down to zero or less and we should then start to refinance on debt. Interest costs could be brought way down."

We've already seen the first electric Porsche, a hybrid Lamborghini and a brand new logo for Volkswagen, but one of the shiny new cars certainly take the spotlight as the threats lurking in the shadows that may also steal the show.

Anna Stewart is in Frankfurt, who better to send to a glamorous location, our intrepid reporter. Anna, talk us through it. It sounds like a tough gig.

ANNA STEWART, CNN REPORTER: Yes, I mean, lots of shine and sparkle. You'll see the new Porsche Tycan all-electric vehicle behind me. But you're right, you pop open the hood in this sector, and you see all sorts of problems. Lots and lots of headwinds. German car production in decline. And this contributes five percent of German GDP. So it's a really big problem.

Now, from all the gloomy reports we've had this week from German economists, it looks like Germany is already in recession. So going through those headwinds. U.S.-China trade war, CO2 emissions regulations. Those are getting much, much tougher for the automakers to reach.

And then, of course, Brexit and that is really the heaven that looms very large at the moment, potentially, of course, at the end of next month if the Prime Minister of the U.K. gets his own way. Possibly a no deal.

And speaking to the Head of the German Automakers Association, they say that they are really worried about this. A no-deal Brexit will be absolutely dire. It's already having a hit on car production and exports. So I asked, what is he doing? Is he lobbying the German government? Is he trying to get a softer stance on Irish backstop? Here is what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BERNHARD MATTES, PRESIDENT, GERMAN ASSOCIATION OF THE AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRY: We have a clear position and we have made this very clear to the Chancellor and the whole government here in Germany. Clearly, we do want to have a Brexit, the orderly Brexit based on a deal with good framework for our trade and for business on one hand.

On the other hand, we need to have the 27 remain as a market and unified because at the end, if we invite others to also leave the E.U., that will be even worse for us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

STEWART: He says that all the German carmakers are as ready as they can be for a potential hard Brexit and that actually echo comments we heard from the Chancellor, Angela Merkel this morning speaking to Parliament and she says they're going to do everything they can to reach a deal with the U.K., right up to the very last minute, but they are ready for a disorderly Brexit -- Julia.

CHATTERLEY: Yes, it's just painful. I remember we spoke to the Aston Martin CEO recently. And he said, look for them, actually, Brexit has already happened. They've seen the detrimental effect. They've had to make changes. They've had to stockpile. It's a nightmare for these guys.

Interesting, though, to your point as well about what we're seeing in terms of the German economy itself. What are these guys saying about demand in the German economy and the outlook here? Because to your point to, there are fears that actually, the economy there is already in recession.

STEWART: Yes, and it's interesting, because if you look at the auto sector, it is in decline globally. You know, last year was the first year of global car sales actually declining since 2009. So this isn't just a German issue, but of course, it contributes so much the German economy.

[09:45:09]

STEWART: So it has heightened fears here. I think a lot of the car makers at the moment are most concerned with how much money they're putting into electric investments, how much they're going to settle on. You just look at this Porsche. How many people will actually buy? This is the problem.

First of this year, 90 percent of car sales all around the world was still combustion engines, people aren't buying electric. And car makers say it's the government's fault. The infrastructure isn't there. They've got these regulations they're trying to meet. They're investing billions. But if the infrastructure isn't there, customers simply will not buy them.

CHATTERLEY: Yes, it's such a great point, investing for a future that's uncertain at a time when actually you probably need to be drawing your horns in. Anna Stewart, great, great story. Thank you so much for that.

All right. We're going to take a quick break, but coming up, a crypto pioneer, who is making it as easy as ABC to get into Bitcoin. Meet the 30- year-old CEO of an exciting startup called, Lolli.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ALEX ADELMAN, CEO, LOLLI: We've never been so connected, as we have with Bitcoin, like the internet connected us all socially. And then Bitcoin came in and connected us all through commerce.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TEXT: Crypto Crazy.

CHATTERLEY: If you've wanted to get into cryptocurrencies or Bitcoin for example, with minimal effort, I want to share one way of building some crypto savings with very little investment. Lolli -- it's like a shopper's loyalty rewards plan.

It lives as a browser extension and kicks in when you use a partner store. You pay for goods in dollars and get rewards back in Bitcoin. It's only available in the United States for now, but Lolli's co-founder, Alex Adelman told me it's an easy introduction for crypto newbies.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ADELMAN: The interesting thing about Lolli is that it turns every one, anyone who shops which is everybody into an investor in this scarce asset. So there's only 21 million Bitcoin and there will only ever be 21 million Bitcoin.

And a lot of people, I would say less than one percent of the world would consider themselves an investor. What Lolli does is it takes a shopper and it gives them the ability to get into Bitcoin without having to invest in it.

So if a consumer was to go on an exchange to buy Bitcoin, it would take a week, maybe more to go sign up, invest their hard-earned money, and then actually accumulate Bitcoin.

What we do is we take every single purchase that you make, and we let you earn Bitcoin when you make those purchases.

CHATTERLEY: For me, the key here is accessibility. Suddenly to someone who reads about Bitcoin or cryptocurrency, hears about it, but just things I have no idea what's going on there. It perhaps starts to get them comfortable with the idea of owning a cryptocurrency like Bitcoin and getting comfortable with maybe transferring it to dollars, maybe spending it if the retailer accepts Bitcoin, is that right? That's what you were trying to achieve here.

[09:50:03]

ADELMAN: Yes. So, Lolli makes it extremely easy and Lolli makes Bitcoin accessible to everybody.

CHATTERLEY: Are you making money doing what you're doing right now?

ADELMAN: Yes. So our business model is very simple, and we make money from day one. And we make money when our user makes money. And so everyone is mutually benefiting in this business model.

So the merchants, when our users shop at our different merchant sites, the merchants pay us in U.S. dollars, and then we send that in Bitcoin to their Lolli wallet. So we take a portion of that. The merchants are paying us.

So one thing I like to think about is what everyone is optimizing for in exchange it is optimizing for you transferring Bitcoin to potentially other cryptocurrencies. We're optimizing to just share Bitcoin with everybody, and so everybody wins. It's a flywheel effect.

The consumer wins because they're earning Bitcoin, the merchant wins, because they are getting new customers that maybe would have shopped elsewhere. And then we win, because we're, you know, the middleware, that's like sharing Bitcoin with everybody and helping the merchants earn.

CHATTERLEY: How many of the people that are doing this, are already comfortable with cryptocurrency versus people that are just learning new and then go on to accept perhaps more cryptocurrency as they continue to shop?

ADELMAN: So that's a great question, because a lot of what we're doing is we're trying to introduce new people into Bitcoin.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

ADELMAN: And into this space. So when we first started, it was a lot of Bitcoin maximalist, people who already had Bitcoin that wanted more. And it was almost entirely that.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

ADELMAN: As we've continued to grow, we found that those people can finally share an application with their friends and their family for them to earn Bitcoin. So what we found is we're nearing 50 percent of our users are now new to Bitcoin, which is really, really exciting.

CHATTERLEY: Wow. So it is an on ramp, basically, to cryptocurrency use.

ADELMAN: Yes. And we're just getting started, so everyone can get in really, really early. We launched a year ago, and so we just started. We have almost a thousand merchant partners, and we have tens of thousands of users that are earning Bitcoin every day on their everyday purchases.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CHATTERLEY: Yes, one of the consistent push backs I hear is that Bitcoin, like other cryptocurrencies has been used for various nefarious activities, which has tarnished the brand to some degree. I asked Alex, whether there a specter of regulation is needed and necessary to keep the crypto craze under control and give it credibility.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ADELMAN: Regulators can work with it. And I think that regulation will come.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

ADELMAN: To make sure that people use it responsibly. And I want to be held accountable for being a company that uses it responsibly. I don't -- I just don't think that it needs -- Bitcoin itself does not need regulation. It just is.

Everyone in the entire world can see the source code, can see what it was - - how it was created, and so everyone can agree that it has value and that it is this like cryptographically secure like asset that everyone can own.

Regulators can actually look at it and say, "Okay, I can either work with it or I can work against it." And the regulators that work against it, I think will be penalized, whereas the ones that work with it, it will increase economic activity. It will connect the entire world through commerce, and that is what makes it so powerful.

CHATTERLEY: What does the future look like for Lolli? Talk to me about your plans? Expansion plans? What you're working on right now.

ADELMAN: So we've just started work on a mobile app, and that mobile app is going to let everybody earn so easily and on daily purchases. Right now, you can earn on all online purchases with about a thousand merchants all across the U.S.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

ADELMAN: Part of our expansion is going into mobile. And so you can have that that web wallet and your mobile wallet, and you can earn on daily purchases going and getting your coffee all the way to your flight for work or your office supplies whatever -- we want every single purchase to drive attention to Bitcoin and for you to be able to earn on everything similar two points.

CHATTERLEY: Is anyone else doing this?

ADELMAN: Not as well as us. We're the first and I'm biased, but I think we're the best.

CHATTERLEY: You're pretty sure that you can continue to grow and not be challenged by any upcoming competitors?

ADELMAN: Well, I think our team -- so I started this with my old co- founder. We've been working together, his name is Matt Senter. We've been working together for about eight years now, and we reassembled our old team.

Our old team was acquired by eBay. It's the biggest cashback company in the U.S. and so we know the space I think better than most people and you know, we stay humble. We understand that competitors can come out. Incumbents can come in.

CHATTERLEY: Amazon? MasterCard? I think these kind of people have an incentive to do something like this, too. Would they be a threat or you think you've got better technology and a better head start?

ADELMAN: I think we have a really good head start. Incumbents can come in. I think the more people that come in, the better because the tide rises all ships.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

ADELMAN: And because we're the first, I think we've created a really solid community and brand around Lolli that I think we will rise with them. I personally -- like I'm talking with MasterCard, I'm talking with Visa. I'm talking with Amazon. We want to work with all of these partners because it makes Lolli stronger.

[09:55:08]

CHATTERLEY: Are you open to being bought?

ADELMAN: Not right now. Yes, I mean, I want to be here, IPO and I want to ring the bell with you.

CHATTERLEY: Really?

ADELMAN: Yes.

CHATTERLEY: Really?

ADELMAN: Let's do it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHATTERLEY: All right, the Lolli CEO there. Now we do have President Trump at the Pentagon this morning for a Memorial for September the 11th.

Speaking right now, he is being introduced by the Pentagon Secretary Mark Esper. We've also got the Joint Chiefs Chairman Joseph Dunford there, an observance ceremony at the Pentagon Memorial, and we are of course 18 years after the Defense Building was attacked by terrorists on September the 11th.

We're going to see a name reading, plus remarks and a wreath laying ceremony. In fact, President Trump just being introduced as you can see him shaking hands there with the Pentagon Secretary. Let's listen in to what he has to say.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Thank you very much, Secretary Esper. Today, our nation honors and mourns the nearly 3,000 lives that were stolen from us on September 11, 2001. On these grounds, 184 people were murdered when al Qaeda terrorists overtook American Airlines Flight 77 and crashed it into the Pentagon.

For every American to live through that day, the September 11th attack is seared into our soul. It was a day filled with shock, horror, sorrow, and righteous fury.

I vividly remember when I first heard the news. I was sitting at home watching a major business television show early that morning. Jack Welch, the legendary head of General Electric was about to be interviewed, when all of a sudden, they cut away.

At first, there were different reports. It was a boiler fire. But I knew that boilers aren't at the top of a building. It was a kitchen explosion in Windows on the World. Nobody really knew what happened. There was great confusion.

I was looking out of a window from a building at Midtown Manhattan directly at the World Trade Center. When I saw a second plane, at a tremendous speed go into the second tower. It was then that I realized the world was going to change.

I was no longer going to be and it could never ever be that innocent place that I felt that it was. Soon after I went down to Ground Zero with men who worked for me to try to help in any little way that we could. We were not alone.

So many others were scattered around, trying to do the same. They were all trying to help. But for the families who join us, this is your anniversary of personal and permanent loss.

It is the day that has replayed in your memory a thousand times over, the last kiss, the last phone call, the last time hearing those precious words, "I love you." Then the attack.

The anguish of knowing your family member had boarded one of these flights or was working in the World Trade Center or serving right here at the Pentagon.

You waited, you prayed, you answered that most dreaded call, and your life changed forever.

To each of you, the First Lady and I are united with you in grief. We come here in the knowledge that we cannot erase the pain or reverse the evil of that dark and wretched day.

But we offer you all that we have -- our unwavering loyalty, our undying devotion, and our eternal pledge that your loved ones will never, ever be forgotten.

Eighteen years ago, the terrorists struck this citadel of power and American strength. But the enemy soon learned that they could not weaken the spirit of our people.

In times of distress, the heart of the American Patriot only grows stronger and more today determined. Even in the midst of the attack, the world witnessed the awesome power of American defiance.

[10:00:10]

urn:contentItem:5TBR-6CC1-DXP3-R4DY-00000-00President Trump & Attorney General Sessions Lack Support For Breaking Up Tech, New NetChoice Survey Finds;Just 5% of Americans Want Antitrust Focus on Tech2018-09-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:27ZLexisNexisPresident Trump & Attorney General Sessions Lack Support For Breaking Up Tech, New NetChoice Survey FindsJust 5% of Americans Want Antitrust Focus on TechWASHINGTON, Sept. 25, 2018

Americans overwhelmingly value the contributions of the technology industry and do not support antitrust enforcement, despite aggressive rhetoric from President Trump, a newNetChoice survey* of 1,200 U.S. consumers found.

President Trump's draft Executive Order would put tech in the crosshairs of U.S. antitrust authorities. Attorney General Jeff Sessions is also holding a meeting with several State Attorneys General today to discuss accusations of social media bias. But Americans don't support an antitrust crack down on America's most innovative businesses.

New polling shows that only about 5% of Americans (on both sides of the political aisles) say the federal government should focus anti-competitive enforcement on the tech industry. Further, just 1 in 5 Americans say the break-up of big tech would most benefit consumers.

The value of tech to consumers and businesses is clear.

Over 70% of Americans say that digital advertising platforms like Googleand Facebook are valuable to both small businesses and the national economy. Just 13% say that they have had a negative experience with large Internet platforms and 72% say that services like Facebook, Google, and Amazonmake it easier for them to connect with people in their community.

"President Trump's fixation on breaking up tech platforms lacks support from Americans," said Steve DelBianco, president of NetChoice. "Antitrust policy needs to be guided by facts, not emotional outbursts. The government cannot violate the First Amendment by forcing Internet platforms to suppress negative news. Internet platforms are a boon for American consumers, businesses, and, in turn, the U.S. economy. The President should listen to regular Americans and allow U.S. tech companies to continue to thrive and innovate."

*About the Survey: From August 6-8, 2018 Zogby Analytics conducted an interactive survey of 1,222 adults focused on consumer attitudes toward Internet platforms and government regulation. The survey, commissioned by NetChoice, has a margin of error of +/- 2.8%.  It is available atNetChoice.org/TechlashPoll

About NetChoice
NetChoice is a trade association of eCommerce businesses and online consumers all of whom share the goal of promoting convenience, choice, and commerce on the net. 

CONTACT: Rob Winterton,rwinterton@netchoice.org
