Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RYY-BND1-JBHT-D038-00000-00President Trump Bashed Wasteful Spending, Then He Praised Over- Budget Military Projects; Zuckerberg's 'Megalomaniac' Style Has Made Facebook the Behemoth It Is; Bump Stock Ban; Battle over DACA; President Trump Calls Over to End Filibuster; Christianity under Attack2018-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:27ZLexisNexisPresident Trump Bashed Wasteful Spending, Then He Praised Over- Budget Military Projects; Zuckerberg's 'Megalomaniac' Style Has Made Facebook the Behemoth It Is; Bump Stock Ban; Battle over DACA; President Trump Calls Over to End Filibuster; Christianity under AttackLanhamFULL TEXT

LOU DOBBS, FBN HOST: Good evening everybody. Happy Friday. The top stories tonight, Wall Street crushed. The stock market suffered a second straight day of steep losses as establishment Red RINOs and Dems in Congress went on a $1.3 trillion spending spree abandoning all restraint in fiscal policy and the Federal Reserve doing its part to confound reason and create more uncertainty by raising rates with no evidence of inflation. Today's losses capping what was the worst week on Wall Street in more than two years. It was simply put, a bloodbath. President Trump hesitated but then did sign the spending bill to assure the largest funding in history for our military and to avoid a government shutdown. But President Trump vows never again will he sign such a reckless and undisciplined spending bill written by Ryan, and McConnell, and Schumer, and Pelosi ignoring the Republican majority altogether.

Joining us tonight to examine the collapse of a fiscal and monetary policy in the same week, one of the top economists in the country Moody's John Lonski, Ed Rollins, one of the country's best political analyst. Also tonight, Facebook's feckless CEO Mark Zuckerberg will have to do more than mumble unintelligibly to the media. Facebook -- unintelligibly. Facebook is in crisis and its so-called leaders turn out to be mostly inept and irresponsible. We'll have a lot more from Mr. Zuckerberg here tonight. Lawmakers of both parties in the House and Senate are no longer asking Zuckerberg to testify. They're ordering to come to Capitol Hill and to explain his lack of leadership, integrity, and the disastrous policies that lead to the mess that is now Facebook.

Cybersecurity expert Morgan Wright, our Deirdre Bolton on what issue to be a regime of regulation about to descend on Silicon Valley, technology, social media in general. We take all of that up here tonight. Our top story, President Trump says the never-ending cycle of budget brinkmanship in the swamp ends today. President Trump signed the $1.3 trillion spending bill needed to keep the government running for the next six months, but not before blasting lawmakers for wasting money on pet projects giving themselves a raise playing politics with DACA recipients, lying about wall funding, and endangering the U.S. military.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: There are a lot of things that I'm unhappy about in this bill. There are a lot of things that we shouldn't have had in this bill, but we were in a sense forced if we want to build our military, we were forced to have. There are some things that we should have in the bill. But I say to Congress, I will never sign another bill like this again. I'm not going to do it again. Nobody read it. It's only hours old. Some people don't even know what is in there, $1.3 trillion. It's the second largest ever. President Obama signed one that was actually larger which I'm sure he wasn't too happy with either.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Joining us tonight the best political mind in the business Ed Rollins, former Reagan White House Political Director, Fox Business Political Analyst, John Lonski, chief economist, Managing Director at Moody's. Great to have you both here and let me begin if I may, John, with you. Fourteen hundred points off the Dow. It was a crushing trillion dollar loss for the week and it is a direct result it seems to me for the most of part a direct result of a fiscal policy that has just been overturned.

JOHN LONSKI, MANAGING DIRECTOR, MOODY: That's a problem on the interest rate front. That's why we have a long-term bond yields of about a quarter of a percentage point higher then where they ought to be at this point in time and we don't want to forget about the problems we're having with international trade. Worry about a possible trade war with China.

DOBBS: Yes. But markets hate uncertainty and if one thing these investors should have been certain about, it was about the president who had told them for two years that he was going to put punishing tariffs on China particularly, on our trading partners who have taken advantage of us for 50 years. I mean most people don't realize, for example, that the United States hasn't run a trade surplus since 1975. We have idiots at the Chamber of Commerce and The Business Roundtable going around saying it's not a zero sum game. Tell that to the American people. Tell that to the American middle class bulk.

LONSKI: Yes. And that's why Donald Trump is president today and let's not forget that one of the reasons for these actions taken against China is because China engages in unfair trade practices. I mean China --

DOBBS: And they steal our technology. They steal our most of advanced innovations and they do so with front companies. They're carrying out daily 24/7 espionage against the United States with those front companies in the United States.

LONSKI: But we have a very close linkage with China. Let's not forget. Many U.S. companies manufacture their goods. High technology, telecommunication devices are manufactured in China for U.S. companies to sell in the United States.

DOBBS: Yes. And that's one of the biggest problems and that's one of the big problems that this president intends to reverse.

ED ROLLINS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, he has -- I applauded that in fact. He threatened a veto today. He should have threatened a veto a month ago and the reality is, you know, political system does not work when it comes to budgets. When you put four --

DOBBS: But now you got scoreless dogs leading the Republican Party in both Houses.

ROLLINS: But when you put four people in the room and two of them -- two of them are the Democrat leaders in both sides --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: We've got the greatest political analyst in the country here. I've got to ask you. How -- and I've got to believe every American who's paying attention is wondering the same thing. How in the hell does a party that has -- the Republican Party with a majority in the Senate, the majority in the House. How the hell do they end up conferring with the two leading Democrats and ignoring their entire conference?

ROLLINS: Well, they shouldn't and they should be removed as leaders. I think Ryan's performance was unbelievable that fact that he would get in the room 24 hours before was -- and make these deals with Pelosi. As you said last night, when Pelosi says it's a great robust bill and we blocked all the Trump's priorities, I mean that got to be the greatest indictment of all to the leadership.

DOBBS: Here's another indictment. When Paul Ryan says it's a great piece of legislation, you know it the same --

ROLLINS: It's not a great piece of legislation. It's a half a trillion dollar increase in the debt. And it's just -- and I think the president if you're reading is serious about what he said today. He's got to get Mulvaney in the budget process. This is only -- we're halfway into a new fiscal year and we haven't begun that process. We just -- we're six months late in the budget and it's an atrocious budget. It was trillion dollar deficits from now for the foreseeable future.

DOBBS: Trillion dollar deficits from now on folks, remember that number. We're now back in trillion dollar deficits. And we just added a trillion to the national debt in the last six months.

LONSKI: Yes. Unfortunately, the Chinese bought a trillion dollars -- they hold a trillion dollars' worth of U.S. government debt. We need their support. But on the other hand of course if the Chinese threatened to reduce their holdings of U.S Treasury and sell them to push --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: They going to reduced their holdings by about 10 percent.

LONSKI: If they use this as part of a trade was strategy, the Federal Reserve can respond in kind by adopting (INAUDIBLE) just buying the treasuries and existing yields that the Chinese want to sell. Why not?

DOBBS: And people don't want to acknowledge this but that four and a half trillion dollars that the Fed put on the balance sheet and, Ed, is looking at me like, what has this got to do with politics? But the fact the matter is they are setting here raising the rate for the repayment of that debt when they recycle it off of -- cycle it off of the balance sheet. They are also and under -- we're under no obligation to sell our treasuries to the Chinese. That's a benefit for them, not for us. We can gin up enough money in perpetuity. We've done it.

ROLLINS: The next generation is going to pay a very heavy price on these deficits getting politically active and neither party owns them and my sense is the party that gives them a formula of how we're going to be fiscally responsible is going to become the majority party.

DOBBS: Well, why don't we send out McConnell and Ryan to every college campus and have them recruit those millennials, what do you think?

ROLLINS: We'll lose -- we'll lose overwhelming the support and we need -- we need to be -- we need to be fiscally sound. We need to basically convince these young people that there is a plan for them for the future because what's going to happen is the interest on this debt is going to become the biggest item in the budget in a very short order, and it's going to take away lots of options for them and whatever the tax cuts we made short-term will basically be offset by other additional things that they have --

DOBBS: Do you think the president meant when he said, never again?

ROLLINS: Well, I hope so. This is a big -- this is a big warning and I hope -- I hope the -- he's going to be active all the way through and Mulvaney has going to be very active all the way through this, the OMB Director.

LONSKI: Who is going vote to cut spending at the federal level? Who's going to vote to raise the retirement age and so on or reduce the entitlements to the federal government --

DOBBS: Did you say raise the retirement age?

LONSKI: Yes. Well, they're going to have to --

(CROSSTALK)

LONSKI: They're still working. But I'm saying for the millennials, you know, you could say that 25 years from now the retirement age might be 68 and going up to 70 since we do live longer. At least that's been the case.

DOBBS: So for -- we can vote --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: Messaging for the Republican Party. You're living longer, so you should work harder.

LONSKI: Well, that's the point and they can't -- they will not deliver that political message if they want to stay in office and --

DOBBS: One thing --

(CROSSTALK)

ROLLINS: These young people are going to find their -- it's their parents that are going to be suffering, so you can't -- you can't cut it for them but you have to have to have some strategic thought processes about where we go 10 years --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: I'm sorry. OK.

LONSKI: Term the limits. I mean that's basically what you're going to need in Washington -

DOBBS: Term limits? You mean what --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: Paul Ryan won't be able to stay in office for 25 years. McConnell three and a half decade.

LONSKI: That may not be a bad idea. That maybe the only solution.

DOBBS: I think those term limits have some interesting appeal and broadening of feel I'm sure. Interest rates, why is it we have to give on the job training to every Fed chairman whether he or she is just steps in and they're new. They get to raise rates and see what happens to an economy in which there's no inflation and then we have to watch the little dance that follows. We're in the dance part now for Jerome Powell.

LONSKI: I think where the problem, you know, with the Federal Reserve is a lot of people that provide information to the Fed Chairman are very theoretically oriented economist. OK. They sit in their office by, you know, computer all day long looking at numbers doing this, that, and yet they do statistical analysis. They have no connection with reality whatsoever. Look what happens during the housing crisis.

DOBBS: Yes. And it's -- and it looks like it's a little like politics, isn't it? I mean who's advising Ryan, and McConnell, and Schumer, and Pelosi? Do they adviser?

ROLLINS: They're about three staffers on the Hill that know what was in the 2000 page bill and there's not a single member in the House and Senate who voted for it had any clue what was in that bill. That's irresponsible.

DOBBS: But "60 minutes" is going to break this wide open. The issues collapsing fiscal policy and monetary policy simultaneously. I understand they got a whole segment on it. It's called "storm field." What?

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: High journalists. Ed Rollins, John Lonski, thank you both. Appreciate it. Up next, lawmakers zeroing in on the zuck demanding answers from Facebook over its absolute breach of public trust. Deirdre Bolton, cybersecurity expert Morgan Wright joins us here next to take up the fiasco, the crisis, the disaster for Facebook and soon Silicon Valley, and big tech. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: The Justice Department charged Iranian hackers in connection with a mass of state-sponsored cyber-attack that targeted more than 140 American universities. The indictment charges the defendants was stealing more than 31 terabytes of academic date, intellectual property worth we're told somewhere around $3 billion. My guess is it's multiples of that. The Justice Department says all nine hackers are still in Iran. They're somewhat like Russian hackers. They don't seem to be extraditable. Well, calls for embattle Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to testify before Congress are growing more numerous and louder. Both the Senate Commerce and House Energy Commerce Committees today formally asking Zuckerberg to appear on Capitol Hill.

Zuckerberg said he's open to testifying as he put it so quaintly and cutely only if he is the correct person at Facebook to do so. Only if he's the correct person, how precious of the zuck? Joining us tonight cybersecurity expert Morgan Wright, Fox Business Correspondent Deirdre Bolton. Great to have you both here. Deirdre, he waits five days to open his mouth and then he says nothing, doesn't even apologize. He has to do that day two of the non-apology. He and Sheryl Sandberg who is supposed to be this all big time executive, these are two of the biggest losers I've ever seen at the top of a company.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: So Lou, they make you feel better that he lost about $10 million.

DOBBS: Not a bit.

BOLTON: Not a bit?

DOBBS: I really think is it the most appalling executive conduct I have seen that the top two officials of any company in crisis --

BOLTON: So one analyst that I speak with a lot who has a cell on the stock said, you know, I never really thought I was going to have to question the management of Facebook. This week has really changed for me because really this data breach let's call it with Cambridge Analytica was sort of the second big strike for Facebook. The first one of course being in the run up to our presidential election. More than half of the U.S. voting population saw an ad that was either created by or manipulated by Russian bots. So we're --

DOBBS: The only proved collaboration with the Russians belongs -- that honor belongs to two companies, one is Facebook and the other is Twitter. And by the way, I think issue number one was the 2012 election in which Zuckerberg, Sandberg, and Facebook got behind the candidacy of Barack Obama. They took sides then and nobody said a word.

BOLTON: Nobody said a word. At this point though, their credibility as business leaders is being questioned. So it's in some ways a business problem aside from an ethical problem as well. But at this point they need to hire more engineers. They need to hire more humans that is going to eat into their profit margins. But I think at this point they must do it. To answer your point, he's going to go to Capitol Hill. The New York A.G. has started an investigation. The Massachusetts A.G., there are two class action lawsuits, one from users and one from investors. So --

DOBBS: This is early days.

BOLTON: This is early days. So they have a big problem.

DOBBS: This is -- Morgan, I want to bring you in now and you can tell us what in the world would any company be thinking? And I have to say to folks that, you know, I think that it's probably -- we can find several other examples of just heinously cowardly management. But right now in this moment Facebook is what's terrible.

MORGAN WRIGHT, CYBERSECURITY EXPERT: Well, look, Lou, now, one thing I will tell you. From a security, just from a pure security standpoint Facebook actually does an excellent job where they're failing it's -- they can't engineer their way out of this. This is a policy and a governance issue and stealing with the privacy of our information, what other policies and how do we enforce that? What we've got is we've got a neophyte organization. By the way, it wasn't exactly a fair fight during the, you know, during the election, we've got a Russian country that has 100 years of influence operations but we've got the technical capability and where was our own government sharing information, so we can prevent this information of going on. So technically, they're good. But they suffer big time because it's not about the technology. It's about the policy and governance and they failed on the privacy.

DOBBS: They failed on privacy, they failed on security, they failed on integrity, they failed on basic courage that is required of any great business leader. Zuckerberg looks terrible here, Morgan. You can't defend that. There's no way to rationalize it.

WRIGHT: That's why leave the political conversation to you and Deirdre, you know, I'm trying to stay on the technical side because you guys are far more experienced than I am. But I will tell you -- but I will tell you absolutely, it doesn't matter what you engineer, you can engineer the best thing in the world, and look, and Department of Defense one time, they've engineered what was called total information awareness, Admiral Poindexter, great program that's down to the Department of Justice at that time doing some work on information sharing. We thought it was the greatest thing. Guess what? It was great technology. They couldn't solve the privacy issues. The ACLU came in and that program was killed off because of privacy.

DOBBS: Well, there's another technical issue here and I'd like you both to address this and that is the users' data that is awash on the web as a result to Facebook and it's whether you call them technical issues, integrity issues, security issues. The reality is those users' have information that is being used for purposes never agreed to nor contemplated. And the fact is, Facebook was aware of that. And this business, Cambridge Analytica, come on third-party users, who's using what. This just -- this is just one example of how this template got out of control.

BOLTON: One think I would like to remind people though, if you're not paying for a service, you are the product, right?

DOBBS: So said Steve Jobs.

BOLTON: Right. So you have --

DOBBS: I think it's one of those great --

BOLTON: People just have to remember --

DOBBS: There aren't many analogs in business for -- if you're not paying for a product, you're the product. This is straight out. A responsible -- I mean think about this, Morgan, and explain it to us. How in the world can Zuckerberg or any one of the Facebook folks sit there and say, you know, we just couldn't manage this issue. We're such clever innovators and first movers that we just had to adjust to that. They knew they had a problem in 2016 during the election with the Russian agents and still didn't move forward. As a matter of fact, they were -- they were attacking conservative groups, censoring conservative groups, and continuing to say they really need, and Zuckerberg is dreaming of being president. And they weren't not even close to doing the responsible thing.

WRIGHT: Well, look, Lou, to build on what Deirdre was saying and you were saying. I don't know people notice but, you know, Facebook collects 48 separate data points about you everything from what you RSVP, what you like, and it's part of a discipline called persuasive technology. It's the whole -- and it was created at Stanford actually. Instagram was the first students that created technology out of this. It's designed to manipulate people and it's not just Facebook. It's done with online gaming.

It's done with advertising. So this persuasive technology, the more I know about you, I get past demographic into what's called psychographic information, what you do, what you're like, your attitude, and values, I can now whole scale, upscale manipulate people.

DOBBS: But I don't think we should go too far beyond that. It's psychographic. And there are entire disciplines of psychometrics gauging who you are, what you are, measuring it, and then deciding how they're going to influence your future decision making and they are creating from those profiles that maybe your friends or in the case of Facebook, people's friends were being co-opted into the buckets of information by the millions, and their influencing decision making. And there is not even a discussion in this country about it.

WRIGHT: One thing I would just add and I'm not trying to defend anybody in this. But let me just state, the U.S. spends $50.3 billion a year on national intelligence program. So we have a program called the domestic security council. Where was your own government with all the information? It was laid out in 2015 by a reporter in the U.K. about this --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: You do not know where our government was? Let me help you. Morgan, you should know this. 16 agencies came together and made a decision about collusion between the Trump campaign and the Russians and they've ignored everything that was happening in the electoral process at the DNC for eight months.

WRIGHT: Exactly, my point. And we give them $50.3 billion to find the obvious and they didn't. But yet we want to throw it all onto the back of tech companies and not just Facebook and Twitter but a lot of the other folks out there, I think first, we've got to do a better job from a government standpoint of using our money widely to defend our infrastructure and our information systems.

DOBBS: OK. Very quickly. It's got to be regulated and it's got to be regulated by the government. This nonsense of the wild frontier in Silicon Valley is done as of now. Would you not agree, Morgan?

WRIGHT: Yes. They put themselves in this --

(CROSSTALK)

WRIGHT: No, no. But I'll tell you. From a regulatory standpoint, it's no different than the way they dealt with cigarettes and its addictive technology. This is definitely addictive. It's got to have some intervention.

DOBBS: You get the last word.

BOLTON: Again a hundred percent on board. I think, yes, Zuckerberg in front of Congress answering questions in front of subcommittees, yes, this is a new page.

DOBBS: But only, Deirdre, only if he's the right person. He's merely the CEO with all of those billions of dollars --

WRIGHT: I'll take his 10 billion and testify.

BOLTON: There you go. The 10 million he lose this week.

DOBBS: Let me negotiate that for you if a usual --

WRIGHT: Your fee, yes.

DOBBS: A fee. Morgan, thanks so much. Deirdre, thanks so much. Appreciate it. Be sure to vote in our poll tonight. The question is, do you believe RINOs and Dems in Congress are incapable of creating a spending bill that doesn't just simply blow up fiscal policy? We'd like to hear from you. You're your vote on Twitter @LouDobbs. Follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs, like me on Facebook, follow me on Instagram @LouDobbs Tonight. On Wall Street, stocks selling off for the second straight session. The Dow plunging 425 point. The S&P down 55. The Nasdaq dropping 174. Volume on the Big Board, 3.8 billion shares. But that one is really child's play.

For the week, stocks closing the worst week in more than two years. The Dow down more than 5 percent. The S&P down 6 percent and the Nasdaq posting a loss of six and a half percent of the week. Bye-bye more than a trillion dollars. The wish -- the Wilshire 5000, those losses, market cap amount to for the week $1.8 trillion. That's what we call a tough week. A reminder, listen to my reports three times a day coast to coast on the Salem Radio Network. Up next, President Trump blasting the Dems and the RINOs in Congress for loading up an omnibus spending bill with just about everything but the sink.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The last time we negotiated something like this and as you know it's always been a problem for our country. They get together and they create a series of documents that nobody has been able to read because it was just done. You tell me who can read that quickly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And who bothers to read after all. A full report on the backlash to the -- to the extraordinary amazing, awesome leadership of Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell. We salute them next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Coming up next, President Trump making moves on gun safety. You can bet the national left wing national media won't give him credit for. We'll take up the bump stock ban, the Justice Department actually doing something, they're moving ahead. And they announced it late this afternoon. We'll take it up with our panel, Gina Loudon, Dom Giordano, joining us right after these words.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: The Justice Department taking action, announcing it's begun the process to ban bump stocks. The Department of Justice now amending federal firearms regulations to clarify bump stocks fall into the technical definition of machine gun. President Trump today tweeted this, "The Obama administration legalized bump stocks. Bad idea. As I promised today, the Department of Justice will issue the rule banning bump stocks with a mandated comment period.

We will ban all devices that turn legal weapons into illegal machine guns." Good idea. I added the good idea. Joining me now, Gina Loudon, Political Analyst, member of President's Trump Media Advisory Board, radio talk show host, Dom Giordano. Great to have you both with us. Gina, I mean, this is bump stocks. What in the world was anybody in the Obama administration thinking? It's such a silly idea, Gina.

GINA LOUDON, MEMBER, DONALD J. TRUMP MEDIA ADVISORY BOARD: It was such silly Idea, but you see, the thing about is just, Lou, the people on the left seem to never be interested in what works. They don't want to deal with data, they don't want to deal with research. They wanted just to do something that feels good. They want to ban things that look scary instead of actually worrying about what will save lives. And for me, as a person who has relied on data and research my whole life as a psychology professional, I look at what actually works to help people. And that's where we need to start. That's the conversation that we need to have. I'm very glad that our President certainly seems to want to have those conversations as well.

DOBBS: Dom, what do you think?

DOM GIORDANO, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST: Well, Lou, I think this is another example of the real upside of President Trump is making a promise and then following through and checking it off and then doing a good job, I think, despite the media, at getting the word out that he's doing that, as we're talking about right now. And he's done this consistently on issue after issue, after issue. And that's why the base recognizes that and they're still supportive.

DOBBS: And this idea of bump stocks, I got to tell you, I know a thing or two about guns but I had never heard of a bump stock before Las Vegas. I mean, I really had never heard of it. It makes no sense. It is ridiculous. It has nothing to do, to me, with anything necessary for defense or for sport. It's just a nonsensical idea and as the President points out, it does moves the semi-automatic weapons into the category of machine gun with the rate of fire. So, now, now let's see how long it takes the idiots to try to take away handguns, rifles and shotguns. Because you know, as Gina was alluding to, that's going to be the play. Because there's no question that the left means to roll back our second amendment rights in this country, period.

LOUDON: But we need to be consistent.

GIORDANO: Well, right. And that's what the march -- that's what the march is going to be about tomorrow, Lou. As you know, I'm an educator and I see these kids, the Parkland kids, a couple of them are out of control.

DOBBS: Isn't that disgusting? We're tuning in to high school assemblies.

GIORDANO: Yes, that's right.

DOBBS: The aggregated wisdom of 18-year-olds. I mean, this is really --

LOUDON: Who by their own words, Lou, say that they shouldn't be able to own guns even though they can go to war but they think that they should be able to make laws. I mean, none of this makes any sense at all. And the very fact, that we are giving such gravitas to people who just -- they haven't had enough life experience yet, Lou, to be experts on much of anything yet. And I don't think, it's not insulting them to say that. I have children. I respect them. I love them. I think my children are brilliant but Lou, I'm not going to put them in charge of public policy as opposed to somebody who study this their whole entire life.

DOBBS: Well, George Clooney is. I mean, we can just step aside. And, you know, it's -- we can't even get test scores rising in this country yet we're watching two teachers unions move children into the street to pursue their political aims. I mean, it is outrageous what they're doing. (INAUDIBLE) You get that question.

GIORDANO: Well, exactly. And as Gina just said, these are nuance complicated issues where people studied the policy, they're actually knowledgeable about this things. And I have to say too, Lou, as an educator, there's a couple of these kids that are just rude in the way that they proceed here, as if they are bullet proof, so to speak, by -- the media is almost wondering (INAUDIBLE) in to this kids.

DOBBS: Let's find another noun next time.

GIORDANO: Well, I caught myself to that, but Lou, a couple of these kids are legitimate, they're sincere about remembering their colleagues and all that. A couple of the others had just got and an almost (INAUDIBLE) this media presence.

DOBBS: Exploited. No doubt about it.

LOUDON: But Lou -- but Lou, they're not covering, I live here -- this is where I live. They're not covering the children like my children who go to school close by where this happened and my children don't agree with these students doing this march. And where is the attention on them? They come to me in social media, I'm sure they've come to both of you too, because they do understand our constitution and our bill of rights and our second amendment. And they want to make sure it's protected for their future. But they're not listening to them, Lou. They're only listening to the radical -- more radical children who have a totally one-way slant.

DOBBS: Or they just happened to have parent who work with the teacher's union or whatever.

Here, let's turn to Facebook, because speaking of young people whose minds are being really dramatically irresponsibly, in my opinion, managed by these psychographic driven, algorithms and propositions on the technology of Facebook and other social media. This has really got to stop, Dom. It really does, it's got be regulated and it's got to happen now.

GIORDANO: Lou, I would agree. It's not just Facebook, it's Google, it's all this other enterprises. The amount of power, this is different. And that's why we haven't caught up with it. And I think, you've been making a great point early on about this. This is not just economic power, this is a power to actually influence our lives, somewhat in the deepest levels, particularly with millennials and others that engage in this all day long.

DOBBS: And particularly children -- and particularly children, Gina.

GIORDANO: Yes, exactly.

LOUDON: Yes, listen, if you want to use my information, let's make a deal. Guys, I am all about the free market, Lou. So, if they want to use my data, how about they pay me for my data. How about I'm a partner in the things that I buy on Facebook and other places. And there are ways to do this where the disclosure is in place, people understand what they're giving away and the free market --

DOBBS: But even with that -- but even with that, Gina, the way in which Facebook and other social media particularly are influencing children with their -- with their business model, with their content is irresponsible, it has to end now. And if Congress doesn't move on this immediately, I can't imagine that they won't even I mean within days.

LOUDON: You're right and Lou, there are deeper darker consequences as well. The amount of depression is in children, especially because their brains are a little bit less developed, the emotional senses of their brain. The amount of depression is directly relative to how much time they spend with their face in that screen, Lou. That's something nobody is talking about right now. It's a great concern, I'm sure -- I'm sure that the teacher here knows all about this. It's a great concern (INAUDIBLE)

GIORDANO: Lou, what I was going to say is, this idea of Zuckerberg testifying, again, we need people in Congress that are more fluent with these things, you know --

DOBBS: You know, we need those people too. But I want to see Zuckerberg explaining to the American people, to Congress and to the Senate and to the President what the hell he and his company have been doing and take responsibility instead of doing that unintelligible blabber mumble jumble that he has so far, treated the press to. Dom Giordano, Gina Loudon, thank you both for being here.

GIORDANO: Thank you very much.

LOUDON: Thanks, Lou

DOBBS: Thank you both. Up next, RINO's Ryan and McConnell abandoning conservatives. Well they're doing more than that. They're trying to back the pickup over them and they've sold out to the Chamber of Commerce and, well, every local U.S. multinational they can find. We take that up. And the national left wing media mocking members of the Trump administration over their faith. I take that up with Pastor Robert Jeffers, here next. Stay with us. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: President Trump today declaring he will never again sign a budget bill like the budget busting ominous spending bill. President Trump with curios veto threat and then grudgingly signed that spending bill. He called it a ridiculous situation. Fox News Chief Congressional Correspondent, Mike Emanuel, with the report.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We looked at the veto, I looked very seriously at the veto. I was thinking about doing the veto. But because of the incredible gains that we've been able to make for the military, that overrode any of our -- any of our thinking.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE EMANUEL, FOX NEWS CHIEF CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Late night last night on the Senate floor lawmakers voted 65-32 to approve the package and sent it to President Trump for his signature. Like the President, many who supported it backed it for the additional $60 billion devoted to rebuilding the military. Today some Democrats blasted the President for being inconsistent.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. TIM KAINE (D), VIRGINIA: We've grown used to just complete unpredictability. So, you know, and then who knows what he'll do an hour from now. But I do know this. This is a good deal. It's a classic compromise. There are things I really like. There were things I wish were in the bill. I wish that the dreamer deal that we put on the table for the President, that he would have accepted it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EMANUEL: Now there's plenty of blame game between the two parties over which side could not get to the yes on the so-called dreamers. Young people brought this country illegally by their parents. A key Democrat challenged the President's ability to cut an agreement.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CHRIS VAN HOLLEN (D), MARYLAND: You've got a President that claims he's the great negotiator, the art of the deal. Where was he when the deal was being made? You know, wakes up the next day and says he wants something different. He's actually one of the worst negotiators I've ever seen.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EMANUEL: Part of the President's frustration is with the rules of the Senate and the fact, 49 Democrats had a lot of leverage. Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has resisted calls to change the Senate filibuster rules. Recognizing one day, the GOP will be the minority party again. A veteran Republican says there is merit to changing the budget process here in Congress.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. JOHNNY ISAKSON (R) GEORGIA: I'd rather see something like, I'll never sign one of these again, so, from now and now, let's do appropriations right or let's, you know, talk it out. That's what we ought to be thinking about the future, not trying to recreate the past.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EMANUEL: With the bill signed the threat of the government shutdown is gone for at least six months, Lou?

DOBBS: Well, we'll take every six month we get. Thank you Emanuel, thank you.

Up next, the national left wing national media's on holy war against the Trump administration.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Occasionally you bow the head and bend the knee. I encourage you to do that. I'm someone that believes that prayer changes things, so pray for America.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: We're praying. We'll take up the White House under fire for its faith. Pastor Robert Jeffress, our guest here next. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Two members of the national left wing national media forced to apologize for attacking the Trump administration and their faith. "MSNBC" host, Stephanie Ruhle, now says she meant no offense after she mocked Larry Kudlow's faith. And Joy Behar who is always just right near the very essence of contrition publicly apologized for mocking Vice President Pence's Christians faith. Joining us tonight, Robert Jeffress Pastor of the First Baptist Church in Dallas, a Fox Business contributor. Great to see you Pastor. And I wanted to -- I wanted -- just I have never heard so many people attacking Christians on whatever level. What is -- there seems to be just an insistence thing that they do so.

DR. ROBERT JEFFRESS, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, isn't that true? And isn't it also true that if Joy Behar or Stephanie Ruhle had attacked a Muslim for their faith, they would have been fired by their networks in a nanosecond. But it's always open season on conservative Christians by the media. But let me tell you what's going on here, Lou.

The reason this is happening is liberals know that conservative Christians are the last speed bump on the road to the godless immoral society that liberals dream of and that is exactly why they're attacking them. And isn't it ironic that it took a secular billionaire businessman from New York City named Donald J. Trump to recognize that marginalization of Christianity that was going on, he spoke up about it. And got elected by the largest margin of the evangelicals in history, that's the reason they support him so much.

DOBBS: And, you know, he spoke up about it, he spoke up early and he spoke up alone on the campaign trail, talking about the persecution of Christians around the world. And to see the left do this, "MSNBC" going after, what's her name, Ruhle, going after Larry Kudlow who worked at "CNBC", a sister network. I mean, there's not even a kinship in media. How low have we fallen?

JEFFRESS: Well, that's right, Lou. And they both have this in common, the personalities you mentioned, Larry as well as Vice President Pence, they claim that their faith has changed them -- has changed them. And that, you know, that's what we're declaring this Sunday night in our 'March for Eternal Life'. We're going to have thousands of people marching through the streets of downtown Dallas carrying a giant illuminating cross saying it is the gospel of Jesus Christ that can change people's heart. And look, you talked earlier about the march for your life rallies tomorrow for gun control legislation.

DOBBS: I'm not talking about them -- I'm not talking about them, I don't care about them. Let them be, if you're going to march a bunch of children through the streets of the country, that's their business. If they don't find that exploitive and if they don't find that demeaning and graceless, you know, that's their problem. But I don't have to pay attention to them.

JEFFRESS: But what we're saying is --

DOBBS: Unless you tell me to and then I'll pay attention.

JEFFRESS: No, sir -- no, sir -- no, sir. What I am saying though is look, trying to depend upon legislation alone to end the violence epidemic is like putting a band aid on a cancer. It doesn't deal with the heart issue and we're talking about what the heart issue is and that is our relationship to Christ. So, this is a positive way of saying we're not ashamed of our faith. We want to proclaim it.

DOBBS: And you know, I think, marches and demonstrations and people actually talking about Jesus Christ are wonderful things and we don't do enough of it -- we don't do enough of it on television, we don't do enough of it on radio, we don't do enough of it in the streets of Dallas or any other community in this country. And it's a wonderful thing you're doing. I truly commend you and the good folks in Dallas.

JEFFRESS: Well, thank you very much. And we invite people to tune in. It's going to be live streamed. And again, this is a new day in America, I believe, Lou. And we thank President Trump for creating a new atmosphere where people feel emboldened to share their faith.

DOBBS: You know, emboldened to share their faith. You know, I like the words. I guess I resist just a little thinking what we have to be bold to share our faith. But it is necessary to be bold, I believe, in this day and age where there is so much oppression of the Christian faith here at home and indeed around the world. But always lifting us up is Pastor Robert Jeffress. And we thank you for so doing and share sharing your time with us, Pastor. Thank you so much.

JEFFRESS: Thank you Lou.

DOBBS: And have a great march.

JEFFRESS: Thank you.

DOBBS: That's it for us tonight. We thank you for joining us. Ann Coulter, General Jack Keane among our guests here at Monday. It makes the weekend well, just worthwhile just to know we're going to have all of that waiting for you on Monday. Have a great weekend. Thanks for being with us tonight. Good night from New York.

END

urn:contentItem:5RY4-D451-JB20-G4C3-00000-00President Trump Bashed Wasteful Spending, Then He Praised Over- Budget Military Projects; Zuckerberg's 'Megalomaniac' Style Has Made Facebook the Behemoth It Is; Bump Stock Ban; Battle over DACA; President Trump Calls Over to End Filibuster; Christianity under Attack2018-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:28ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTJohn Lonski, Morgan Wright, Gina Loudon, Dom GiordanoNEWSFinancial032301cb.229President Trump Bashed Wasteful Spending, Then He Praised Over- Budget Military Projects; Zuckerberg's 'Megalomaniac' Style Has Made Facebook the Behemoth It Is; Bump Stock Ban; Battle over DACA; President Trump Calls Over to End Filibuster; Christianity under AttackLou Dobbs, Ed Rollins, Deirdre Bolton, Robert Jeffress; Mike Emanuel

LOU DOBBS, FBN HOST: Good evening everybody. Happy Friday. The top stories tonight, Wall Street crushed. The stock market suffered a second straight day of steep losses as establishment Red RINOs and Dems in Congress went on a $1.3 trillion spending spree abandoning all restraint in fiscal policy and the Federal Reserve doing its part to confound reason and create more uncertainty by raising rates with no evidence of inflation. Today's losses capping what was the worst week on Wall Street in more than two years. It was simply put, a bloodbath. President Trump hesitated but then did sign the spending bill to assure the largest funding in history for our military and to avoid a government shutdown. But President Trump vows never again will he sign such a reckless and undisciplined spending bill written by Ryan, and McConnell, and Schumer, and Pelosi ignoring the Republican majority altogether.

Joining us tonight to examine the collapse of a fiscal and monetary policy in the same week, one of the top economists in the country Moody's John Lonski, Ed Rollins, one of the country's best political analyst. Also tonight, Facebook's feckless CEO Mark Zuckerberg will have to do more than mumble unintelligibly to the media. Facebook -- unintelligibly. Facebook is in crisis and its so-called leaders turn out to be mostly inept and irresponsible. We'll have a lot more from Mr. Zuckerberg here tonight. Lawmakers of both parties in the House and Senate are no longer asking Zuckerberg to testify. They're ordering to come to Capitol Hill and to explain his lack of leadership, integrity, and the disastrous policies that lead to the mess that is now Facebook.

Cybersecurity expert Morgan Wright, our Deirdre Bolton on what issue to be a regime of regulation about to descend on Silicon Valley, technology, social media in general. We take all of that up here tonight. Our top story, President Trump says the never-ending cycle of budget brinkmanship in the swamp ends today. President Trump signed the $1.3 trillion spending bill needed to keep the government running for the next six months, but not before blasting lawmakers for wasting money on pet projects giving themselves a raise playing politics with DACA recipients, lying about wall funding, and endangering the U.S. military.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: There are a lot of things that I'm unhappy about in this bill. There are a lot of things that we shouldn't have had in this bill, but we were in a sense forced if we want to build our military, we were forced to have. There are some things that we should have in the bill. But I say to Congress, I will never sign another bill like this again. I'm not going to do it again. Nobody read it. It's only hours old. Some people don't even know what is in there, $1.3 trillion. It's the second largest ever. President Obama signed one that was actually larger which I'm sure he wasn't too happy with either.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Joining us tonight the best political mind in the business Ed Rollins, former Reagan White House Political Director, Fox Business Political Analyst, John Lonski, chief economist, Managing Director at Moody's. Great to have you both here and let me begin if I may, John, with you. Fourteen hundred points off the Dow. It was a crushing trillion dollar loss for the week and it is a direct result it seems to me for the most of part a direct result of a fiscal policy that has just been overturned.

JOHN LONSKI, MANAGING DIRECTOR, MOODY: That's a problem on the interest rate front. That's why we have a long-term bond yields of about a quarter of a percentage point higher then where they ought to be at this point in time and we don't want to forget about the problems we're having with international trade. Worry about a possible trade war with China.

DOBBS: Yes. But markets hate uncertainty and if one thing these investors should have been certain about, it was about the president who had told them for two years that he was going to put punishing tariffs on China particularly, on our trading partners who have taken advantage of us for 50 years. I mean most people don't realize, for example, that the United States hasn't run a trade surplus since 1975. We have idiots at the Chamber of Commerce and The Business Roundtable going around saying it's not a zero sum game. Tell that to the American people. Tell that to the American middle class bulk.

LONSKI: Yes. And that's why Donald Trump is president today and let's not forget that one of the reasons for these actions taken against China is because China engages in unfair trade practices. I mean China --

DOBBS: And they steal our technology. They steal our most of advanced innovations and they do so with front companies. They're carrying out daily 24/7 espionage against the United States with those front companies in the United States.

LONSKI: But we have a very close linkage with China. Let's not forget. Many U.S. companies manufacture their goods. High technology, telecommunication devices are manufactured in China for U.S. companies to sell in the United States.

DOBBS: Yes. And that's one of the biggest problems and that's one of the big problems that this president intends to reverse.

ED ROLLINS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, he has -- I applauded that in fact. He threatened a veto today. He should have threatened a veto a month ago and the reality is, you know, political system does not work when it comes to budgets. When you put four --

DOBBS: But now you got scoreless dogs leading the Republican Party in both Houses.

Joining us tonight, Robert Jeffress Pastor of the First Baptist Church in Dallas, a Fox Business contributor. Great to see you Pastor. And I wanted to -- I wanted -- just I have never heard so many people attacking Christians on whatever level. What is -- there seems to be just an insistence thing that they do so.

DR. ROBERT JEFFRESS, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, isn't that true? And isn't it also true that if Joy Behar or Stephanie Ruhle had attacked a Muslim for their faith, they would have been fired by their networks in a nanosecond. But it's always open season on conservative Christians by the media. But let me tell you what's going on here, Lou.

The reason this is happening is liberals know that conservative Christians are the last speed bump on the road to the godless immoral society that liberals dream of and that is exactly why they're attacking them. And isn't it ironic that it took a secular billionaire businessman from New York City named Donald J. Trump to recognize that marginalization of Christianity that was going on, he spoke up about it. And got elected by the largest margin of the evangelicals in history, that's the reason they support him so much.

DOBBS: And, you know, he spoke up about it, he spoke up early and he spoke up alone on the campaign trail, talking about the persecution of Christians around the world. And to see the left do this, "MSNBC" going after, what's her name, Ruhle, going after Larry Kudlow who worked at "CNBC", a sister network. I mean, there's not even a kinship in media. How low have we fallen?

JEFFRESS: Well, that's right, Lou. And they both have this in common, the personalities you mentioned, Larry as well as Vice President Pence, they claim that their faith has changed them -- has changed them. And that, you know, that's what we're declaring this Sunday night in our 'March for Eternal Life'. We're going to have thousands of people marching through the streets of downtown Dallas carrying a giant illuminating cross saying it is the gospel of Jesus Christ that can change people's heart. And look, you talked earlier about the march for your life rallies tomorrow for gun control legislation.

DOBBS: I'm not talking about them -- I'm not talking about them, I don't care about them. Let them be, if you're going to march a bunch of children through the streets of the country, that's their business. If they don't find that exploitive and if they don't find that demeaning and graceless, you know, that's their problem. But I don't have to pay attention to them.

JEFFRESS: But what we're saying is --

DOBBS: Unless you tell me to and then I'll pay attention.

JEFFRESS: No, sir -- no, sir -- no, sir. What I am saying though is look, trying to depend upon legislation alone to end the violence epidemic is like putting a band aid on a cancer. It doesn't deal with the heart issue and we're talking about what the heart issue is and that is our relationship to Christ. So, this is a positive way of saying we're not ashamed of our faith. We want to proclaim it.

DOBBS: And you know, I think, marches and demonstrations and people actually talking about Jesus Christ are wonderful things and we don't do enough of it -- we don't do enough of it on television, we don't do enough of it on radio, we don't do enough of it in the streets of Dallas or any other community in this country. And it's a wonderful thing you're doing. I truly commend you and the good folks in Dallas.

JEFFRESS: Well, thank you very much. And we invite people to tune in. It's going to be live streamed. And again, this is a new day in America, I believe, Lou. And we thank President Trump for creating a new atmosphere where people feel emboldened to share their faith.

DOBBS: You know, emboldened to share their faith. You know, I like the words. I guess I resist just a little thinking what we have to be bold to share our faith. But it is necessary to be bold, I believe, in this day and age where there is so much oppression of the Christian faith here at home and indeed around the world. But always lifting us up is Pastor Robert Jeffress. And we thank you for so doing and share sharing your time with us, Pastor. Thank you so much.

JEFFRESS: Thank you Lou.

DOBBS: And have a great march.

JEFFRESS: Thank you.

DOBBS: That's it for us tonight. We thank you for joining us. Ann Coulter, General Jack Keane among our guests here at Monday. It makes the weekend well, just worthwhile just to know we're going to have all of that waiting for you on Monday. Have a great weekend. Thanks for being with us tonight. Good night from New York.
