JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Right.

BARTIROMO: And what consumer is showing within this GDP number, the expect -- 3.5 percent is the number, Jon. 3.5 percent is better than expected. We were expecting 3.3 percent, and we are watching markets for any reaction. Your expectations and your reaction to a 3.5 percent number, Jon.

HILSENRATH: Well, that's a strong number. What I want -- what I want to do is break this down a little bit and see where it comes from. I think trade was probably a drag for the quarter. I think we also have to look very carefully in addition to the consumer at government. There's been a - - as we've reported today in The Wall Street Journal, there's been a big pickup in military spending, government spending is contributing a lot to growth right now.

BARTIROMO: Consumer spending is up four -- consumer spending is doing well within this, up four percent?

HILSENRATH: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Correct, four percent in the third quarter. The strongest rate of growth in almost four years on the consumer side.

BLOCK: Street was looking for up 3.3 on that as well, so that's a big beat.

PEEK: That's big. That's a big beat.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Jon?

HILSENRATH: Right. And that -- I mean, that makes sense. You've got an unemployment rate that's down under four percent, lowest levels since the 1960s. And you also have tax cuts that are making their way through the system, so we should be seeing strong consumer spending right now. We also have to look at what's going on on the business investment side, you know, for this growth to be sustainable in the long run, we need to see more business investment, and I want to see how that breaks down as well.

MCDOWELL: Investment by companies was weak, Jon, non-residential, fixed- investment, spending on commercial construction equipment, intellectual property products like software rose only eight-tenths of one percent in the third quarter. That was after rising in an 8.7 percent rate in the second quarter and 11-1/2 in the first.

BLOCK: Inflation is also light here, core PCE came in up 1.6 percent quarter over quarter, street was looking for up 1.8, so there's not some runaway inflation story here. It looks like consumption is strong. As Dagen points out, investment weak --

MCDOWELL: And just one --

BARTIROMO: Markets improving.

MCDOWELL: Right. One more thing, private inventories which is something that Liz was talking about, private inventories added more than two percentage points to the third-quarter growth rate, reversing that trend that you saw in the second quarter when companies were drawing down their stockpiles ahead of the tariffs.

PEEK: That has been sort of an offset on going quarter-to-quarter with the trade -- the widening trade deficit. It seems to me that consumer news here is very important, because the fourth quarter is all about holiday sales, all about consumer spending, the fact that that's held up and actually beat by such a wide margin, I think teases up for less pessimism if you want to look at it that way about the fourth quarter.

BARTIROMO: And interesting, there's no revisions on the second quarter, Jon. The second quarter was really strong at 4.2 percent, that is not being revised downward, so that stays in place with the better-than- expected initial or advanced reading, the first reading for the third quarter at 3-1/2 percent, Jon.

HILSENRATH: Well, so I'd say a few things here based on these breakdowns that you've given me. One is let's go back and talk about that inflation number, the market has been very concerned and the President has been very concerned about the Fed continuing to raise interest rates going into next year. You know, the inflation numbers have come in kind of soft over the last couple of months, and I think the Fed is going to have to start paying attention to that and factor in that into how far they want to go on interest rate increases.

On the inventory piece that you talked about, that's a volatile number, it doesn't fundamentally have much to do with economic growth in the long run. So, the fact that it added a lot to growth in third quarter I think becomes a potential drag on growth in the second quarter. A lot of the estimates that we get at The Wall Street Journal for fourth quarter is that it's going to slow down a little bit on overall growth, and it's going to slow down -- growth is going to slow down going into 2019, that inventory piece plays into that.

PEEK: It seems to me it's almost a percent number for people who are Fed watchers, though, right? Because it isn't really high enough to spur alarm at the Fed, any kind of acceleration, or you know, incremental rate hikes next year neither is it low enough to kind of take them off their paths. So, it seems to me that's sort of a neutral.

MCDOWELL: Although, I will add looking at this report, higher borrowing costs have hurt housing and auto sales.

PEEK: Sure.

MCDOWELL: Spending on motor vehicles and parts added just 0.09 percentage points, so third quarter growth, and in terms of residential-fixed investment fell at a four percent annual rate in the third quarter. So, is --

HILSENRATH: You know, residential has been -- residential has been a really big drag for several quarters now, and that's continuing. It's a little puzzling because there's under supply in the housing market, but builders (INAUDIBLE) building because labor is short, and land supply is short, and costs are going up, so, you know, we should be seeing more building and we're just not getting it right now.

MCDOWELL: But, Jon, there is -- during the summer, there was a plentiful amount of inventory coming on the market in many housing markets that were already weak. There are a lot of pockets of weakness in housing in this country that are overlooked because we tend to focus on the metropolitan areas.

BLOCK: You know, and supply, actually, has been going up in some of these metrics. I think I saw a 7.1 month supply in one of the -- one of the metrics this week on existing home sales. The only thing I'll point out is, even in the Fed minutes, it was pointed out that higher rates might be crimping residential investments to your point, Jon.

BARTIROMO: Well, I also think that it's, you know, understandable that the third quarter rate of business investment was weak. And this is actually the weakest since the fourth quarter of 2016, spending on structures down, 7.9 percent. You would expect companies to pull back in terms of spending with the uncertainties of tariffs, with the uncertainties of the demand picture on the horizon, because there is all of this worry, this narrative that things slow down a bit. So, I'm not surprised that the level of investment spending is weak in this report, Jon, particularly after we've seen animal spirits these last two years, spending has been up.

HILSENRATH: Well, there are three things going on in the business investment side we have -- we have to look at. One is you mentioned structure is down, structures has been very strong because there's been a lot of investment going on in oil and gas rates as oil prices came up. They've stabilized so maybe that spurred a growth that we've gotten that's also stabilized.

The other thing you just mentioned, you know, with tariffs coming on, a lot of companies are talking about slowing their investment plans because they're just so uncertain about what the trade landscape is going to look like. And then the third piece is tax cuts. You know, the Trump administration, Republicans in Congress cut taxes, corporate tax rates very aggressively to try to spur business investment. But it looks like this tariff uncertainty is taking away some of the boom that they were hoping to get on the business investment side.

You know, again, if these growth rates are going to be sustainable, it's going to have to show up in business investment, and I'd say, the soft number there has got to be a little disappointing today.

PEEK: I would say politically, too, that's a problem, because Democrats have really made the case that the tax cuts for corporations are really just going into stock buybacks, they're not going to have any impact on workers, and we need investment to get productivity up, so that wages will go up, so I do think it's a disappointing number. And probably is a result of the uncertainty.

BLOCK: You know, Jon, the other day, you know, we're starting to hear some noises about the yield curve, there were some comments a few weeks ago saying, well, it's kind of a relief. It was even in the minutes as well that with rates backing up and along the curve may be there's not so much risk of inversion. We see what the 10-year is doing now. Look, my call was actually -- we're going to see the 10-year back below three. You can write that down, I'm saying it right now. Are we going to get the Fed more concerned now about the possibility of inversion and what that can mean? Do they care about that?

BARTIROMO: And let's point out this op-ed in The Journal today written by Minneapolis Federal Reserve President Neel Kashkari titled "Pause Interest Rate Hikes to Help the Labor Force Grow." Kashkari writes, "With the Fed funds rate at two to 2-1/4 percent, monetary policy is now close to neutral, neither stimulating nor restricting the economy. Prematurely tapping the brakes could restrain wage growth and keep many Americans from participating in the economic recovery." You expect the 10-year to go back down below three percent. Is it partly because you think that they are going to see a pause in the rate hikes?

BLOCK: I think we're going to see a slowdown and I think we are going to see that happen. And, you know, look, I'm going to say it right now, I think next year, I think two hikes max.

BARTIROMO: Two hikes max.

BLOCK: That's where I am right now. I've been there.

BARTIROMO: They're at three hikes for next year, Jon, isn't that right?

HILSENRATH: Yes. And it all comes down to the inflation numbers. The -- you know, you're talking about the yield curve and long-term interest rates, and I think long-term interest rates are a signal of how concerned the long-term investors are in the outlook for inflation. And if the inflation numbers come -- continue to come in in soft, and it sounds like they were soft in this number, then I think the Fed has going to have to think about maybe slowing down the pace of rate increases. You know, I just wanted to ask you all, we've talked about a lot of different components if this, if anyone has the government spending numbers, I'd love to know what they are, because they -- military spending is a really big impact on growth right now, there's a lot -- there's a lot of --

BARTIROMO: Yes, here it is. We got it, Jon.

MCDOWELL: Government expenditures were up at 3.3 percent annual rate, and the third-quarter defense spending rising in an annual rate of 4.6 percent, Jon.

HILSENRATH: Yes. Yes, that's a big driver, and that one is going to continue. So, the two things I think we have driving economic growth right now are consumers and government, ironically.

BLOCK: You know, the last time we didn't mention explicitly here is that exports were down 3.5 percent in Q3 and imports rose at 9.1 percent. It just plays into this whole rising deficit thing. Look, I don't think the bottom market cares but it's part of it.

MCDOWELL: But we -- but we would know that watching these trade deficit numbers coming in, in the third quarter, Jon, that the trade deficit has widened throughout the third quarter. Again, there were some pull forward in the second quarter where you had, say, soybeans exporters really pushing inventory overseas ahead of those tariffs between the United States and China that went into place over the summer, so, again, that reversed course and showed up in this GDP figure.

HILSENRATH: That's exactly right, Dagen, you have to look at what happened with trade in the second and third quarter combined, there was a lot of anticipatory reaction in the second quarter, particularly in agricultural goods, and that looks like it reversed. But, you know, with the tariffs that we have going on, we have to think about trade being a potential drag for the economy -- for the global economy in the months ahead.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And that's what we were -- we're also expecting companies to start pulling back as we have seen in this report, because of the uncertainty of it. You know, what will the impact of these tariffs be in this quarter and into 2019? That's one reason that you --

PEEK: That's a little ironic, right? I mean, basically, under Obama, the uncertainty all had to do with regulation and changes that the business community faced day-to-day, now it is so unfortunate that we have that deregulatory cloud sort of lifting, but in its place, we have uncertainty about the tariff policies.

MCDOWELL: Well, we switched -- we switched from one form of government swappiness to another.

PEEK: Yes, that's true.

MCDOWELL: That it's government intervention in business, where if you use steel in this country, you have to go to the Commerce Department hat in hand and beg for waivers.

PEEK: That's right.

MCDOWELL: There have been thousands of waivers.

BLOCK: And there is a huge backlog at the Commerce Department right now for these applications for waivers.

MCDOWELL: That's right.

HILSENRATH: So, there is a lot of red tape on the trade front.

BARTIROMO: Yes, all right, Jon, we leave it there. Great to see you this morning, Jon, thanks so much.

HILSENRATH: Great. Thanks a lot.

BARTIROMO: Great analysis, as always, from Jon Hilsenrath from The Wall Street Journal. Once again, the GDP is out, this is the first reading of the third quarter, it came in better-than-expected, up 3.5 percent versus an estimate of 3.3 percent.

Coming up next, Microsoft on track to pass Amazon in market cap after earnings. We will tell you where that market cap stands. We break down the latest numbers right after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We told you the breaking news earlier. The GDP out moments ago. The economy grew at a -- at a rate of 3-1/2 percent in the third quarter. This is the first take on the third quarter. GDP is better than the expectation which calls for 3.3 percent.

Futures came off of their lows, then, went back down again. We're still looking at a decline at the start of trading, although, we are off of the lows. Dow Industrials down 160 points, NASDAQ down 116.

"VARNEY & COMPANY" host, Stuart Varney weighs in. And Stu, what I think is really a good takeaway is the fact that the consumer part of this report --

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- consumer spending up four percent, Stu.

VARNEY: Yes, the -- what is it? Consumption, that's the proper (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: That's right.

VARNEY: Consumption of, what, four percent. Now, that's a big number. That is a very bright spot in this report. You know, Maria, I was the party pooper about the Mega Million jackpot.

BARTIROMO: I know you are.

VARNEY: Well, I'm not -- I thought I might be the party pooper over GDP because I was really hoping for a four percent number as growth in that quarter. OK, so, we got 3-1/2 percent. I still think that's pretty good. I'm a little disappointed because I was looking for four and more, because that's what we've been promised if we get the tax cut. But, look, I'll take 3.5 percent, especially coming on the back of a 4.2 percent growth rate in the second quarter. That's the best back-to-back quarter performance that we've seen in four years.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: So, the trend is still very strong and if we keep this up, we're going to have a much better than three percent gain for the full calendar year, 2018. I'll take it, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I'll take it. And let's not forget that the second quarter that you just mentioned, 4.3 percent, no revision there, Stu.

VARNEY: Right.

BARTIROMO: Right? So, we still got the 4.2 percent in the second quarter and now, 3-1/2 percent for the third quarter. I know you're going to dig deep into these numbers in about 10 minutes. We will see you top of the hour.

VARNEY: You got it, Maria. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Stu. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour, 9:00 Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join Stuart and his great team there.

First, though, Microsoft makes a move, the technology giant now on track to pass Amazon's market cap. We've got those numbers. Microsoft's shares today down two percent, Amazon down eight percent. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We have breaking news right now. An 11th suspicious package has been found. This one from an Opa-locka, Florida facility. The FBI is confirming that this package was addressed to New Jersey Senator, Cory Booker. This is an 11th package coming out of the Florida facility and we are following that and other things this morning. We'll bring you the latest there.

Meanwhile, we want to look at market, we've got technology earnings have been leading this market sell-off, disappointing revenue numbers last night from a number of high-profile companies.

Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange right now with those details. Nic, good morning to you.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, good morning, Maria. So, we're off of the lows of the morning on that better-than-expected GDP number. But we're looking at Amazon which had that revenue miss and the guidance on revenue, obviously, less than expected. So, some concerns potentially about the holiday season, that's one thing, but the other areas, such as cloud and advertising units continue to grow, have been the area of growth. And you've had a mixed bag, some analysts actually raising their target, some pulling back, and some that are raising still like the long-term growth story on Amazon. And those FANG stocks are up 37 percent annually over the last -- since 2014.

By the way, as Amazon pulls back, we might see Microsoft move higher in that closer to the trillion-dollar market. Remember when Apple crossed it, didn't close there, but Microsoft now may be getting closer, may surpass Amazon today with Amazon sell-offs. So, we'll watch for the market cap battle.

And then, there's Alphabet, Google. The one area that people were concerned about is people are looking to Amazon to search for products instead of Google. So, we've seen, obviously, they've had surging profit with the slower sales growth. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Nic. Thank you so much. And of course, it's been an incredibly volatile and busy week for stocks. We had a really busy week on this program as well. Take a look at some of the top moments with the program.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE) business with the Pentagon. Amazon wants it, too, but Google walks away from the business with the DOD, and yet, they are all-in on going into China.

LARRY ELLISON, CO-FOUNDER AND EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, ORACLE: I hear Jeff Bezos and I absolutely agree. I think U.S. tech companies who say we will not -- we will not support the U.S. military. You know, we will not -- we will not work on any technology that helps our military. But yet, goes into China and facilitates the Chinese government, surveilling their people, is pretty shocking.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is Larry.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hey, the Oracle of Oracle. What a pleasure. Nice to see you.

BARTIROMO: Tony Stark, I -- did you influence that character?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I've heard that. I didn't know Stanley is (INAUDIBLE) so I guess -- I guess Tony Stark was invented before (INAUDIBLE) so, I guess no.

KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSELOR TO PRESIDENT TRUMP: Part of why the President would like to continue cut tax with the middle class is because it has gone so well. He sees the fruits of that tax cut and jobs act which passed last December without a single Democratic vote.

BARTIROMO: This can't possibly happen before the midterms. The midterms are 13 days away and this has to be voted on and Congress is -- the House is not even in session.

CONWAY: Well, Washington moves a little bit too slowly for the sheer volume and velocity of the Trump agenda.

REP. CHUCK FLEISCHMANN (R), TENNESSEE: Obviously, it was so important to get tax reform passed. We got no help from the Democrats. That's actually very sad, and I think that's going to hurt them in the midterms.

MARK PENN, FORMER ADVISOR TO THE CLINTONS: I've seen the biggest buildup and turnout to a midterm election that we've ever seen, which classically has fairly low turnout. And I think we've seen the blue wave become a blue edge, now, I think fairly it's a blue tossup.

MERCEDES SCHLAPP, WHITE HOUSE SENIOR ADVISOR FOR STRATEGIC COMMUNICATIONS: President Trump has been talking to the -- to Saudi Arabia, to the King, as well as to the Crown Prince. There's a continual dialogue there. Our eyes are wide-open when it comes to what we've seen to be this horrific tragedy.

GEN. JACK KEANE (RET.), FOX NEWS SENIOR STRATEGIC ANALYST: If he's found to have his fingers on this in any way, I think he is likely to be removed by his -- by his father.

LT. COL. ALLEN WEST (RET.), U.S. ARMY: This is in complete violation of human rights. We cannot continue to allow this to happen.

BARTIROMO: The migrant caravan from Honduras has swelled to at least 7,000 people now as it makes its way north.

KEANE: We've got to protect our borders, and we have got to protect our sovereignty.

FLEISCHMANN: We're seeing by virtue of this caravan right now just how chaotic and really anarchistic the border situation has become.

BARTIROMO: Violence and intimidation now on both sides of the aisle.

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA), HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER: Individual through a great big boulder through -- entered the office and another person entered as well, and they stole equipment. The one thing about America we believe in civil discourse. I mean, you could -- you could agree -- disagree with someone and not be disagreeable, but then now it's in your face.

WEST: We should not be politicizing political terrorism or violence such as this. And I would say to those people that are seeking to do so, you know, this is a crazy unhinged individual, this is not acceptable.

BARTIROMO: Impact of Iran sanctions within two weeks, your view.

STEPHEN SCHORK, PUBLISHER, THE SCHORK REPORT: We've had five months to digest this Iranian news. This Iranian news is already priced into the market. The market has shown us over the summer that it's capable of handling the current situation.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Maria. I didn't win the Mega Millions this morning, so here I am joining you from (INAUDIBLE) from New York.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I haven't checked my numbers yet, but since I didn't buy a ticket, I'm probably not going to win, that's my guess.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Hi, welcome back. Final thoughts from this all-star panel. Liz Peek?

PEEK: Well, I don't think that the GDP report did much for the markets, but let's -- if the market doesn't completely tank today, I think we're going to be in a rebuilding phase next week.

BARTIROMO: Still a good number, 3-1/2 percent growth --

(CROSSTALK)

PEEK: Yes, it definitely was. And teas up the fourth quarter pretty well.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

BLOCK: Yes, personal consumption was good, investment is challenged, trade is challenged. Let's see what happens after midterms. And longer-term, I'm going to be -- I'm going to stay optimistic.

BARTIROMO: Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Well, that's unusual. And I will be, too. So, we have about half of the S&P 500 is still yet to report, so let's hope for better revenue.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right. See the glass half full. There you go. Seize the day, everybody. Have a great weekend, Dagen McDowell, Michael Block, and Liz Peek, good to see you. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins now. Stuart, take it away.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W2T-RYV1-DY0W-41JD-00000-00President Trump Considering Blocking Migrant Entry at U.S. Southern Border; Khashoggi's Son Now in U.S.; Saudi Gov't Changes Story; Oracle's Ellison and Hurd Sit Down For First Interview Together; First Nor'easter Of Season; Ford Recall; Snap Losing Users; Bieber's Bizarre Bite; Holiday Season Hiring; Amazon Starts Minimum Wage Increase Next Week For All U.S. Employees2018-10-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:28ZLexisNexisPresident Trump Considering Blocking Migrant Entry at U.S. Southern Border; Khashoggi's Son Now in U.S.; Saudi Gov't Changes Story; Oracle's Ellison and Hurd Sit Down For First Interview Together; First Nor'easter Of Season; Ford Recall; Snap Losing Users; Bieber's Bizarre Bite; Holiday Season Hiring; Amazon Starts Minimum Wage Increase Next Week For All U.S. EmployeesLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, indeed. The earnings, obviously, confirming what a lot of people were worried about, that we're seeing a slowdown, and expectations of a slowdown as some of these companies lower guidance.

Girls, will see you in a little while. Thank you so much and good morning, everyone. Happy Friday, thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo.

And today is Friday, October 26th. Your top stories right now just at 6:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

Markets in selloff mode again this morning.

Dow Jones Industrials average expected to be down better than 255 points, that's about one percent lower at the open.

The NASDAQ, sharply lower, down 175 points right now, that is a decline of two and a half percent right now. This after the markets posted strong gains on Wall Street yesterday. We had a nice rally bouncing back after the selloff the day before.

The Dow Industrials, at the close yesterday, up 400 points, that was one and two-thirds percent at the close yesterday. The S&P 500 was up almost two percent, 50 points higher. And the NASDAQ, at the close, up three percent, 210 points higher on the NASDAQ at the close yesterday.

It's been a wild week for the markets, for sure. Right now, the Dow and the S&P 500 are down nearly two percent on the week, as you can see there.

Global markets this morning look like this. European indices down across the board.

FT-100 down one and two-thirds percent. CAC Quarante in Paris down two and a quarter percent, and the DAX Index in Germany down almost two percent.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board. To report worst performer there was in Korea. The KOSPI Index down one and three-quarters percent. Hong Kong down better than one percent.

Technology earnings in focus, once again, Amazon and Snap, among the names report after the bell last night. Look at Amazon sliding after revenue missed expectations. The stock down 10 and a quarter percent right now at 1600 and change.

Snap down almost 13 percent. Investors are watching Google parent, Alphabet. The company's profit soared, but sales slowed down, the revenue not as what people expected.

The bombshell report also here, sexual misconduct Ad Google weighing on the stock as well. We got a lot to tell you about going on at Google. That stock is down five and a half percent right now.

The caravan crisis, hundreds more National Guard troops making their way toward the border, as President Trump calls on the group of illegal immigrants to turn around. We will take you to Mexico live later this hour.

Then a view from the top, the CEO of Oracle, Mark Hurd, and the cofounder, Larry Ellison, weighing in on everything, from growth to artificial intelligence and data security in my exclusive interview.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

LARRY ELLISON, CO-FOUNDER, ORACLE: Cloud's -- modern cloud is constantly under attack by what are called botnets. Some are state actors, some are, you know, cyber criminals, and we're building modern robotic defenses to protect our customers' data.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: This is the first time they've ever sat down together for an interview. We will bring you that coming up. All the stories coming up this Friday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Third Seven Advisors Market Strategist, Michael Block, and Fox News Contributor, Liz Peek. Great to see you this morning.

LIZ PEEK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning. Another messy morning.

BARTIROMO: It is another messy morning. Good way to put it there.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: This is -- this is because of revenue, which is what we've been warning our viewers about for weeks and weeks and weeks, Lindsey Bell, and the like.

Overall of the half of the S&P 500 companies that have reported, 43 percent of the companies have missed revenue estimates, and that is getting worse and worse as the days wear on.

And the headlines this morning, Amazon, another profit, but sales underwhelm. Alphabet, Google parent, delivers surging profit, but slowing sales growth.

BARTIROMO: Yes, slowing sales growth, but also the guidance is troubling, right? Because they're basically saying, looking forward in the next quarter in the next year, we want to pull down the expectations a bit.

MCDOWELL: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: And Amazon's forecast for the holiday quarter was -- for revenue was below expectations as well.

So, again, it's disappointing. These valuations, you got to deliver and better. Yes.

PEEK: That's the problem. That's the problem. Narrow market, narrow segment. We've all been looking at these stocks for so long and estimates kind of got ahead of reality, I think a little bit.

BARTIROMO: And yet the backdrop still feels strong.

PEEK: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Well, in a backdrop like this, where we're about to get the GDP this morning in two and a half hours, and we're expecting a number above three percent.

MICHAEL BLOCK, MARKET STRATEGIST, THIRD SEVEN ADVISORS: Yes. We'll see about that.

You know, the thing I will say here, you know, I have to look at Amazon's guidance in particular and wonder if they're sand-bagging, but the other thing I'll point out in the revenue side is, we had Alphabet's CFO blaming the stronger dollar here and that's been a theme we've been looking at. Trade of stronger dollar, what effect is it having, it's -- is it all coming home to roost here.

And as I said to my clients, you wanted volatility, well, now you have the volatility.

BARTIROMO: Well, you sure do. We're going to get a lot of conversation this this morning.

Joining the conversation, Energy Secretary, Rick Perry, is here this morning, along with the Chairman of the RNC, Donna Romney McDaniel is here.

Arizona Congressman and House Judiciary Committee member, Andy Biggs, joining me as well with -- look at the border.

And my exclusive joint interview with Oracle founder, Larry Ellison, and Oracle CEO, Mark Hurd, both of those coming up as well. Big show ahead. Don't a miss moment of it.

But first, let's take a look at technology earnings and the tumble going on this morning. Global stocks extending declines, following disappointing third-quarter revenue from internet giants, Amazon and Alphabet.

That put a dent in a solid earning season certainly for technology, and that is what it's weighing on markets this is morning.

Both industry leaders beat on earnings, but fell short of Wall Street revenue. Amazon forecasts its weakest profit growth in two years, that's what was one of the issues with Amazon, down 10 percent this morning.

And, of course, the expectations, as you mentioned, on Amazon way up here.

PEEK: Totally.

BARTIROMO: Company just passed a trillion dollars in terms of its own market value that's --

PEEK: And they're raising costs. I mean they put through a big wage increase and so that's weighing a little bit on margins. That's the other story, I think, is a lot of companies are talking about cost pressures from either wages going up or the tariff or whatever.

But, you know, it's a little bit of a margin squeeze we're seeing for the first time in a long time.

BARTIROMO: That's exactly right.

PEEK: And it --

MCDOWELL: And some of that isn't -- because the $15 minimum wage from amazon was -- it's going to cost them about $3 billion next year according to one estimate from Morgan Stanley, but this was in reaction.

Again, the government is factoring into these companies as well that Amazon likely raised the minimum wage for its employees because, remember, Senator Bernie Sanders introduced the BEZOS Act, trying to tax big companies.

PEEK: Yes. All right. Yes.

MCDOWELL: Those employees rely on government services, so that -- that's government. And then also the government likely going to crack down on Google's business. You've seen that. That showed up in the stock.

Alphabet's stock had already lost a sixth -- one-sixth of its market value in the last months.

BARTIROMO: And I mean --

MCDOWELL: And so this was on top of the pressure we've have seen in recent months.

BARTIROMO: We pointed out that Google has 90 percent market share when it comes to surge.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Right.

BARTIROMO: And so that, you question whether or not that's going to be too big for regulation.

BLOCK: The other issue is, you know, Microsoft had very strong numbers in their cloud business, we see what Amazon did in cloud business.

Alphabet, a little disappointing on that side, and if that was supposed to be a growth area for them beyond the search business, not -- it didn't quite deliver what people wanted to --

BARTIROMO: I'll tell you, when I was talking to Larry Ellison the other day, I was just struck at how competitive he is with Amazon.

I mean, after everything --

MCDOWELL: Yes. (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: -- that he said and all of his accomplishments, he said, "Oh, yes," and then "We will beat Amazon in their database services."

MCDOWELL: That was my personal favorite part of the interview, is him just slamming these companies that try to tacitly dismiss Oracle's database.

PEEK: Right.

MCDOWELL: He's like, 'What do you think they're using?"

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: "They're using Oracle database."

BARTIROMO: They're on Oracle.

BLOCK: It's always been --

MCDOWELL: But one thing I did want to point out because we mentioned the sexual harassment issue with Google. Google said that it's fired 48 staff members over the past two years for sexual harassment. That's out of more than 80,000 employees.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: It's clearly in response to this New York Times story that was saying Google protected three senior executives over the last 10 years, one of whom was dismissed, accused of sexual misconduct, and given a $90 million exit package.

But Sundar Pichai said in a memo that the Wall Street Journal obtained that none of those fired in the last two years got an exit package. And he said, "We're dead serious about making sure that we provide a safe and inclusive workplace." I wanted to point that out.

BARTIROMO: He didn't say something about that $90 million, as that he's walking out with $90 million.

PEEK: Yes, right, exactly.

MCDOWELL: I mean, it begs the question. But, again, 48 people out of 80,000.

BARTIROMO: Good -- yes. Good point. Let's put this in context right here. Let's talk more about what's going on this morning with Synovus Trust Portfolio Manager, Dan Morgan, joining us right now.

Dan, good to see you. Thanks very much.

DANIEL MORGAN, SENIOR MANAGER, TRUST PORTFOLIO: Hi, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Assess the backdrop for us. We're seeing revenue warnings here and technology obviously was all the way up here and it is coming down last week or so. What's going on?

MORGAN: Well, Maria, you know, the overall view of the market in terms of technology, obviously, has kind of turned negative, but we have to bear in mind these stocks have had huge runs over the last two or three years. I think it's only natural that we get a bit of a pullback.

I'm not as concerned as maybe the Street is on these most earnings -- most recent earnings report that have come out.

I get it, their revenue guidance going in the next quarter was a little bit light, but if we kind of parse through some of these businesses within the big umbrella of these companies, they actually did pretty well.

BARTIROMO: They did pretty well, but people are worried about costs going up and we're hearing the expectations that revenue estimates are too high, so they may be doing well, but are they doing well enough for what the market is expecting?

MORGAN: Well, for example, we look at Amazon, Maria, in terms of the most recent quarter, we actually saw operating profit double, you know, with 6.6 percent. They showed tremendous strength in --

BARTIROMO: Strength.

MORGAN: -- some of their, you know, newer businesses, like AWS and also other revenues, which is our advertising business.

So, yes, maybe the estimates have to come back a little bit, maybe everyone got a little too euphoric in terms of the expectations, but I don't think we're at the point now where we hit the panic button and say, "Hey, we got to get out of tech and move on. The sector's going down the tubes, like, let's say back in 2008 or 2000."

BARTIROMO: All right.

PEEK: Dan, question for you, what kind of multiples are we looking at now factoring in these assessments, reassessments of next year's prospects maybe, where is Amazon selling and where is Google selling in terms of P.E.?

MORGAN: Well, there's no doubt Amazon carries a huge multiple, as does Netflix. I mean you're looking at, you know, 150 plus times earnings.

Even if you go out to 2019, you're looking at huge multiples on Amazon. Now Google, though, is much more priced better. You're looking at probably 20 to 25 times earnings going into fiscal year '19.

So, there is some big differences between Apple and you look at Amazon or Apple versus Google and so forth. I mean, Apple trades at 15 times earnings. So --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MORGAN: -- we can't take a blanket statement and say, you know, "These stocks are all trading way too high."

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MORGAN: Yes, Netflix and Amazon are huge multiples, but Apple and Google, and some of these other players are not.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a good point, Michael.

BLOCK: Dan, I know we're talking about tech today. It's the middle of earning season. But are there other sectors you're looking to where you're steering investors towards in terms of trying to find growth?

MORGAN: Well, you know, in terms of growth for the S&P 500, as you guys have reported, I mean the third quarter is probably going to be 20 percent, you know, right now. Going forward in terms of areas that I think are interesting, like biotech, is still interesting. That's a sector that's been under the weather recently because of issues with patents and so forth.

But I think there's some good valuations there, Biogen, MGEN, and so forth. So there are other sectors away from just tech that I think are interesting.

BARTIROMO: Do you want to put money to work in this market even though things are so nervous? I mean would you buy today with a market that's likely going to open down about 200 points?

MORGAN: Well, Maria, I haven't really been buying a lot of stocks in the last three or four months to be quite honest with you, with all these new highs and trillion dollar marks with, you know, Amazon and Apple, so I'm looking for opportunities.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MORGAN: I have money on the sideline right now, Maria, I'm ready to put to work, so I'll watch these valuations that no one's going to guess the bottom, but eventually some of these stocks are going to start to really make sense again.

And I don't think the -- I don't think the backdrop has really changed. I really think we're going through correction right now that we got to be patient.

I don't think it's a time where we change the entire preface behind investing in equities at this point.

BARTIROMO: But, you know, you got a -- you got a backdrop where interest rates are going up and you do have alternatives now in the short end of fixed income, 3 percent on the two-year, do you think this is an allocation-shift going on, broadly speaking, in this market?

MORGAN: Well, Maria, if we continue to see the Federal Reserve raise rates the way that they've guided to going forward, which is going to put us at, what, two and a quarter, two and a half, on Fed funds --

BARTIROMO: Right.

MORGAN: -- going into the December meeting and then maybe two and three and quarters and three percent?

If that happens, obviously, that's got ta huge negative effect on the equity markets, but we're still OK --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MORGAN: -- I think, at this point, but anything beyond this is really going to be detrimental.

And obviously, President Trump has come out and commented on that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, all right. We will leave it there. I mean Dan says that the -- that nothing has changed in terms of the storyline, but we know that we're getting revenue misses, so --

MCDOWELL: Right. Major revenue misses.

PEEK: And --

MCDOWELL: And in terms of overall percentage of companies missing revenue, it's been growing as we moved on in the season, and this will be the biggest revenue miss overall for the S&P potentially this year so far, and expectations for the fed have been coming down for December, I wanted to point that out.

BARTIROMO: Hmm. OK. We will -- we will watch that. Dan Morgan, thank you very much.

Coming up, searching for answers this morning, Saudi Arabia now says the killing of the journalist, Jamal Khashoggi, was premeditated. The intense investigation coming next.

And then more of my exclusive interview with the Co-Founder of Oracle, Larry Ellison, also Oracle's CEO, Mark Hurd.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Markets are under pressure this morning, take a look.

The Dow Jones Industrial average expected to be down 240 points right out of the gate this morning, that's one percent lower.

The NASDAQ fairing even worst this morning. It is down two and a half percent right now. That is a decline of 175 points at the open this morning.

We want to get to the growing caravan crisis right now.

President Trump is considering blocking entry at the southern border as over a thousand migrants make their way toward the United States right now.

Griff Jenkins is at the Mexico border this morning, he's got the very latest. Griff, good morning to you.

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning.

We're about 120 miles north of the Guatemalan-Mexico border in Pijijiapan, which is a town where the migrants mostly spend the night, and you see hundreds of them marching behind me.

Let me just give you a look here, it's really quite compelling, a mother and her child making this trek. They marched early, Maria, because of the heat of the day can get so brutal. It's just very, very difficult.

But look, come with me for one second.

We'll actually ask the -- ma'am, hola. Buenas Dias. Habla Ingles?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: No.

JENKINS: No? OK. We're trying not to really bother them, but, you know, when you hear the President say -- tweeting to turn around, you hear DHS Secretary Nielsen saying that they won't be allowed in. They just won't stop from continuing their march.

In fact, we talked to a Honduran man earlier about a hour ago and he said he's coming because of the conditions in his country are the result of the Honduran president, Juan Orlando Hernandez, and they said when the President Trump says he's cutting off aid on -- to Honduras, he says, "We've never seen any of the aid anyway, it won't affect us," because of their President.

But most of them come because of the conditions, they come for work, trabajo, that's the word we keep hearing, the Spanish word for "work" and many of them will continue from here on a trek towards Tijuana.

But, Maria, where we are, it would be about 800 miles from this very point to McAllen, Texas, where we were earlier this week, but yet about twice that, about 1,600 miles, if they're going to go to Tijuana, although they typically, migrants in these caravans, like the last one in April, go to California to Tijuana because they perceive California as much more friendly to asylum-seekers and migrants than say the State of Texas.

But we have seen at least more than a thousand of migrants turn away because they've been at this since October 13th, very, very difficult conditions.

I don't have a car coming through now because those are going southbound, but as we -- see, when cars come through and come northbound, you see them hopping on any cars that they can.

We've seen little stations along this road of church groups from Mexico and others that have set up food, water, clothes, supplies, this is just one of the checkpoints just above the town of Pijijiapan as they go along.

It looks like a lot of them tell me that their destination -- today, their goal is about 80 to 100 kilometers north to a jungle of Arriaga, where they've usually gotten on a train, but we're told the trains are not running, it's been suspended for the time.

So very interesting morning, already very busy. Maria.

BARTIROMO: Wow. Incredible, Griff. We'll get back to you as news develops. Thanks so much. Griff Jenkins in Mexico this morning,

Well, the son of Jamal Khashoggi has arrived in the United States. Cheryl Casone with the details there. He had just come from Saudi Arabia, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, Maria. The eldest son of the murdered post-journalist is now in the U.S. with his family.

He'd previously been unable to leave Saudi because of Jamal Khashoggi's criticism of the Saudi government.

State department says the U.S. welcomes Saudi Arabia's decision to allow Khashoggi's son to leave the country.

Meanwhile, the Saudi government changing its story again, now saying the killing was premeditated. Saudi officials say Turkey's evidence shows that the murder was planned contradicting their earlier claim that rogue officials killed Khashoggi by mistake during a fistfight.

Well, job cuts coming to Nokia. The telecom company announcing it's launching a round of global layoffs as they gear up for fifth generation networks. No specific number has been put on these job losses, but Nokia says they are going to be part of a plan to save about 800 million a year by the end of 2020.

Shares of Nokia are higher in the premarket.

All right. We got a lot more coming up on "MORNINGS WITH MARIA".

The hunt is on, right, Maria?

BARTIROMO: Yes, they sure are. The feds are turning their focus on Florida as they search for who sent at least 10 suspicious packages to President Trump's critics. We will have that next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The search for a suspect and a motive in a string of 10 suspicious packages sent to prominent democrats.

Authorities zeroing in on Florida this morning, investigators are searching a mail facility there, they have been doing that overnight. There could be more coming out there.

Meanwhile, President Trump taking on critics of his response to the incidents tweeting this overnight. "Funny how lowly-rated CNN and others can criticize me at will, even blaming me for the current spate of bombs and ridiculously comparing this to September 11th and the Oklahoma City bombing, yet when I criticize them, they go wild and scream, 'It's just not presidential.'"

Joining us right now to talk more about that is Washington Examiner Columnist, Philip Wegmann.

Philip, good to see you. Thanks so much for being here.

PHILIP WEGMANN, COLUMNIST, WASHINGTON EXAMINER: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to all of this?

WEGMANN: Well, I think that this can be explained by President Trump's initial reaction to the bombings. He said two things, first he called for unity, and the second was that he was very angry that this attack had happened, and that explains this 3:00 a.m. tweet because presumably the President is doing everything he can to get federal agents to get to the bottom of this.

Meanwhile, he turns on CNN and looks elsewhere and sees that, you know, before we know the name of the attacker, before we know their motivation, before we have anything besides a general profile, he's being blamed.

And so I think what this is going to show us going forward is that, you know, with two weeks ahead of the elections, the President isn't going to moderate his tone and the President isn't going to entertain any arguments that he's responsible for this in any way.

BARTIROMO: And, by the way, we should point out that CNN has been criticizing this President for two years, bringing John Brennan on so that they could make these false claims about any Russia collusion, which never materialized, and there's absolutely zero evidence about it.

So, I mean, to be fair, the, you know, the media has been against this President and criticizing him, and attacking him, and not reporting any of his accomplishments for two years.

WEGMANN: Yes, to be certain, I mean, we've seen the President go to bat against this media in the past and he's been critical of them, they've been critical of him.

There's been a back and forth that hasn't been pleasant. But, you know, like, we're all professionals here, we're all adults, and we can deal with people calling us names.

I think it is a very large leap to assume that because a president is calling someone out, because he's calling out an industry and --

BARTIROMO: Right.

WEGMANN: -- I don't think that he should do it, but it's -- I think it's a leap to say that because of that rhetoric that somehow is going to incite people to violence.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

WEGMANN: I mean, I'm young, but I do remember President Obama saying, you know, that when there's a knife fight, you bring a gun, and no one was saying that, you know, President Obama was somehow responsible for any of the violence that we've seen subsequently against --

BARTIROMO: Great point. Is there any indication of what this meant for the polling as we approach the midterms? I mean any kind of sentiment read that you -- that you're aware of?

WEGMANN: Well, you know, I really expect President Obama, when he's in Wisconsin today, I think he's going to echo a lot of the rhetoric from Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer who they certainly hope that they can argue that this President, because of his tone and because of his rhetoric, has somehow inspired some of these attacks.

I haven't seen polling that has changed anything significantly yet.

BARTIROMO: Right.

WEGMANN: But I think that you're going to have a problem when you try to compare this to Oklahoma City or pin this on the right like the Clintons did during the '90's for two reasons.

First, no one was hurt, thank God, and second, it's going to be very difficult the left to lecture the right on civility when just --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WEGMANN: -- a couple of news cycles ago, you had Hillary Clinton saying that civility wasn't required.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and then you had -- or called or --

WEGMANN: You had Maxine Waters, yes.

BARTIROMO: You know, when they go low, let's just kick them.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

WEGMANN: Absolutely. Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: I want to get in real quick before you go, this fallout from the Kavanaugh Confirmation.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman, Chuck Grassley, is referring Michael Avenatti and his client, Julie Swetnick, for possible criminal prosecution. Criminal prosecution over the allegations of making false statements to Congress, because we know, Dagen, throughout this whole Kavanaugh circus, she comes out and starts calling gang rape with no --

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: With nothing to back it up.

MCDOWELL: That one NBC interview that she gave fell apart in her first breath literally.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MCDOWELL: That she couldn't even explain the timeline of why she came forward and when.

This is equal application of the law. It'll be interesting to see if the Justice Department follows through on this. Jeff Sessions has not been great at doing that in terms of going after people who say didn't show up for subpoenas in front of Congress.

If they were members, you know, associated with Hillary Clinton --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: -- this would be interesting, but this is -- again, you can't come in front of Congress and lie.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's right. And remember when Jeff Sessions first started, he said he had all these leak investigations going on. Remember that one?

PEEK: Yes. Whatever happened to that?

BARTIROMO: What happened to that?

PEEK: Good question.

MCDOWELL: I was referring to Bryan Pagliano because he didn't show up for two subpoenas in front of Jason Chaffetz's congressional committee and they wanted the Justice Department to go after him for not showing up for the subpoenas and Sessions did nothing.

BARTIROMO: We'll keep watching that because Grassley is referring Swetnick and Avenatti to the Justice Department for criminal charges.

Philip Wegmann, good to see you this morning. Thanks very much --

WEGMANN: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: -- for weighing in on all of the above.

Coming up, user-friendly no more, Snapchat's revenue blew past expectations, but look at the stock, sliding this morning over concerns about active user growth slowing down. Then, more of my exclusive interview with both Larry Ellison and Mark Hurd of Oracle, where we talk growth and opportunities. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Friday, it is Friday, October 26th, your top stories right now, 6:33 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets are selling off again this morning, we've got a serious decline underway, Dow Industrials down 228 points, that's one percent, the NASDAQ is down 152 points, that's 2-1/4 percent lower, on the NASDAQ.

Stocks under pressure amid weak results from the technology sector, particularly, Alphabet, parent of Google, and Amazon, last night, talking about weaker than expected sales.

In Europe this morning, markets down across the board, FT-100 down 1-1/2 percent, CAC Quarante in Paris, down 2-1/4 percent, DAX Index in Germany, down almost two percent. In Asia overnight, similar story, worst performer there, was Korea, down one and three quarter's percent.

One stock to watch today, Snap, the stock plunging ahead of the open, down 14 percent, Snapchat loses millions of users in the last quarter, and it does see more, leaving.

First though, a Fox Business exclusive this morning, Oracle CEO Mark Hurd and Executive Chairman Larry Ellison, sitting down for an interview side- by-side, for the first time, ever. We discussed the company's growth prospects, competition in the tech sector.

We began with this historic relationship and how they coexist and thrive, while piloting one of the world's most influential technology companies.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MARK HURD, CEO, ORACLE: We get along.

ELLISON: Yes.

HURD: We talk through a lot of things. We don't agree on everything. But, yes, we talk through them. And I think we have a great relationship.

BARTIROMO: Larry, you felt one of the greatest technologies -- most important technology companies of our time. You're still leading its direction. Tell us where you prioritize your interests, in Oracle, as you've got Mark, at the helm, as CEO?

ELLISON: Well, I think, from the very beginning at Oracle, I've ran engineering and, I guess, when I'm back, back again, running -- all of it, engineering. So, I work on our product development, whether it's database product development, the foundation of our business, or our latest and greatest Cloud applications.

BARTIROMO: So, that's where the growth is, in the whole industry today. Tell us where you find the growth stories within Oracle in the industry, what's the most exciting right now?

ELLISON: Well, in terms of growth, I mean, if you're looking at the numbers, to me, it's two separate questions, what do you think the coolest new technology is that you are working on, which might not have shown up in the numbers yet, and then, what, you know, what's showing up in the numbers. What have we been doing well for a while? So, you can actually see it through the financial results.

And that's our SAS applications. We are, by far and away, the largest provider of Cloud applications for financial accounting, for supply chain, for manufacturing. We have now 6,000 ERP customers for our Fusion suite, another 15,000 for our next suite ERP customers, financial accounting customers.

Our closest competitor claims to have a couple of hundred customers.

BARTIROMO: A couple of hundred customers.

ELLISON: Couple of hundred customers.

BARTIROMO: OK, OK. And Mark, you're seeing the ups and downs of the business in terms of running the operations, a lot of worry out there, about growth and whether it's slowing down. Are your customers wanting to transition into the Cloud? How fast are they doing that and what can you tell us about growth?

HURD: You know, going (INAUDIBLE) applications business, we've got most of our customers looking and moving to Cloud. About 10 percent of our base has actually moved their core applications to the Cloud, about another 40 percent have bought some product in the Cloud that they are using with their existing On-Premise product.

But our entire base will move to the Cloud, over the next several years, all of it.

BARTIROMO: And you made the point, that you can -- when you're -- when you're looking specifically at the applications business, you can actually transition your existing customers and double revenue in that business.

HURD: Exactly right, so just one more time, our total applications revenue, when all of our existing On-Premise customers moved to the Cloud, that revenue will double.

ELLISON: I think about starting over again, I go into Biotech. I think that's where all -- almost all the excitement is going to be, into robotics. We're seeing a tremendous amount of robotics in our specific industry. You know, we have all of this autonomous systems built in to the latest generation of our Cloud.

So, our database is completely robotic. There are no human beings involved in operating our database. Our Cloud has robotic, you know, Star Wars-like cyber defenses, where these cyber robots find security threats and kill them.

So, Clouds, modern Cloud is constantly under attack by, what are called botnets, some are state actors, some are cyber criminals, and we are building modern robotic defenses to protect our customers' data.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible. I want to go back to what you said about Biotech, but to touch on what you just said, you made the point in your keynote, earlier this week, that the approach Amazon and AWS has taken, it means it runs AWS Cloud control code on the same machines that it actually stores the corporate data, possibly leaving that data, vulnerable. Can you tell us more about that?

ELLISON: Not possibly. I mean, we've seen headlines, you know, cyber break-ins at Google, at Facebook and Amazon, big government agencies. It is happening because these architectures, these old Cloud architectures really were designed for security, security was an afterthought.

We have separated our Cloud control code and put it in a network of computers that are entirely separate from the computers we rent to customers. Amazon, if a customer comes in and rents a computer from Amazon, in that same computer, is Amazon code.

That means, that customer, if they're smart, can hack the Amazon code, take control of that computer, and then go out to other computers in the Amazon Cloud, and steal data.

That is impossible to do with the architecture we have, in our Generation 2 Cloud, where user computers, customer computers, only has customer code in it. And our control or security computers are Cloud control computers has only our code in it. There is no way a customer can get at our Cloud control code, hack it, and take control of the Cloud.

BARTIROMO: And this confirms the idea of what you've been talking about, for years, and that is staying with one integrated company which is away from the open public Cloud. Is that right?

ELLISON: No. I mean, our Cloud -- our Cloud is available on the internet. So, I mean, you come in on the internet, and you can use our SAS applications, you can use our database, you can use all of that. So, it is completely -- it's not a walled garden.

Every -- all of our customers can get -- can get at our Clouds, very easy to do, in fact, getting at our Cloud and getting at Amazon's Cloud, looks kind of the same. The difference is, if you take, you know, if you look very closely, you'll see, we give customers a set of computers that they can rent, just like Amazon does.

We have our control code, the code that controls the Cloud, and that's on a completely separate set of computers. We would never let our control code, you know, be in the same computer as our customers' code, because the customer might be someone you don't know from the Ukraine, who is really, really smart, hacks your code.

And then, has able to, you know, hacks your control code, and is able to take over that computer or take over a big chunk of the Cloud.

So, it's just as easy to access our Cloud, as to access the Amazon Cloud. But when you access our code -- Cloud, you are -- we create this impenetrable barrier around our users, so they can't get through. You know what? They can't get through to our Cloud control code, which is on a completely separate network of Cloud control computers.

Amazon does not have a separate network of Cloud controlled computers. They share the same computer. That's a terrible security vulnerability.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BLOCK: You know, the last time we didn't mention explicitly here is that exports were down 3.5 percent in Q3 and imports rose at 9.1 percent. It just plays into this whole rising deficit thing. Look, I don't think the bottom market cares but it's part of it.

MCDOWELL: But we -- but we would know that watching these trade deficit numbers coming in, in the third quarter, Jon, that the trade deficit has widened throughout the third quarter. Again, there were some pull forward in the second quarter where you had, say, soybeans exporters really pushing inventory overseas ahead of those tariffs between the United States and China that went into place over the summer, so, again, that reversed course and showed up in this GDP figure.

HILSENRATH: That's exactly right, Dagen, you have to look at what happened with trade in the second and third quarter combined, there was a lot of anticipatory reaction in the second quarter, particularly in agricultural goods, and that looks like it reversed. But, you know, with the tariffs that we have going on, we have to think about trade being a potential drag for the economy -- for the global economy in the months ahead.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And that's what we were -- we're also expecting companies to start pulling back as we have seen in this report, because of the uncertainty of it. You know, what will the impact of these tariffs be in this quarter and into 2019? That's one reason that you --

PEEK: That's a little ironic, right? I mean, basically, under Obama, the uncertainty all had to do with regulation and changes that the business community faced day-to-day, now it is so unfortunate that we have that deregulatory cloud sort of lifting, but in its place, we have uncertainty about the tariff policies.

MCDOWELL: Well, we switched -- we switched from one form of government swappiness to another.

PEEK: Yes, that's true.

MCDOWELL: That it's government intervention in business, where if you use steel in this country, you have to go to the Commerce Department hat in hand and beg for waivers.

PEEK: That's right.

MCDOWELL: There have been thousands of waivers.

BLOCK: And there is a huge backlog at the Commerce Department right now for these applications for waivers.

MCDOWELL: That's right.

HILSENRATH: So, there is a lot of red tape on the trade front.

BARTIROMO: Yes, all right, Jon, we leave it there. Great to see you this morning, Jon, thanks so much.

HILSENRATH: Great. Thanks a lot.

BARTIROMO: Great analysis, as always, from Jon Hilsenrath from The Wall Street Journal. Once again, the GDP is out, this is the first reading of the third quarter, it came in better-than-expected, up 3.5 percent versus an estimate of 3.3 percent.

Coming up next, Microsoft on track to pass Amazon in market cap after earnings. We will tell you where that market cap stands. We break down the latest numbers right after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We told you the breaking news earlier. The GDP out moments ago. The economy grew at a -- at a rate of 3-1/2 percent in the third quarter. This is the first take on the third quarter. GDP is better than the expectation which calls for 3.3 percent.

Futures came off of their lows, then, went back down again. We're still looking at a decline at the start of trading, although, we are off of the lows. Dow Industrials down 160 points, NASDAQ down 116.

"VARNEY & COMPANY" host, Stuart Varney weighs in. And Stu, what I think is really a good takeaway is the fact that the consumer part of this report --

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- consumer spending up four percent, Stu.

VARNEY: Yes, the -- what is it? Consumption, that's the proper (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: That's right.

VARNEY: Consumption of, what, four percent. Now, that's a big number. That is a very bright spot in this report. You know, Maria, I was the party pooper about the Mega Million jackpot.

BARTIROMO: I know you are.

VARNEY: Well, I'm not -- I thought I might be the party pooper over GDP because I was really hoping for a four percent number as growth in that quarter. OK, so, we got 3-1/2 percent. I still think that's pretty good. I'm a little disappointed because I was looking for four and more, because that's what we've been promised if we get the tax cut. But, look, I'll take 3.5 percent, especially coming on the back of a 4.2 percent growth rate in the second quarter. That's the best back-to-back quarter performance that we've seen in four years.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: So, the trend is still very strong and if we keep this up, we're going to have a much better than three percent gain for the full calendar year, 2018. I'll take it, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I'll take it. And let's not forget that the second quarter that you just mentioned, 4.3 percent, no revision there, Stu.

VARNEY: Right.

BARTIROMO: Right? So, we still got the 4.2 percent in the second quarter and now, 3-1/2 percent for the third quarter. I know you're going to dig deep into these numbers in about 10 minutes. We will see you top of the hour.

VARNEY: You got it, Maria. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Stu. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour, 9:00 Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join Stuart and his great team there.

First, though, Microsoft makes a move, the technology giant now on track to pass Amazon's market cap. We've got those numbers. Microsoft's shares today down two percent, Amazon down eight percent. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We have breaking news right now. An 11th suspicious package has been found. This one from an Opa-locka, Florida facility. The FBI is confirming that this package was addressed to New Jersey Senator, Cory Booker. This is an 11th package coming out of the Florida facility and we are following that and other things this morning. We'll bring you the latest there.

Meanwhile, we want to look at market, we've got technology earnings have been leading this market sell-off, disappointing revenue numbers last night from a number of high-profile companies.

Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange right now with those details. Nic, good morning to you.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, good morning, Maria. So, we're off of the lows of the morning on that better-than-expected GDP number. But we're looking at Amazon which had that revenue miss and the guidance on revenue, obviously, less than expected. So, some concerns potentially about the holiday season, that's one thing, but the other areas, such as cloud and advertising units continue to grow, have been the area of growth. And you've had a mixed bag, some analysts actually raising their target, some pulling back, and some that are raising still like the long-term growth story on Amazon. And those FANG stocks are up 37 percent annually over the last -- since 2014.

By the way, as Amazon pulls back, we might see Microsoft move higher in that closer to the trillion-dollar market. Remember when Apple crossed it, didn't close there, but Microsoft now may be getting closer, may surpass Amazon today with Amazon sell-offs. So, we'll watch for the market cap battle.

And then, there's Alphabet, Google. The one area that people were concerned about is people are looking to Amazon to search for products instead of Google. So, we've seen, obviously, they've had surging profit with the slower sales growth. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Nic. Thank you so much. And of course, it's been an incredibly volatile and busy week for stocks. We had a really busy week on this program as well. Take a look at some of the top moments with the program.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE) business with the Pentagon. Amazon wants it, too, but Google walks away from the business with the DOD, and yet, they are all-in on going into China.

LARRY ELLISON, CO-FOUNDER AND EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, ORACLE: I hear Jeff Bezos and I absolutely agree. I think U.S. tech companies who say we will not -- we will not support the U.S. military. You know, we will not -- we will not work on any technology that helps our military. But yet, goes into China and facilitates the Chinese government, surveilling their people, is pretty shocking.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is Larry.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hey, the Oracle of Oracle. What a pleasure. Nice to see you.

BARTIROMO: Tony Stark, I -- did you influence that character?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I've heard that. I didn't know Stanley is (INAUDIBLE) so I guess -- I guess Tony Stark was invented before (INAUDIBLE) so, I guess no.

KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSELOR TO PRESIDENT TRUMP: Part of why the President would like to continue cut tax with the middle class is because it has gone so well. He sees the fruits of that tax cut and jobs act which passed last December without a single Democratic vote.

BARTIROMO: This can't possibly happen before the midterms. The midterms are 13 days away and this has to be voted on and Congress is -- the House is not even in session.

CONWAY: Well, Washington moves a little bit too slowly for the sheer volume and velocity of the Trump agenda.

REP. CHUCK FLEISCHMANN (R), TENNESSEE: Obviously, it was so important to get tax reform passed. We got no help from the Democrats. That's actually very sad, and I think that's going to hurt them in the midterms.

MARK PENN, FORMER ADVISOR TO THE CLINTONS: I've seen the biggest buildup and turnout to a midterm election that we've ever seen, which classically has fairly low turnout. And I think we've seen the blue wave become a blue edge, now, I think fairly it's a blue tossup.

MERCEDES SCHLAPP, WHITE HOUSE SENIOR ADVISOR FOR STRATEGIC COMMUNICATIONS: President Trump has been talking to the -- to Saudi Arabia, to the King, as well as to the Crown Prince. There's a continual dialogue there. Our eyes are wide-open when it comes to what we've seen to be this horrific tragedy.

GEN. JACK KEANE (RET.), FOX NEWS SENIOR STRATEGIC ANALYST: If he's found to have his fingers on this in any way, I think he is likely to be removed by his -- by his father.

LT. COL. ALLEN WEST (RET.), U.S. ARMY: This is in complete violation of human rights. We cannot continue to allow this to happen.

BARTIROMO: The migrant caravan from Honduras has swelled to at least 7,000 people now as it makes its way north.

KEANE: We've got to protect our borders, and we have got to protect our sovereignty.

FLEISCHMANN: We're seeing by virtue of this caravan right now just how chaotic and really anarchistic the border situation has become.

BARTIROMO: Violence and intimidation now on both sides of the aisle.

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA), HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER: Individual through a great big boulder through -- entered the office and another person entered as well, and they stole equipment. The one thing about America we believe in civil discourse. I mean, you could -- you could agree -- disagree with someone and not be disagreeable, but then now it's in your face.

WEST: We should not be politicizing political terrorism or violence such as this. And I would say to those people that are seeking to do so, you know, this is a crazy unhinged individual, this is not acceptable.

BARTIROMO: Impact of Iran sanctions within two weeks, your view.

STEPHEN SCHORK, PUBLISHER, THE SCHORK REPORT: We've had five months to digest this Iranian news. This Iranian news is already priced into the market. The market has shown us over the summer that it's capable of handling the current situation.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Maria. I didn't win the Mega Millions this morning, so here I am joining you from (INAUDIBLE) from New York.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I haven't checked my numbers yet, but since I didn't buy a ticket, I'm probably not going to win, that's my guess.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Hi, welcome back. Final thoughts from this all-star panel. Liz Peek?

PEEK: Well, I don't think that the GDP report did much for the markets, but let's -- if the market doesn't completely tank today, I think we're going to be in a rebuilding phase next week.

BARTIROMO: Still a good number, 3-1/2 percent growth --

(CROSSTALK)

PEEK: Yes, it definitely was. And teas up the fourth quarter pretty well.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

BLOCK: Yes, personal consumption was good, investment is challenged, trade is challenged. Let's see what happens after midterms. And longer-term, I'm going to be -- I'm going to stay optimistic.

BARTIROMO: Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Well, that's unusual. And I will be, too. So, we have about half of the S&P 500 is still yet to report, so let's hope for better revenue.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right. See the glass half full. There you go. Seize the day, everybody. Have a great weekend, Dagen McDowell, Michael Block, and Liz Peek, good to see you. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins now. Stuart, take it away.

END
