urn:contentItem:5XFR-FBG1-DXH2-62M7-00000-00President Trump Distracted by Heating Impeachment Process; No Answers Yet for Nine People Murdered; Turkey Taking Down Members of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi's Family; American Made Weapons Funneled into Yemen. Aired 2-3a ET2019-11-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:28ZLexisNexisCNN NEWSROOM2:00 AM ESTLinda FeldmannINTERNATIONAL110719CN.V11President Trump Distracted by Heating Impeachment Process; No Answers Yet for Nine People Murdered; Turkey Taking Down Members of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi's Family; American Made Weapons Funneled into Yemen. Aired 2-3a ETRosemary Church, Kaitlan Collins, Bianca Nobilo, Rosa Flores, Derek Van Dam, Sherisse Pham, Jeanne Moos

Donald Trump takes aim at Democratic leaders as new details emerged about White House request to Ukraine; Funerals are to be held for the nine victims of a massacre in Mexico, three women and six children, all members of the same Mormon family; Turkey's president says they've captured one of the wives of the late ISIS leader and this comes as soon after his sister, her husband and daughter-in-law were caught; CNN obtained exclusive new video of key U.S. allies secretly funneling U.S. made weapons into Yemen

[02:00:00]

(MUSIC PLAYING)

ROSEMARY CHURCH, CNN ANCHOR (voice-over): Hello and welcome to our viewers joining us from all around the world, I'm Rosemary Church and this is CNN NEWSROOM.

Coming up, the top diplomat in Ukraine told lawmakers about a quid pro quo with Ukraine and in less than a week he and other officials will testify in public.

In the U.K. the election campaign is off to an urgent start and Brexit is on the line.

Also ahead, Mexican authorities intensify the hunt for the people behind the brutal attack on an American family. We are learning about the tiny survivors and some incredible acts of bravery.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: She had saved her baby by pulling it off the seat and tucking it down on the floor and she covered her baby up with a blanket.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(MUSIC PLAYING)

CHURCH: Democrats in the U.S. House of Representatives are just about ready to take their impeachment case against Donald Trump to the American public. Intelligence Committee chairman Adam Schiff says televised public hearings will begin Wednesday.

The testimony will mark a new phase in the inquiry, as Democrats try to prove the president abused to his power by withholding military aid from Ukraine in exchange for an investigation of his political rival, Joe Biden. CNN's Phil Mattingly has more now on what to expect.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN U.S. CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT: When you look at the big picture of what we're going to see next week, Democrats are going to attempt to paint a picture of a U.S. foreign policy that was essentially operated through rogue channels, outside the traditional way foreign policy is run, with a heavy emphasis on Rudolph Giuliani, the personal attorney for the president and an acknowledgment that, based on what they are seeing, they believe they already have enough evidence for an impeachable offense.

You're also going to see Republicans make very clear some of the defenses we have seen over the last couple of days, that they don't believe any of the witnesses, no matter how damning their testimony, have a direct link to President Trump.

There will be a lot of that as we look forward, but bigger than anything else, Wolf, this is spilling into the public sphere, which means, more than anything, while impeachment is obviously part of what Congress has in its set of duties, it is also very much a public sentiment type of exercise.

You talk to Republicans and Democrats, they acknowledge that fact, the public hearings a real opportunity to start to sway public opinion, which has largely broken down on partisan lines, into their favor as they move forward in this process.

And also worth noting, the public hearings making clear this is moving forward and it's moving forward quickly. After those public hearings, likely a full report. Then it gets kicked over the Judiciary Committee. Those articles of impeachment will come and then a House vote before it moves to the Senate. Very clear Democrats are moving forward and moving forward fast.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CHURCH: CNN's Phil Mattingly reporting there.

The first witness to testify in public will be the top U.S. diplomat in Ukraine, Bill Taylor. We have a preview of what he'll say on Wednesday. CNN's Alex Marquardt has the details.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ALEX MARQUARDT, CNN SENIOR NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT (voice- over): It's among the most explosive testimonies yet in the impeachment inquiry. Now the transcript of the deposition of Ambassador Bill Taylor, the most senior U.S. diplomat in Ukraine, gives a damning on-the-ground perspective.

[02:05:00]

MARQUARDT (voice-over): Taylor told lawmakers it was his clear understanding security assistance money would not come until Ukrainian President Zelensky committed to pursue the investigation, meaning into the Bidens and the 2016 election.

Taylor added, "It was also clear that this condition was driven by the irregular policy channel I had come to understand was guided by Rudy Giuliani." It was also Giuliani, according to Taylor, who came up with the idea of demanding that President Zelensky publicly declare he would investigate the Ukrainian company Burisma that Joe Biden's son Hunter had been on the board of.

REP. ADAM SCHIFF (D-CA), CHAIR, HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: I think you will see in the transcript what a dedicated public servant Ambassador Taylor is, someone who graduated from West Point, someone who served in Vietnam, someone who is, I think, performing another vital service for the country in relating the facts that came to his attention.

MARQUARDT: Taylor testified that he was told about a meeting on September 1 between the U.S. ambassador to the European Union, Gordon Sondland and a top aide to President Zelensky, in which Sondland told the aide: "The security assistance money would not come until President Zelensky committed to pursue the Burisma investigation. Everything was dependent on such an announcement."

Days prior, Taylor had written a rare so-called first-person cable to his boss, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, "describing the folly I saw in withholding military aid to Ukraine at a time when hostilities were still active in the east and when Russia was watching closely to gauge the level of American support for the Ukrainian government."

Taylor was embarrassed he couldn't tell the Ukrainians why the aid was being held up and he prepared to resign. Despite these concerns, Taylor admitted he had never talked to the president.

MARQUARDT: Taylor's testimony is full of references to what Giuliani activists said the Ukrainian officials listen to him because they knew that he was working at the president's direction.

We've also learned that Giuliani has hired himself a team of lawyers tweeting up the names of three of them to the any clearly feeling the heat at this inquiry ramps up -- Alex Marquardt, CNN, Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CHURCH: Mr. Trump isn't saying much about the growing list of witnesses who accused him of a quid pro quo with Ukraine. He has called some of them "never Trumpers" but he is being more focused on demanding that the original whistleblower's identity be revealed.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The whistleblower, before they knew I was going to release, he came out with a whistleblower. You know, like he's some wonderful person. Take a look at the whistleblower. But the whistleblower came out with this horrible statement about this call. So I really had no choice. I said immediately, talk about transparency. I said release it. Release it immediately.

And then the whistleblower saw it and Shifty Schiff saw it, is a total crook, Schiff saw it, Pelosi saw it and they said, we got a problem. We don't want to have anything to do with the whistleblower anymore. And the whistleblower disappeared.

You know who else disappeared?

The second whistleblower.

And you know who else disappeared?

The informer to the whistleblower, if there was such a person, which I doubt.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHURCH: Donald Trump reportedly wanted the U.S. attorney general William Barr to hold a news conference, declaring the president did not break any laws in his phone calls with Ukraine's leader. That is according to "The New York Times" and "The Washington Post."

Barr declined the request. President Trump calls these stories "fake news" and the U.S. Justice Department did not respond to CNN's request for comment.

So let's talk more about all of this with Linda Feldmann. She is the Washington bureau chief for "The Christian Science Monitor."

Thanks for joining us.

LINDA FELDMANN, WASHINGTON BUREAU CHIEF, "THE CHRISTIAN SCIENCE MONITOR": Hi, my pleasure.

CHURCH: So the publicly released testimony of top U.S. diplomat Bill Taylor confirms not only the existence of a quid pro quo of military aid for Ukraine in exchange for an investigation into the president's political rival but also the second quid pro quo involving a meeting at the White House for Ukraine's president.

Is this the most significant of all testimony so far and where does this take the impeachment inquiry do you think?

FELDMANN: I think it is the most significant not only because of what Bill Taylor is saying but also because of who he is. He is a career diplomat highly respected, was the acting U.S. ambassador in Ukraine. Has no political connections to the president and therefore he brings a lot of credibility to the table.

CHURCH: And Taylor's testimony like others puts the president's personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, once again right at the center of the Ukraine quid pro quo. What might that reveal about Trump's role in all of this do you think?

FELDMANN: Well, that's an interesting question because by having it all go through Rudy Giuliani it insulates Donald Trump just a little bit. It doesn't prove that Donald Trump wasn't behind all of this but it doesn't go directly to the president.

But given that Donald Trump has said and told people go to -- go to Rudy on this, one can assume but you know, it's just sort of part of this whole larger scene of a shadow foreign policy run by the president's professional lawyer which completely bypasses the formal foreign policy structures of Washington. And it made a lot of people nervous here and it's not illegal.

I mean, this sounds kind of devious undoubtedly but in fact, the president has a lot of leeway in how he conducts foreign policy and even if it doesn't look good, it's that in of itself isn't illegal.

CHURCH: Right. And Democrats announced Wednesday they planned to hold public impeachment hearings next Wednesday and Taylor will be the first to testify signaling the significance of all of this.

[02:10:00]

(END VIDEO CLIP)

[02:55:10]

CHURCH: A salute to Australia. And the gender pay gap is a burning issue in sports, of course. In March, the U.S. women's football team filed a discrimination lawsuit against the U.S. Soccer Federation arguing that they get paid less than men for substantially equal work.

The American women won their fourth World Cup this year, the U.S. men are still searching for their first title.

Well, it's hard to remember all the twists and turns of the Ukraine controversy, right? Well, at least, that's what the U.S. ambassador to the European Union is claiming. Gordon Sondland, now recalls. He delivered a quid pro quo arrangement to Ukrainian officials. And that's something he seems to have forgotten when he first testified.

As CNN's Jeanne Moos reports, the late-night comedy shows are having a memorable time with all of this.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JEANNE MOOS, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: If only we could all have what he's having, the Gordon Sondland memory cure.

JIMMY KIMMEL, HOST, NBC: And he claims his memory was refreshed.

MOOS: Voices dripped with skepticism.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: And he now remembers or mended. That's right, corrected.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: On Sondland's revision.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: All of a sudden now he remembers this? What's going on?

WHOOPI GOLDBERG, HOST, ABC: What do you think jogged his memory?

MOOS: Jail was the number one answer. "The idea of using a stainless-steel toilet every day does wonders to improve the memory." KIMMEL: Maybe he started taking those omega-3 supplements (INAUDIBLE). They say those are very effective against perjury. So --

MOOS: In his updated declarations, Sondland use terms like "refreshed my recollection" and "I now do recall".

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is quite a refresh of your memory.

MOOS: Equally refreshing were the snarky headlines. "Oh, that pro quo, yes, now I remember."

Someone demonstrated the exact moment. His memory was refreshed. There was a reference to a Tommy Lee Jones line from The Fugitive.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Can you revise your statement, sir?

TOMMY LEE JONES, ACTOR AND FILMMAKER: What?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Do you want to change your -- story, sir?

MOOS: Ambassador Sondland denied changing anything.

GORDON SONDLAND, UNITED STATES AMBASSADOR TO THE EUROPEAN UNION: I didn't change my testimony but I can't answer any questions.

MOOS: He was chased by a couple of protesters down an escalator at Portland International Airport.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Hey, Gordon Sondland, tell the truth.

MOOS: Gordon Sondland had a Barbra Streisand moment when he refreshed all of those --

BARBRA STREISAND, AMERICAN SINGER: Misty water-colored memories.

MOOS: Of the way his testimony was. Jeanne Moos, CNN.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Memory --

MOOS: New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CHURCH: I'm Rosemary Church, and I'll be back with more news in just a moment. You're watching CNN. Do stick around.

[03:00:00]

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TWG-6RM1-JBHT-D060-00000-00President Trump Eager To Get His Border Wall Budget Or Choose A Government Shut Down; Big Tech Companies Accused of Selling User Data To Third Parties; President Trump Cancels His Meeting With Russian President Vladimir Putin At The G20 Summit Over The Russia-Ukraine Tensions; Possible Tax Break Could Be Given To General Motors To Save Thousands Of Jobs; Louie Gohmert On How A Former Federal Trade Commission Official Claimed That A Facebook Official Made False Statements To International Leaders; Homeland Security Has Estimated There Are Hundreds Of Criminals In The Migrant Caravan; President Trump Blasting At His Former Personal Attorney, Michael Cohen; Dems Get Tough On Immigration; John Kerry Says Europe Crushed Under Impact Of Mass Immigration2018-11-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:28ZLexisNexisPresident Trump Eager To Get His Border Wall Budget Or Choose A Government Shut Down; Big Tech Companies Accused of Selling User Data To Third Parties; President Trump Cancels His Meeting With Russian President Vladimir Putin At The G20 Summit Over The Russia-Ukraine Tensions; Possible Tax Break Could Be Given To General Motors To Save Thousands Of Jobs; Louie Gohmert On How A Former Federal Trade Commission Official Claimed That A Facebook Official Made False Statements To International Leaders; Homeland Security Has Estimated There Are Hundreds Of Criminals In The Migrant Caravan; President Trump Blasting At His Former Personal Attorney, Michael Cohen; Dems Get Tough On Immigration; John Kerry Says Europe Crushed Under Impact Of Mass ImmigrationLanhamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Our Democratic colleagues seem to come up with a lot of criticism, but have no answer.

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER, (D) NEW YORK: If there's any shutdown, it's on President Trump's back.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: They look at what's happening in Tijuana but they don't see the bigger picture which is the drug cartels and the transnational criminal organizations.

SCHUMER: Stick to the 1.6 billion.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If we don't get border security, a possible shutdown.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: It's coming down to the wire over a key Trump campaign promise. The president is gearing up for this fight when he gets back from the G20. Build that wall.

We've got two top legislators with an inside look on the race to get it funded before the Democrats take over the House.

Plus, new disturbing details on what's going on at the border. And you won't believe this. Top Democrats all of a sudden sounding tough on immigration. They're doing a 180. And it's not just Hillary Clinton. It is a potential 2020 Democrat contender. He is even citing Europe as a warning. We're going to tell you who it is and you won't believe it.

And still more trouble ahead for Facebook and Google. Breaking news on that front for you tonight. And it will make you ask why does it always seem like billionaire Mark Zuckerberg says one thing in public but does another thing behind our backs.

We have attorney and Silicon Valley critic Harmeet Dhillon on that. Also, Gregg Jarrett will take on the media hysteria and get to the facts on that Michael Cohen guilty plea today. No smoking gun yet.

Well, thank you so much for joining us. Thank you for watching. Money, politics, we're going to bring you the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. The Evening Edit starts right now.

First up, President Trump standing tough. Canceling a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin at the G20 summit, citing the Ukraine conflict. And separate from that, the president says he does think China wants to make a trade deal.

Blake Burman is live at the G20 in Buenos Aires. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, there, Liz. President Trump steps the land here in Buenos Aires, Argentina within the next two to three hours. After that it's a couple days' worth of meeting with a handful of world leaders culminating Saturday evening a dinner sit-down with the Chinese President Xi Jinping to talk about several topics none more important than trade.

The president, though, when he left the White House to come to Argentina earlier this morning cast some doubt though, on whether or not there would be a breakthrough as it relates to a possible trade deal.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I think we are very close to doing something with China. But I don't know that it wants to do it. Because what we have right now is billions and billions of dollars coming into the United States in the form of tariffs or taxes. So, I really don't know.

But I will tell you that I think China wants to make a deal. I'm open to making a deal. But frankly, I like the deal we have right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: The president will not be meeting with Vladimir Putin. President Trump canceled that meeting via Twitter on board Air Force One after being briefed by his Chief of Staff, John Kelly, the Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, and his National Security Advisor, John Bolton about Russia's recent aggressive action against Ukraine in the waters of Crimea.

The State Department today defending that decision.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERT PALLADINO, DEPUTY SPOKESMAN, STATE DEPARTMENT: What's clear is, the president's tweets on the subject were quite clear what we looked for. And that is the return of the Ukrainian sailors and the vessels.

The aggression that we witnessed this week is unacceptable, and a strong message has been sent.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: A spokesperson for the Kremlin said that they were not made aware of the president's tweet, the president's decision before he signed off on that tweet. Saying in a statement earlier today, quote, "If this is so, the president will have a couple, speaking of Putin, a couple of additional hours on the program for useful meetings on the sidelines of the summit." Liz?

MACDONALD: Great to see you, Blake. And Rudy Giuliani and President Trump's lawyers are now slamming the decision to file charges against Michael Cohen during this G20 trip.

Let's get to the border. President Trump declaring, quote, "a very possible government shutdown if we don't get the wall money."

This, as the U.S. officials saying no criminal charges have been filed against the 42 migrants who were arrested for illegally crossing the border during that caravan protest that ended in tear gas. He says the press reports charges were not filed because the accused had things like medical problems or issues with having children alongside them. Or they are accompanying.

And there is an issue on whether or not they were actually deported. We are staying to getting the facts of that story.

Let's bring in Republican Texas Congressman Michael Burgess. Great to see you, sir.

REP. MICHAEL BURGESS, (R) TEXAS: Thanks for having me on, Liz. I appreciate it.

MACDONALD: What is the holdup in Congress over getting money for the border wall?

BURGESS: Well, the deadline is the 7th of December. There was a continuing resolution passed at the end of September that gave us until December. It is possible that there will be required another very short-term extension. But I believe that an agreement can be reached and I believe the president needs to get the money for the wall that he's asked.

We all saw last weekend the images of people coming to the fence, literally coming through the fence. The fence is not secure. The infrastructure needs to exist to secure the border and the president is exactly correct. And he needs to get the money to do the job.

MACDONALD: Yes, our border authority says a border wall would help them back them up in their efforts at the border. You make an important point. Now the president -- this is a story that's coming fast next week. He is saying he will shut down the government. Do you think a deal can get done here, sir?

BURGESS: Well, the actual -- the actual mechanics of a government shutdown would come from the lapse of appropriations if an agreement can't be reached on the 7th or if there is indeed a short-term extension of whatever point after that.

So, it's not actually an action by the White House that shuts the government down. It would be failure to reach an agreement an appropriation lapse that occurs in homeland security.

Do bear in mind that a number of the appropriations bills did pass by September. So, unlike in 2013 when a similar situation existed, the United States military has been funded.

MACCALLUM: Right.

BURGESS: The Department of Health and Human Services had been funded. So, there are significant funding bills that have already passed. Homeland security is one of the ones that remains, it needs to be done. The president needs to get his money.

MACDONALD: Yes. Sir, it will be a partial shutdown. I hear what you are saying. So, what do you in -- what dollar figure do you have in your mind that you think is the correct number?

BURGESS: Well, the president has said he needs $25 billion to build the wall and that this year a $5 billion installment is what is required. I believe that is correct. And that is -- that's what the Congress should provide the president. I think that the votes are there on the House side to get that done.

The difficulty is always on the Senate side with a 60-vote, a 60-vote margin that's required. This is one of those times that I believe that the Senate majority leader should forgo the 60-vote rule and just simply pass the bill with 51 votes. This is too important. It needs to protect--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Can he do that? Can he--

BURGESS: Yes.

MACDONALD: Under on what grounds?

BURGESS: Well, it happened before and in fact, it happened of course with the Supreme Court Justice Gorsuch. Where they suspended the 60-vote rule of this. That obviously we challenge on that. But he sustained some of the simple majority.

So, there would also be the possibility of doing another quick reconciliation bill that would only require 51 votes to pass. So, there are avenues to get this done. It is unconscionable that the Senate leader on the Democratic side would shut down the government because he doesn't want to defend our southern border.

MACDONALD: Congressman Burgess, thank you so much. We'll have you back on again soon, sir.

BURGESS: Great.

MACDONALD: Great to see you.

BURGESS: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Thanks again.

Bill and Hillary Clinton on their 13-city speaking tour. Now in -- they were in Montreal. Bill Clinton saying America should be more like Canada when it comes to the border security there.

To National Diversity Coalition for Trump, Madison Gesiotto. Madison, great to see you.

MADISON GESIOTTO, MEMBER, NATIONAL DIVERSITY COALITION FOR TRUMP: Good to be with you, Liz.

MACDONALD: You know, Madison, Bill Clinton he likes Canada's system for immigration. Doesn't Canada have a merit-based immigration system which Trump says the U.S. should do? It sounds like he may be agreeing with him on that front.

GESIOTTO: Yes, Canada does have a partially merit-based system. But the one thing to note about Canada is that I think the majority are close to 50 percent of their immigrants that come in don't come on the merit-based system. They come in other pathways. So, their pathways are still open in Canada and a lot of immigrants have come through that way.

But when it comes to merit-based, the president has been pushing that. He thinks it's a great, of great option and will be a wonderful policy for our country. And I think it very much mirrors and goes back to what President John F. Kennedy said in his 1961 address which we all have heard so many times. Ask not what your country can do for you. Ask what you can do for your country.

And I think that's what the heart of this policy really is, and why the president has been pushing for that. What can these immigrants do to produce the United States of America to make our country better.

MACDONALD: You know, Democrats in 2013 were for what President Trump is now saying, right? It was Chuck Schumer who signed off on it. Dozens of other Democrats. Obama supported merit-based systems, so did Joe Biden.

You know, Madison, it's pretty striking for Bill Clinton to say what he's saying now about Canada, you know, having a good system. Because Clinton was the one who signed in 1996 the toughest immigration reform bill that is still with us today. It essentially invented the immigration enforcement and increased deportations, right?

GESIOTTO: Well, I think over the years it's been bipartisan in terms of support for securing our borders and to making sure that we improve our immigration system but the problem was no one ever came to an agreement on what to get done.

Now President Trump is in office and people hate for this president, really has, you know, overcome their desire to get things done for the American people and to make our system better. They know. They know that it's broken. They know we need to get things done. But they really would prefer to go against and obstruct the agenda of President Trump, then they want to accomplish this.

And so, I think a lot of them are backtracking and really flipflopping on this issue. And as you know, it's not just 2013, it's not just the 1990's. There's been many cases over the past 20 or 30 years where a lot of these Democrats still in Congress today have supported man of the things President Trump and his administration are talking about now.

MACDONALD: Yes. Madison, you are an astute observer of what's going on in the media and how the media covers things. Tell us what happened over the last five years. Because all of a sudden, you know, the media and their coverage, critics are saying there is kind of a 180 in perspective on what is needed to do border security. This was as of five years ago. There was very tough, tough coverage. And now, all of a sudden, it's open borders. That's how it feels.

GESIOTTO: Yes. I mean, and I think when we look at the media coverage of this issue specifically, it's actually quite appalling. Journalism is so very important. Making sure that we have people out there being fair and covering the facts are so important. And it's not happening.

People are letting their personal biases come into their stories. And they're not reporting the facts. So, people out there that are watching the mainstream media or reading articles online aren't getting the information that they are here to receive and that's very disappointing. And I hope that we can turn things around. Because I want fair coverage even if it's not always what I want to hear.

MACDONALD: Yes. Madison Gesiotto, you're great. Thank you so much for joining us. We really appreciate it.

GESIOTTO: Thanks, Liz.

MACDONALD: Let's get to a market check of your money. The Dow closing slightly lower today. But the blue chip index is on pace for it best week since the 2016 election.

To prices at the pump. The national average for regular gas is $2.51 a gallon. That is down 50 days straight. That's money in your pocket. And 21 states now have gas stations selling gas for less than $2 a gallon and that trend is growing.

In other headlines. New information about that murderous Boston mobster Whitey Bulger. Bulger reportedly wrote to a friend that he hoped to die peacefully in his sleep. Those letters sent right before he was brutally murdered in prison.

Manhattan U.S. attorney announcing a new distribution of more than $695 million to the victims of Bernie Madoff's Ponzi scheme. It is the third payout, it will be sent to 27,000 victims worldwide. Bernie Madoff sentenced to 150 years in prison.

Now in honor of the 50th anniversary -- anniversary of the Beatles white album the hash tag Beatles songs for millennial's on fire today trending worldwide on Twitter. Look at this. Tweeters including millennials are rewriting the titles of famous Beatles songs, it's all about poking fun at millennials.

Look these titles. Strawberry field. Whatever. I get by with a little help from my parents while my iPhone gently tweets. It's pretty funny stuff.

And look at this cute video. A 6-year-old boy upstages Pope Francis during the post weekly speech. The young boy ran on stage, he shook the hand of a security guard along the way. He got a lot of laughs at the pope. The pope let the child continue to play around them. And that was totally cute.

Coming up, President Trump still going after General Motors. The president saying, he is just trying to protect American jobs. We got the mayor of one Ohio town at the center of this fight. He is now fearing economic disaster right before Christmas, but we've got breaking details on something we were first in telling you could be coming. Possible tax race to keep those G.M. jobs.

We're going to be right back. Stay there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. President Trump again slamming General Motors on twitter saying quote. "G.M. is very counter to what other auto and other companies are doing big steel opening plants all over the country, auto companies pouring into the U.S., including BMW."

Let's bring in by phone the mayor of one of the towns where G.M. is planning to cut jobs. He is the mayor of Lordstown, Ohio. He's Mayor Arno Hill. Mayor, how serious is this for your town? We want to hear about the human pain behind the story. Can you tell us what's going on?

MAYOR ARNO HILL, LORDSTOWN, OHIO: I will tell you. You know, we just had our third layoff in the last two years. Two years ago, we were running three shifts. Lost the third shift, lost the second shift, lost the third shift, lost by the town of (Inaudible) we lost over 3,000 jobs.

You know, the biggest thing is, you know people who have lost jobs whose benefits are starting to run out. I'm sure the people from the third lay off their benefits have run out. The second lay off I believe theirs would be running out by the end of the year. And by the people at the first shift, you know, they may be able to ride it out and settle on employment for a while.

But, you know, the village has taken a pretty good hit. And we're doing what we can. You know, we've been adjusting every time there is a layoff, so it would be OK. You know, the village would be OK for a while. But the small business as every business, which came in they figured it had seven people there's been a ripple effect is what we're looking at.

And I know a lot of those restaurants, stores, gas station, all of businesses, you know, they are the ones who are feeling it already.

MACDONALD: Yes. Mayor, what's your take on how the president has been reacting to the story?

HILL: I think the president is trying to get General Motors' attention. You know, the General Motors they get bailed out many years ago, and you know, he ran on those, in fact, today, in Northeast Ohio, we're going to bring the jobs back. You know, the Northeast Ohio part of the state were the first one to go down. And to downturn, the last one to come up. He did campaign. He did turn (Inaudible) where we're at grab during the last presidential election.

And you know, right now, only then I could say I'm glad that they said they weren't permanently shuttering the plant. it's just that they are going to see its production and I think that we still have a pulse in our heartbeat.

MACDONALD: Mayor, we're hearing the president may try to get tax breaks to keep those G.M. jobs including jobs from going overseas. That's what Ohio Senator Sherrod Brown is saying. We're also hearing about how Ford says it figured how to keep jobs by rearranging shifts at factories in Kentucky and Michigan. What's your take on the possible tax breaks and what's your take on what Ford is doing.

HILL: As far as the possible tax break -- you know, I talked to Sherrod Brown. I talk to governor and lieutenant governor-elect Mike DeWine. They've all talked, they said, you know, we have to know what G.M. wants what G.M. needs to remain competitive. My phone has been ringing off the hook. I do believe that long-term I feel we'll get the product.

As far as what General Motors is doing and God, General Motors is reshuffling some of their laid off plant workers to other plants that all the (Inaudible) will do (Inaudible) whether it be in Spring Hill, Tennessee or Arlington, Texas. You know, if there's an opening I'm sure that several people may move on. I appreciate that. I'm sure that if we get another product a lot of those people will want to come back home.

MACDONALD: So, you're saying that hopefully G.M. will put an SUV or truck manufacturing capabilities in the factory in Lordstown. Is that a possibility?

HILL: I'm hoping that the crossover and SUV, a truck, a hybrid, an autonomous vehicle--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Can they do that. Can G.M. do that? Forgive me for interrupting. Can G.M. recalibrate their factories to do that?

HILL: The factory was set up for a smaller car. But I do know when they came on the 90's they had to posture the plant in case there was something and they would have to change the product. They had told me they could do that. Now, you know, they did it, they got a new paint plant, probably around 12 years ago. Someone says the paint plant may not be able to assist them on the bigger product.

I know they can make adjustments. You know, I heard rumors that they may be bringing the (Inaudible) in Korea. They have the same architectural base on the (Inaudible) and the Chevy truck and that would be a good fit for our plant. But I'm holding out that we're going to get a product.

MACDONALD: All right. Mayor Arno Hill of Lordstown, Ohio, I think you made some news there tonight, sir. Thank you so much for coming on. We will be staying on this story, sir. Your honor, we appreciate you coming on the show. Thank you so much.

HILL: Thank you very much. I appreciate the invite.

MACDONALD: OK. Next up, we've got new show premiering on Fox Business tomorrow night. WSJ at-large, hosted by Jerry Baker. Here's a sneak peek with former Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers. He is a big Democrat. He says President Trump is right about China. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE SUMMERS, FORMER SECRETARY, U.S. TREASURY DEPARTMENT: We, in the United States need to be very clear we were entitled and we are right to reject Chinese cheating in. Chinese violations as a rule. Rules that don't cover unfair practices. We're right when we're against that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: The full interview will air tomorrow night on WSJ at Large with Jerry Baker at 9.30 p.m. Eastern Time right here on the Fox Business Network.

Coming up, remember when Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg told Congress earlier this year that Facebook does not sell your data? Well, not so fast. We're going to detail for you Zuckerberg's fastball there because Facebook was all about selling access to your data. That slow drip of bad news continues out of the U.K. The U.K. now scouring through Facebook's internal documents that it seized last week. We've got that for you.

And later in the show. A shocker life expectancy for Americans falling at a rate not seen in 100 years, that's back when there was World War I and the flu pandemic. Dr. Marc Siegel joins us on that and how President Trump is fighting to help rural America where this health crisis is at its worst.

We're going to be right back. Stay there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Well, it's another day another round of shady dealings by big tech.

You're watching the Fox Business Network. You won't believe these stories.

A New York labor union slamming Amazon for, quote, "dehumanizing and deadly work practices." Internal documents seized by Great Britain shows Facebook is that profiting by selling companies access to your data including free access to the dating site Tinder.

We got Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey under fire. A House committee examines whether Jack Dorsey gave misleading testimony about twitter taking care of violent posts. Also, Twitter censored a U.S. marine for apparently no reason.

We've got Google CEO Sundar Pichai, he's set to testify at a congressional hearing next week. Google faces multibillion-dollar fines in Europe for tracking where you are even after you turn off your location on Google. It's a lot of stuff.

Let's bring in attorney Harmeet Dhillon. She is fighting the battle against social media censorship of conservatives. It's like tech is losing their minds, Harmeet. What's going on here?

HARMEET DHILLON, NATIONAL COMMITTEEWOMAN, RNC: Well, you know, Liz, we've heard these types of stories actually for a couple of years now. But what's amazing to me, is that we haven't seen more action against these big tech companies from Washington, where even those conservatives have been discriminated against clients like my client James Damore have been fired from Google for voicing conservative views.

We haven't used the last two years of conservative dominance in Washington to actually open up investigations by the Federal Trade Commission, the Department of Justice, or Congress passing some regulations that would reign in these massive abuses of civil rights and privacy rights on the part of Americans.

We do see that happen in Europe. However, some of the stories that you just mentioned are emanating out of Europe where they have much more concern for privacy rights of citizens there. I would like to see more of that in America.

MACDONALD: Yeah, we've got big tech lobbyists all over Washington, D.C.Harmeet, I like your response to Republican Texas Congressman Louie Gohmert. Here is his fix for the problem with big tech. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. LOUIE GOHMERT (R), TEXAS: They ought to be subject to lawsuits and I think some billion dollar class actions here and there would probably change their conduct pretty dramatically.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Wow! Is that the fix? That Louie Gohmert last night, Harmeet, because under the law, you know, the social media is exempt from lawsuits because they supposedly offer truly diverse political discourse. What's your answer to that?

DHILLON: Well, number one, I think that the Congress which Representative Gohmert sits on has had two years to do something about it. They need to redefine and perhaps pair back the Communications Decency Act Section 230. That would be one.

But another is that a lot of these companies have arbitration clauses or limitations of liability. For example, Twitter has $100 limitation of liability and that's user policy.

MACDONALD: Yeah.

DHILLON: Some of these things make it unattractive to file a lawsuit and those are also issues that could be addressed by Congress and by regulators in Washington.

MACDONALD: You know, Harmeet, it's pretty creepy that Google is tracking you after you turn off your location or pause it. They are potentially tracking you via other apps, on Android devices. It's creepy because Google workers have been protesting Google building a search engine for China because China will use that search engine to track its citizens and commit human rights abuses.

And now, we have had news coming in that started this talk yesterday, Harmeet, that more Google workers support, support that censored search engine, building it for China while they didn't help the Pentagon. What's going on there?

DHILLON: Well, I think to be clear, it's that they were double the number of Google employees protesting Google's work for the Pentagon than they are protesting the work in China. I am actually impressed that any Google employees are bold enough to protest what Google is doing in China.

But I think it's also convenient for them to protest what's happening somewhere else where they don't seem to care about the welfare of their own fellow employees and what Google is doing to Americans by stealing their privacy, undermining them, censoring them and tracking them. I think there is some massive hypocrisy going on there among Google employees or what we call dissonance, cognitive dissonance.

MACDONALD: Stay on that cognitive dissonance. I am looking at the headline out of TechCrunch. Five hundred Google workers signed a letter, saying, yes, Google, go ahead and build that censored search engine for China.

DHILLON: OK.

MACDONALD: Yes, there are some against -- I mean, it's pretty striking what's going on there, Harmeet.

DHILLON: No, but, Liz, that's 500 saying, yes, do it. Five hundred people who have questionable moral judgment who signed that. But there are 80,000 plus Google employees.

MACDONALD: Good point.

DHILLON: I don't think it's fair to say that there are many of them who support it. I think most of them are probably ashamed of it. I would have to imagine.

MACDONALD: So, what do you think of Google going ahead with this censored search engine for China? It's pretty amazing stuff.

DHILLON: I think it's awful. I think it is awful that an American company is going to be complicit in shadowing and giving this data to China which uses it to punish people.

China uses data like this to prevent people from flying, to put people into camps, to prevent them from getting jobs to the government, and to track them and punish them and their relatives. It's really outrageous that any American company would participate in that, but they are doing it for the unholy dollar, unfortunately.

MACDONALD: Do you think -- getting back to Facebook, do you think Facebook jumped a shark here in terms of its credibility?

DHILLON: Well, again, if you look into the details, it looks like the consideration of charging for the data that is uncovered to this particular story is from 2012 to 2014. They have come out and said that they don't currently do that.

However, you know, follow the money. You have to understand that if you are not being charged for a product, you are the product. I think that's also OK for Americans as long as it's properly disclosed. The problem is we haven't had transparency and that has not been disclosed what is being done with our data. We also can't get it back.

MACDONALD: Yeah.

DHILLON: I don't think there is a way for you to shut off Facebook and then retrieve your data from that. That doesn't exist.

MACDONALD: Beyond 2012, more recently, they have been giving access to data. Certainly Cambridge Analytic was reading Facebook messages. Harmeet, you're great. Come back soon. We love having you on.

DHILLON: Anytime.

MACDONALD: It's good to see you. Coming up, high-profile Democrats now doing a 180, and now standing tough about border security. You'll never guess the latest Democrat who jumped on the Trump bandwagon, and he's thinking about running in 2020. We've got the name, coming up.

But first, more details surfacing about the growing crisis at the border with the migrant caravan. We've got the latest there. That's next. Stay right there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. Developments tonight at the border. The border patrol has arrested an active member of the MS-13 gang on U.S. side of the border. He traveled with the caravan. He is a Honduran national. Homeland Security has estimated there are hundreds of criminals in the caravan.

Separate from that, health officials in Tijuana warned about an escalating humanitarian health crisis with the caravan. Jeff Paul is on the ground of Tijuana, Mexico with more. Jeff?

JEFF PAUL, FOX NEWS REPORTER: Yeah, Elizabeth. Just about the last couple of hours, the situation behind started to develop. There are some migrants from that caravan who are staying at the nearby shelter. They tried to march towards the immigration offices here to protest, but they were then stopped by the federal police over here who said that they are doing their job and they are given orders to not let them pass.

At the same time this is happening, it has been a very rainy day, and that of course is causing lots of health concerns. Sixty percent, according to health officials, are suffering from respiratory infections that are staying in that shelter. We spoke with one migrant who told us he is not only concerned about his health but the others around him.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: That's a big problem, especially with children. You hear children coughing, for example. You hear they -- they start crying because they can't take it. They start coughing and coughing and coughing. If you think about it, we, adults cannot even take it sometimes. With children, it is much more difficult.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PAUL: With so many people, some 6,000 migrants living in such close quarters and very poor condition, there are talks of now opening up a second additional shelter. The details right now being hammered out as we speak. Elizabeth?

MACDONALD: Jeff Paul. Thank you so much for your reporting, sir. We really appreciate it. With me now if Fox News medical correspondent, Dr. Marc Siegel. Doctor, there is a lot of concern about the health crisis. It is a humanitarian issue, what's happening in Tijuana, right?

MARC SIEGEL, FOX NEWS MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT: I feel very bad for the people there. The migrants are in trouble because they are in such close quarters, hygiene might not be what you would want, and the respiratory viruses. The issue is that the viruses spread very quickly among people that are in close quarters, especially this time of year.

So, the report was from Griff Jenkins this morning, one-third are sick. It's probably more than that. I think that's probably under-reported. The nurses have been telling him that. Respiratory viruses, I'm concerned about something like chicken pox which is going around down there because a lot of people aren't vaccinated. That's about 90 percent infectivity rate of chicken pox.

You can get quite ill. We think of that as a childhood disease. You can get quite ill from that. Three cases of tuberculosis down there. That's very problematic. Hepatitis A and lice. And also of course other diseases like heart disease, asthma. So, there is a lot of problems with the conditions. It's only going to get worse.

MACDONALD: Yeah. The Tijuana mayor says 30,000 a day funding for the migrants is running out. We are going to stay on that story for you. Let's switch to another shocker of a story. Life expectancy dropping in the U.S. for the third straight year. Let's talk to the doctor about this, because rural America is really getting hit too. This is stunning. We haven't seen it dropping at this rate since World War I.

SIEGEL: You know, when I saw this, my jaw dropped because I thought it was going to be the obesity epidemic that you and I talked about last week. People are overweight that they get heart disease, that they get cancer, that they get stroke. That's stable. In fact, we have less people dying of cancer than before.

It's actually suicide and the drug overdoses we have been talking about. We are seeing 70,000 drug overdose deaths per year which is up because of illegal fentanyl. Even as we start, Liz, to get a handle on doctors not prescribing too much, on pharmacies not giving out too much, we still got illegal chemists in China and Mexico with their fentanyl that caused over 30,000 overdose deaths in places like West Virginia, Ohio, the capitol, Pennsylvania.

So, those states, New Hampshire getting really hammered with overdose deaths. And we have suicide in places that are my favorite places in the country. Nevada, Wyoming, Montana, Idaho, New Mexico. Gorgeous places where you would think just being alive in this place would be enough to sustain you, but not if you don't have a job.

In 2017, this is the statistics we are talking about, 53,000 deaths -- 53 percent increase over 1999, 53 percent increase, and it's because of job loss. Hopefully, with the economy recovering --

MACDONALD: Yeah.

SIEGEL: -- that we are going to see improvement.

MACDONALD: Yeah, because this is despair and lack of hope. So, the White House has been battling to get jobs for, you know, across the country. Is that could be curative here?

SIEGEL: I think that's the cure.

MACDONALD: One of the cures, right?

SIEGEL?: This has been hitting mainly ages 25 to 44. I think that the White House getting us on track in terms of economy, I think we are seeing more jobs than ever before, that's going to translate into people being happier in rural states like the ones I just mentioned.

MACDONALD: It's a health crisis. Doctors are trying to help with the opioid addition. It's humanitarian crisis. Doc, we love having you on. Are you going to stay on the story for us?

SIEGEL: Absolutely.

MACDONALD: It was a shocker, when we saw that, right?

SIEGEL: Unbelievable. I never expected that.

MACDONALD: Yeah.

SIEGEL: I think jobs will translate to people being happier and staying alive.

MACDONALD: We hope so. We are thinking of those folks out there. Thank you, Dr. Siegel. Coming up next, much of the mainstream media losing their collective mind after President Trump's former attorney, Michael Cohen, pleads guilty to lying to Congress about the Trump Tower real estate deal in Moscow.

It's not good to lie to Congress. The markets shrugged it off. But Gregg Jarrett is here too to explain why it is not exactly the smoking gun against Trump as the media is trying to report that. We are going to stay on the story. Stay there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. President Trump blasting at his former personal attorney, Michael Cohen, calling him weak and a liar after Cohen pleaded guilty to a single count of lying to Congress to minimize the president's role in efforts to build the Trump Tower in Moscow. It was special counsel Robert Mueller who brought the charges.

Let's bring in Fox News legal analyst Gregg Jarrett. He is the author of the bestseller book, "The Russia Hoax." Gregg, a lot of speculation. What are the facts at this moment? What do we know?

GREGG JARRETT, FOX NEWS LEGAL ANALYST: We know it's not a crime to build a tower in Moscow. Trump is a real estate developer. He had an option and letter of intent. He scrapped the deal. To my mind, you know, if there really was some coordination or collusion or conspiracy with Russia to win the election and those connected to Trump Tower, Cohen would have been charged, but he wasn't.

He's charged as four other individuals who have been charged with what we know as process crimes. These are things that have occurred after the fact caused by Mueller's investigation itself. So if Cohen -- if Mueller had evidence of collusion, Cohen would have been charged and so others.

MACDONALD: That is the key silver bullet to what's happening here --

JARRETT: Right.

MACDONALD: -- at this point in time, because we don't know what Robert Mueller is going to do down the road. Nobody -- if there was conspiracy or collusion, you're saying we would have seen those charges already?

JARRETT: Right.

MACDONALD: You know, against individuals at Trump's campaign.

JARRETT: The media and the left which is slightly redundant have promised that we would know by now all of the evidence of collusion, secret bank transfers and rendezvouses in Moscow and the bowls (ph) of the Kremlin between Trump and Putin and others, smoking gun, documents that would evidence this conspiracy to steal the White House. None of it has come to fruition.

MACDONALD: No conspiracy or collusion charges right now.

JARRETT: You know, collusion, first of all, not even a crime in a criminal code. You would have to find some other relevant statute. And so far, it appears that Mueller hasn't because of all of the people he has been charging, all of them are for the most part are tax fraud cases, money laundering or these process crimes, gee, you are not telling the truth to me.

MACDONALD: All right. Attorney Alan Dershowitz agrees with you that Mueller is -- he is saying Mueller is creating crime --

JARRETT: That's right.

MACDONALD: -- after the fact. And Trump says that even if Cohen's testimony were true, it would be perfectly legal for President Trump to be negotiating real estate deals while campaigning. It was a byproduct of him, running a business while campaigning.

JARRETT: Yeah, it's very much not only is it legal to talk to Russians building some real estate in Moscow, but it's also perfectly legal as in the Trump Tower meeting with a Russian lawyer to have a conversation with the Russians.

In fact, it is the title of one of the chapters in my book. It is not a crime to talk to a Russian. You can receive information from a Russian as long as money doesn't exchange hands. It's not a violation of the Federal Campaign Election Act. It's not conspiracy to defraud the government. All that is nonsense.

MACDONALD: But the media is basically bringing up that the president is not meeting with Putin over Michael Cohen when it's over Ukraine.

JARRETT: Exactly, you know, but, the media is on board with this collusion narrative. They think if they say the word "Russia" and "collusion" enough, the mere use of the term which connotes to crime will establish a crime -- it just doesn't under American law.

MACDONALD: OK. Let's move on to this story. The president apparently told The New York Post that a pardon for Paul Manafort is not off the table. What's your take on that story?

(LAUGHTER)

JARRETT: If it were me, I's pardon everybody. Just to vaccine anger, Robert Mueller and his team of partisans. This is the most lopsided, unfair, biased prosecution I have ever seen in my life and I have been a lawyer for almost 40 years. Mueller had conflicts of interest. Should never have accepted the job. Assembles a team of nothing but pro-Hillary, anti- Trump partisans.

Every move they have made the better part of 19 months now, have exhibited severe prejudice. So when Mueller comes out with his report, whether it's made public or not, Trump's legal team, Jay Sekulow and Rudy Giuliani and others, will be publishing their counter report because as Professor Dershowitz has pointed out, Mueller's reports going to be one-sided.

His version of events from a prosecutorial point of view. He is not going to represent the others. Somebody has to. The lawyers for Trump have been preparing their own counter report, or you can read my book.

MACDONALD: Right.

JARRETT: And that needs -- in fairness to the president, that needs to be presented simultaneously.

MACDONALD: Gregg Jarrett, thank you so much for coming on. Will you come on again?

JARRETT: Yeah.

MACDONALD: As soon as that Mueller report comes out, we're going to call you.

JARRETT: I'm not holding my breath.

(LAUGHTER)

MACDONALD: Exactly. Great, Jarrett. You're terrific. Thank you so much. We're going to be right back. Stay right there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. OK, who said this? "Europe is already crushed under this transformation that is taking place because of immigration. Germany - Angela Merkel, weakened because of it. And other places impacted, Italy - significantly impacted its politics by immigration." It's former Secretary of State John Kerry.

John Kerry may run in 2020. He is starting to sound a lot like President Trump. He certainly sounds like what Senator Obama and Senator Hillary Clinton have said in the past.

Let's take it up with New York Republican Congressman Tom Reed. Sir, great to see you. Your reaction to John Kerry.

REP. TOM REED (R), NEW YORK: Obviously a statement like that about immigration should be reflected in America's policy. We need a border, we need to secure our border and make sure that it's functioning. When you see the hypocrisy now of Secretary Kerry on the left demonstrating that they recognize this in Europe and not in America, that's a question that we should be asking as American citizens of our leaders.

MACDONALD: You know, Republican conservatives alike are humanitarian, they are pro-legal immigration. The Democrats continue to muddy and the media muddies this issue. It's not the first time Democrats have spoken against illegal immigration. Bill Clinton again, Barack Obama, Senator Harry Reid, Senator Dianne Feinstein. Your take on that.

REED: Yeah, Liz, you're absolutely right. I mean, we as Republicans, myself, firmly believe people should be able to come to America legally to enjoy the American dream. That's what's made us great for generations. The diversity is a strength, not a weakness. But you need a border that keeps us secure.

When you see an MS-13 gang member just recently arrested at our southern border trying to cross with this caravan that is coming up through Tijuana, that is a signal, that is a problem that needs to be fixed. I will just tell you, this hypocrisy on the left, it's good for Europe to control its borders, its good for Europe to control its immigration status and not for America, politics at play, not substance.

MACDONALD: Sir, are you pro-immigration?

REED: Yeah, I believe in immigration. I believe we should have a country that welcomes people to the American dream, but we have to do it in a smart, sensible manner that has structure such as walls, such as technology, such as people to keep us safe, our fellow American citizens safe and sound. That's the top priority, but have a border that also functions so that people can come and go in a way that is controlled.

MACDONALD: Congressman Tom Reed of New York. I wish I have more time with you, sir. We ran out of time. Come back soon. Great to see you.

REED: Always great to be with you, Liz. Thank you.

MACDONALD: Thank you so much for having us in your homes and thank you for watching. Lou Dobbs is next right here on the Fox Business Network. Have a good night.

END
