urn:contentItem:60HB-78H1-DXH2-6451-00000-00President Trump Fights For American Workers; Trump Fires Chair Of Tennessee Valley Authority, Calls For Ouster Of CEO Over High Pay; President Trump Signs Executive Order Barring Federal Agencies From Replacing Americans With Foreign Workers; Minneapolis Police Investigates 41st Murder This Year, Up From 21 Murders Over Same Time In 2019; Another Bloody Weekend In Chicago; Ohio Hospital Researcher Pleads Guilty To Trying To Steal Trade Secrets For China; Top Federal Reserve Official Suggests A Four To Six Weeks Shutdown; President Trump May Use Executive Orders If Relief Bill Deal Can't Be Reached With Democrats; Manhattan DA Says Trump Could Be Investigated For Bank And Insurance Fraud; President Trump Addresses Coronavirus Response2020-08-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:28ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTMarc Short, Larry ElderNEWSFinancial080301cb.229President Trump Fights For American Workers; Trump Fires Chair Of Tennessee Valley Authority, Calls For Ouster Of CEO Over High Pay; President Trump Signs Executive Order Barring Federal Agencies From Replacing Americans With Foreign Workers; Minneapolis Police Investigates 41st Murder This Year, Up From 21 Murders Over Same Time In 2019; Another Bloody Weekend In Chicago; Ohio Hospital Researcher Pleads Guilty To Trying To Steal Trade Secrets For China; Top Federal Reserve Official Suggests A Four To Six Weeks Shutdown; President Trump May Use Executive Orders If Relief Bill Deal Can't Be Reached With Democrats; Manhattan DA Says Trump Could Be Investigated For Bank And Insurance Fraud; President Trump Addresses Coronavirus ResponseLou Dobbs

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Thank you so much for watching. We hope you have a good evening and join us tomorrow night. Good to see you.

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Good evening, everybody. We're waiting for the President this hour to hold his news conference in the White House Briefing Room and we expect President Trump to give us an update on his administration's fight against the China virus and potentially take some questions from the assembled White House Press Corps. They get along so well, you know.

We'll be bringing you the President's remarks nonetheless, just as soon as he takes the podium, and be sure to join us here tomorrow for my exclusive interview with President Trump. That's at 5:00 p.m. Eastern right here on the Fox Business Network on LOU DOBBS TONIGHT.

President Trump today following through on a major pledge from his 2016 presidential campaign promises to protect American workers, to put an end to the abuse of the H-1B visa program.

President Trump signed an Executive Order at the White House today, that order bans Federal agencies from firing American citizens or green card holders from their Federal jobs and hiring foreign workers to replace them.

Today's action also orders a study to determine just how many Federal jobs are now held by foreign visa workers. President Trump today heard from a number of American workers, workers who were forced into the degrading, humiliating process of training their less qualified foreign replacements - - that's right -- H-1B visa workers trained by the workers they were replacing from the Tennessee Valley Authority, a federally owned corporation that provides utility services to residents in seven states.

The TVA recently announced a plan to outsource 20 percent of its technology jobs to companies based overseas. Do you suppose anyone in the TVA knew who was President? That move threatens more than 200 highly skilled American technology workers in Tennessee alone.

President Trump was enraged, announcing that he is firing two of the board members and called for the Board to fire the company's CEO.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The current CEO, Jeff Lyash is ridiculously overpaid. He earns $8 million a year -- did you know that? Eight million. He is the highest paid government official of any country anywhere in the world.

The Board must work to ensure the CEO does not receive a lavish compensation package upon his departure, too. We don't want him leaving and then he gets a big check for millions and millions of dollars.

So let this serve as a warning to any federally appointed Board. If you betray American workers, then you will hear two simple words, "You're fired."

So with that, we're getting rid of him in one form or another, either the Board is going to do, we're going to do it, but he's gone.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Well, he ought to be gone, and he should have been long gone. Not long after that strong warning from the President, he was handed a note from Chief of Staff, Mark Meadows. Here's what that note said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Mark just brought this in from the TVA CEO and he has indicated a very strong willingness to reverse course.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: He is willing to reverse course, isn't that nice? He would actually -- well, you know, we couldn't get the same note, I'm sure from the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. We couldn't get it from the Department of Depends in all likelihood. It's good at least that the TVA's overpaid CEO, arrogant as he is, and as disloyal as he is to the U.S. worker, at least he understood that he should be a little flexible when the President of the United States is telling you to reverse course.

During that same roundtable discussion today, President Trump also learned of a $15 million contract given by the Tennessee Valley Authority to the French based tech firm Capgemini. Here's the President reacting.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: You spent $15 million to one consulting firm.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's not a consulting -- that's one of the companies they're picking up and it's Capgemini and that's $15 million just for that one company.

TRUMP: How many -- how many are there?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: There's Capgemini, CGI, Accenture and Tech Systems that TVA is saying.

TRUMP: They are paying a tremendous amount.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: And our workers are very tight.

TRUMP: They're very political people. You know, that's a very political group of people. You just --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Really. That is now the --

TRUMP: Not to me. I don't care. I don't care who they are, but they are very political.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Very political. Their names have been on nearly every list of outsources in the country for 10 years. These are the same people who lobby day in and day out, spending millions of dollars to influence your elected representatives, whether they be congressmen or senators, and they are at it full time, and it is outrageous.

Outrageous that anyone running any agency would think that he or she is entitled to replace an American worker with a cheaper foreign worker who the fired American must -- well -- train. Outrageous.

President Trump once again showing he is standing up to corporate interest and providing a straightforward defense of American workers every day.

All of the companies you just heard about, French based, Capgemini; Canada based, CGI. There's a beauty by the way, with a terrible checkered background, Irish based Accenture. It was, I believe it was part of the -- well, ill-fated Arthur Andersen Company flood around 15,000 H-1B visas into the United States every year -- 15,000. That is by the way, a conservative estimate 15,000 to 65,000.

Yet there are corporations on Wall Street and their lobbying groups that would have more foreign workers come into this country to undercut the future of millions of American workers and their families.

We asked the Business Roundtable for a statement on today's presidential Executive Order. They pointed us to a statement from June, which says in part, they are concerned that the administration's proposed changes to immigration policy will disrupt business operations, the lives of our employees and ultimately harm our ability to do our part to rebuild the economy.

This is the Business Roundtable along with the Chamber of Commerce -- are the globalist elites who really don't really give a damn about the American worker.

At a time when roughly 30 million Americans are collecting unemployment benefits, the Business Roundtable is sufficiently arrogant and indifferent to be concerned there won't be enough immigrants to rebuild the economy. I guess they haven't heard of robotics either.

These are ideas that are swirling around the swamp, and not just among the open border radical Dems. Republican Senator Mike Lee, oh yes, he is still pushing his outsourcing bill, he calls it the Fairness for High Skilled Immigrants Act. You know, we can't get anywhere without a bunch of lower paid high skilled foreign workers.

The bill is backed, of course by Big Technology and their owner oligarchs and the outsourcing firms, a number of whose names you've just heard here.

It is estimated to clog green card lines for the next decade with hundreds of thousands of Indian and Chinese H-1B visa workers. Perhaps Senator Lee should take a listen once again to President Trump's warning for those who betray American workers.

President Trump's defense of the American worker today is sure to help his continued rise in the polls. Rasmussen now showing President Trump with a 51 percent approval rating. How good is that? Well, let's put it in context.

It is seven points higher than Barack Obama at the same point in his presidency. That is when he was running for reelection in 2012.

Meanwhile, supporters of China -- Joe Biden chief among them -- are fearful that the nominee for the party of hate might have to actually show up for a debate with President Trump. Whoa, you don't think that would work out so well for China Joe? Me either.

Bill Clinton's former White House Press Secretary, Joe Lockhart advised Biden in an op-ed saying this, "Whatever you do, don't debate Trump." I haven't agreed with Joe about much, but he's got this one right.

Perhaps Biden's supporters are concerned about the former Vice President's -- well, so many things to be concerned about, but amongst them the enthusiasm levels of his supporters.

A new poll finds just 40 percent of Biden supporters are enthusiastic about China Joe. That compares to 68 percent of voters supporting President Trump. They are very enthusiastic about reelecting the President of the United States.

The President's surge in these polls coming as violence has exploded in Democrat-run cities all across America. This weekend, Minneapolis police were investigating the city's 41st murder of the year. That's nearly the double the number from the same period a year ago.

Radical Dem leaders in that city, they don't have any other kind by the way in Minneapolis, pushing the Police Department into submission. So far the department is now urging residents to cooperate with criminals in order to remain safe. My Lord. Don't you wish you lived in Minneapolis?

Recommendations from the Minneapolis Police -- what's left of them include being prepared to give up your cell phone and purse or wallet, to carry less cash because you don't want to share that either, do you? And to not fight with the criminal and do just exactly what they say. Thank you, Police Department of Minneapolis. You're an inspiration to every American.

In socialist Bill de Blasio's New York City, there have already been more shootings in the first seven months of this year than in all of last year.

And the carnage continues to rage in Chicago. Chicago's murder rate rising last month by 139 percent, August is off to just as deadly a start. Nine people murdered this weekend, 30 people were shot. One of those shot, a nine-year-old African-American boy. To the criminals running the streets of Chicago, his life obviously does not matter and the organization pushing all of this nonsense, all of these organizations, do you want to open your eyes? Do you want to be woke when it comes to the children of this country being slaughtered on your streets and you're playing games?

On Wall Street, stocks finishing higher to kick the week off. The Dow up 236 points. The S&P up 23. The NASDAQ gaining 158 points to its 29th record close of the year. Volume on the big board, four and a half billion shares. Crude oil $40.82 a barrel.

A reminder listen to my reports three times a day, coast to coast on the Salem Radio Network.

Up next, we're awaiting the President to give an update on his efforts to fight the China virus pandemic. Also tonight, President Trump may take action if the Dems keep slow rolling deal a relief package for millions of Americans.

Vice President Mike Pence's Chief of Staff, Marc Short joins us here next.

And my new book, "The Trump Century: How Our President Changed the Course of History Forever." Please preorder your copy or copies. You can do so at thetrumpcentury.com, amazon.com, barnesandnoble.com.

We're coming right back with much more. Stay with us, please.

DOBBS: Breaking news now, Chinese national Li Chen has pleaded guilty to stealing trade secrets for China while working as a researcher at the Nationwide Children's Hospital in Columbus, Ohio. Her husband also charged, his case is pending.

Chen was accused of stealing U.S. funded research intellectual property to set up a company in China and transfer the research she stole to the Chinese government.

And Dr. Anthony Fauci weighed in last week, saying don't worry about China stealing our research and intellectual property. Everything is so transparent. What's the fuss all about? Here he is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES: I don't think so at all. I think one of the things people need to understand that what we do is really transparent. We publish it. We announce it.

So if they want to hack into a computer, and find out what the results of a vaccine trial are, they're going to hear about it in "The New England Journal of Medicine" in a few days, anyway.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Yes, as Dr. Fauci knows, it wasn't about the results of the vaccine, it was about the construction of the vaccine. And Anthony Fauci talking about everything is so transparent. Well, maybe it's about time everyone got used to the idea that we are now in a serious Cold War with the People's Republic of China, and it is time to understand that the Communist Chinese party is stealing hundreds of billions of dollars from the United States every single year.

This is not a game and it is not a set of benign elites at "The New England Journal" deciding what will be the outcome of that contest.

One top Federal Reserve official says the economy -- speaking of bizarre elites -- that we could all benefit from a four to six-week shutdown of the economy.

His name is Neel Kashkari. He is the President of the Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank, and he says economic recovery is possible if the Chinese virus is brought under control. Now, this is a member of the Federal Reserve. They don't even know how to run the Federal Reserve folks, let alone what is best for the economy.

He also says Congress could afford big spending on another China virus relief bill. The Fed, however, can't manage an economy, as I said, let alone our entire society. They can't even manage interest rates. So here we have the President of the Minneapolis Fed, holding forth on just what is best to forestall the pandemic. It's just unbelievable what the Fed produces.

President Trump today says he may use Executive Orders to help American families if the radical Dems continue to resist any kind of relief for hurting Americans.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: A lot of people are going to be evicted, but I'm going to stop it because I'll do it myself if I have to. I have a lot of powers with respect to Executive Orders and we're looking at that very seriously right now.

But what the Democrats want, they want -- they are slow rolling it and all they're really interested in is bailout money to bail out radical left governors and radical left mayors.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And that is exactly what they want to do. Joining us tonight is Marc Short. He is Chief of Staff for Vice President Mike Pence, and it's great to see you, Marc.

You were present at the signing of the Executive Order today. We're used to a lot of outrages in the Federal government, but to have an $8 million a year, CEO of the Tennessee Valley Authority deciding to replace workers, American workers with H-1B cheap labor. This is -- the outrage that must be felt across this country won't be even measurable. It's going to be off the charts.

MARC SHORT, CHIEF OF STAFF FOR VICE PRESIDENT MIKE PENCE: Well, Lou, thanks for having me back on. As you know, in 2016, Donald Trump campaigned and pledged to drain the swamp and I think that's what you're seeing evidence of today's action.

A lot of Americans don't even recognize the Tennessee Valley Authority programs set up during the FDR years. It is still around other than those who still get electricity in parts of the southeast from it, but the fact that somebody on a Federal government payroll is getting $8 million in compensation is outrageous to most Americans and Donald Trump has brought attention to it and said we're going to stop it.

But as you mentioned earlier in your show also, what we're going to do is to make sure that government agencies like that are not using H-1B visa programs to displace American workers.

And so by shining light on it, it shows exactly what this President promised when he said he was able to drain the swamp in Washington, D.C.

DOBBS: Absolutely. And it is -- to me, it's just dismal that the Federal government has never kept track of who is in its workforce. We don't know how many contractors there are -- I've never seen the number. I have never seen the number of people being outsourced in this country from the labor market to cheap, foreign -- to cheap foreign labor markets.

It's really stunning what the Federal government doesn't know about itself and about the country, and I hope as a result of this, we'll know how many visa workers are employed by the Federal government. Again, this President thinks of things no one else does. Hopefully, we can have a quick response.

SHORT: Well, again, it's why they elected a businessman to come in and to help create seven million jobs for Americans in his first three and a half years before the pandemic. It's why they trust him to rebuild our economy again, and it's because he's going to help make sure that American workers are placed first. That's what his campaign promise was. It's what he's delivered on. It is what he will keep doing as the President of the United States.

DOBBS: And the visa sponsors, they're led by Google, Amazon, TCS, Facebook, Apple. We've got all sorts of this. These are the Big Tech, Silicon Valley. The President has said we've got to bust it up.

He has talked about it throughout the first three years, three and a half years of his presidency. Where are we? Because we really do need to do precisely what the President said. We watched the three top CEOs of the three major technology companies make $250 billion in additional market cap within one day of being on Capitol Hill being grilled by the radical Dems.

I mean, it is stunning stuff what we're permitting in this country?

SHORT: Well, Lou, I think that our concern is less how much value they are creating or earning from a private sector perspective, but it is a concern, as you mentioned before, about censorship and how many of these companies really more or less have a monopoly on information flow.

And I think there's been a lot of attention from conservative organizations brought to Google search engines and whether or not there's an inherent bias.

And as you know, the President signed the Executive Order back in May, asking the Attorney General to develop legislation to come forward and look at ways to protect Americans, so the information they are getting on online searches is legitimate as opposed to going through a bias filter.

And I think you'll be hearing more from the administration in the coming days on it.

DOBBS: This -- the violence that has seized these Democrat-run large cities across the country, the President has stepped forward, his Operation Legend working in, I believe, it's now five cities. But we're watching a Democratic Party that is not only the party of hate speaking rhetorically, they have become a party of hate in terms of letting young people be shot to death on their streets.

The explosion and violence since the Minneapolis death of George Floyd is outrageous, and we're hearing all of this money that's flowing to an organization called Black Lives Matter. Most of those deaths are black people who have been killed on the streets, say in Chicago, in Minneapolis, you name it.

SHORT: Lou, as you mentioned, the killing of George Floyd was a travesty, but what's happened in our inner cities is also a travesty. What we've seen -- you mentioned earlier on your show, the homicide increases in Chicago and New York.

Shockingly, there's been a double digit increase in homicide in 36 of our 50 biggest cities over the last few months and what you've seen, as you said, are these large inner cities that are run by roughly the Democratic Party and Democratic mayors that have turned a blind eye to the violence, and what we hear when the Vice President travels the country is those that are most upset and most asking for Federal support are actually African- American small business owners who are saying please protect my business. Please protect me from these rioters and looters.

And the reality is that while we all want to protect the First Amendment and make sure that the Right to Peaceably Assemble is protected, that doesn't constitute rioting, looting, violence, destruction of property, destruction and arson of churches, and that's where we're going to make sure, as this President said, we're going to step in.

If these mayors are unwilling to do it, this President is going to step in and make sure we protect the American people.

What we saw in the first three and a half years of this administration was the lowest unemployment rate ever for the African-American population of this country. This President put them first and foremost, we passed opportunity zones to make sure there's investment in those communities.

And sadly, what you're seeing in the name of protest is a destruction of a lot of the private property and frankly, businesses that are owned by African-Americans, and this administration is not going to tolerate it.

DOBBS: Marc Short, always good to have you with us. Thanks so much.

SHORT: Thanks for having me.

DOBBS: Marc Short, Chief of Staff for Mike Pence.'

Up next, Manhattan District Attorney Cy Vance back at it. We will take that up right after these quick words.

DOBBS: Manhattan District Attorney, Cy Vance, fabricating more fraudulent accusations to go after President Trump. Vance coming up with the nonsense that the Trump Organization committed insurance and bank fraud as a pattern of financial misconduct in order to justify why he has been seeking subpoenas.

When will Attorney General Barr or perhaps Chief Justice John Roberts or the Judiciary -- we can't do much, I guess, with the state government of New York, that would be talking about nonsense -- but somebody needs to straighten all of this political combat out.

Joining us now is Larry Elder. He is host of "The Larry Elder Show" on the Salem Radio Network. Also the executive producer of the number one documentary in the entire world, "Uncle Tom: Oral History of the American Black Conservative."

Larry, great to have you with us. I mean, here we have ...

LARRY ELDER, RADIO SHOW HOST, SALEM RADIO NETWORK: Thank you.

DOBBS: ... Cy Vance trying to justify wanting to go after this President anyway he can. And people -- I mean, he's talking like he has -- that these are serious charges. This is frivolous. It's fraudulent. And he is a leftwing hack.

ELDER: Well, Lou, he is picking up on the mantle that was thrown down on Thursday by former President Barack Obama, who at John Lewis's funeral compared Donald Trump, believe it or not to Bull Connor.

Bull Connor is that Birmingham law man who in the 60s turned water hoses and six dogs on Civil Rights workers. He also compared President Trump to George Wallace, who famously stood in front of the University of Alabama and said segregation now, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever.

Meanwhile, Donald Trump, as Marc Short has just said, presided over the lowest unemployment rates for blacks in history before the coronavirus pandemic shutdown. He expanded spending on historically black colleges. He wants to do something about the threat to unskilled workers in the inner city posed by unskilled illegal aliens.

If he is a racist, he needs to go back to racism school.

DOBBS: Yes, it's absolutely a straightforward reality. This President has done more for African-Americans than any President in history, including -- Barack Obama. I mean, it's just stunning that he stood there in that church in Atlanta and lied through his teeth.

ELDER: I would say especially under Barack Obama. The black poverty rate increased under Barack Obama. The so-called wealth gap increased, and from a period of 2010 to 2013, black net worth fell a third, a full third under Barack Obama.

So Donald Trump has done far better for black people than Obama has ever done. It is not even close.

DOBBS: Yes. And that's one of the reasons that blacks in this country are showing up in polls, 40 percent saying that they will vote for President Trump. That's a stunning margin.

ELDER: I think I've lost you, Lou. I really didn't hear the question.

DOBBS: Well, I'm going to -- I'm going to back it up. We'll try it again. What do you think of the fact that 40 percent of blacks surveyed in this -- in the most recent poll said they will be voting for Donald Trump?

ELDER: I'm not sure it's going to be that high, but certainly, it's going to be much higher than the seven or eight percent that he got. I think it's going to be I think -- I think I've lost you again.

I think it's going to be at least twice what he got in 2016, if not more, and that'll be enough for Donald Trump to prevail at the presidential level. If he gets 20 to 25 percent of the black vote, it's all over for Mr. Biden.

DOBBS: All right, Larry Elder, it's always good to have you with us and I'm sorry that you lost me because that is the most fascinating thing, is to hear me all the time, Larry. Just joking.

Up next President Trump threatens the radical Dems with legal action over their efforts to steal another election.

And a reminder about my new book, "The Trump Century: How Our President Changed the Course of History Forever" available for preorder now at thetrumpcentury.com, amazon.com, barnesandnoble.com. Stay with us. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: President Trump speaking at the podium in the White House Briefing Room now. Here is the President.

TRUMP: It's currently off the coast of South Carolina heading northward to North Carolina. It is expected to make landfall sometime this evening as a Category 1 Hurricane. Very serious. A lot of water -- a lot of water coming from that storm.

I've already issued emergency declarations for Florida, South Carolina, North Carolina, and F.E.M.A.'s personnel -- and they are great. They are the job. They're already on the ground in all areas, every single area that we mentioned is covered.

Over the next several days. There's expected to be heavy wind and rain in the coastal areas of North Carolina, Virginia, Maryland, Delaware, and New Jersey. We're working with each of those states, and in particular as it relates to F.E.M.A., the military, law enforcement, all of the different groups that are involved.

Storm surge and inland flooding are possible and everyone needs to remain vigilant until it passes. I encourage everyone to follow the guidelines of the state and local authorities. We're working with them. And I think the guidelines have been very accurate so far. So, stay safe.

Next, let me provide an update on the path forward for our country as we continue our war to defeat the China virus. We're beginning to see evidence of significant progress.

Nationwide, the number of positive cases has declined by nearly six percent from the week before and the positive test rate has also dropped from 8.7 to eight percent over that same period of time, an encouraging sign, very encouraging, I have to add that the virus is receding.

In hotspots across the south and west, we've seen slow improvements from their recent weekly peaks, Arizona's weekly case counts have dropped 37 percent. That's a tremendous drop and the governor and the state have done a fantastic job, down 37 percent. Texas down 18.7 percent. I was there a couple of days ago. And Florida 21.2 percent drop. So that's a tremendous job that they're all doing.

As we begin to contain the virus in these states, we must focus on new flare-ups in the states where the case numbers have risen, including Georgia, Mississippi, Tennessee, Oklahoma, Missouri, and I think you'll find that they're soon going to be very much under control.

Meanwhile, 18 states continue to have very low case numbers and low test positivity rates, under five percent: Alaska, Connecticut, Delaware, Illinois, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Montana, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, North Dakota, Oregon, Rhode Island, Vermont, West Virginia and Wyoming. So under five.

Even in these states, however, where the virus is under control and at a very low number, Americans should continue to be vigilant, be careful in order to prevent the new hotspots from opening up or any new hotspots from opening up in those states.

To that end, I urge all Americans to continue to socially distance, wash your hands, wear a mask when you cannot avoid crowded places, and to protect the elderly -- very, very important -- protect the elderly. It's much different.

The young children have very strong immune systems. We've learned how strong they are. But protect the elderly. The average age of those who succumb to the virus is 78 years old. That's the average age.

It's important for Americans to recognize that a permanent lockdown is not a viable path toward producing the result that you want or certainly not a viable path forward and would ultimately inflict more harm that it would prevent.

As we're seeing in foreign countries around the world where cases are once again surging, you have many places where we thought they were under control -- and doing a great job -- and they are doing a great job, but this is a very tough invisible enemy.

Lockdowns do not prevent infection in the future, they just don't. It comes back, many times it comes back. The purpose of a lockdown is to buy time to build capacity, especially with respect to hospitals, learn more about the disease and develop effective treatments as we did in the United States. We're doing very well with the vaccines and the therapeutics.

Countries where there have been very significant flare-ups over the last short period of time are Spain, Germany, France, Australia, Japan and also, as you probably heard in Hong Kong, they've had some very serious flare ups.

Japan has gone-- yes, a lot of -- six-fold flare-up, it's a lot, but they'll get it under control.

In our current phase, we must focus on protecting those at highest risk while allowing younger and healthier Americans to resume work and school with careful precautions. Ideally, we want to open those schools. We want to open them.

At the same time, we're placing an emphasis on continuing to drive down the mortality rate with improved care, treatment and medical interventions. Building a bridge to the introduction of a vaccine, the vaccines are coming along incredibly well.

Today, I'd like to also provide an update on the actions of my administration, and the work that we've done. We are really taking an increased interest and we're seeing numbers that nobody can even believe in terms of percentage increase. It's telehealth for American patients.

The percentage increase is being worked on right now. But it's very, very significant, numbers that you would not even think possible. This has been a priority from the beginning of my administration when we launched an initiative to allow veterans to connect remotely with their VA healthcare team, and it worked out really well.

We have a 91 percent approval rating in the VA in terms of the job we're doing. This is the first, it's the highest ever recorded. Now, telehealth is a critical part of our path forward in the VA and it's becoming a critical path, especially with our senior citizens. You don't have to go to the doctor's office. You don't have to go to hospitals.

When the invisible enemy struck our shores, I took immediate action to eliminate regulatory barriers to telehealth, making it easier for patients to consult with doctors from safety and convenience. And really they have great safety and great convenience right from their homes.

Today, I'm taking action to ensure telehealth is here to stay. Moments ago in the Oval Office, I signed an Executive Order to make many of our regulatory reforms permanent. We've done some regulatory reforms that have had a tremendous impact on what we're doing on Medicine and medical and what we're doing. They can do things that you wouldn't believe that even a year ago or two years ago would not have been doable.

We're enshrining the right of American patients to meet with their medical providers in a way that is best for them and very, very convenient and very talented people on the other side of the line, I have to tell you.

The order builds upon a series of actions we've all taken to make telehealth available to all. We ensure that Medicare covers telehealth visits at no additional cost. That's no additional costs and co-payments can be waived for telehealth services.

We are working very hard also on prescription drug prices. And I will tell you that the favored nations clause that I've signed into existence -- nobody thought anybody would ever do that -- has a massive impact on prescription drug prices.

In addition to the three other elements of reduction of drugs, particular prescription drugs, but the favored nations clause is massive. For instance, if Germany buys a pill for 10 cents a pill, as an example, just as an example, and the United States pays $2.00 for the same pill, we get the same privilege and the same right as they do. We've never had that before. We paid all of the expenses, all of the research and development. So the numbers are astronomical.

And as you probably noticed, big ads are taken against me by Big Pharma, very big ads, very massive buy, but in the meantime, they're calling, they want to know if they can make a deal. And I say to people, the only reason these ads are being taken is because prices are coming down for you and they understand that. I think our people understand that.

But in particular, when you look at the matching, you could call it matching or you could call it favored nations, call it whatever you like. It's a tremendous -- it's going to have a tremendous and I'm talking about 50 percent, 60 percent, 70 percent. That doesn't mean it goes to 10 cents as an example, but there's comes up and ours goes down.

And you have many, many countries where their numbers -- the numbers are so low. I mean, so low, and by that I mean much lower than the United States.

Another thing I'm doing is if a certain country like Canada -- Canada buys for very much less than the United States has bought. How they allowed this to happen, representatives of our country, standing at these podiums are in the Oval Office, how they allowed this to happen is just to me incredible.

We've been working on this for a long time. I've been talking about it with Kayleigh for a long time, right? So, now a governor like Ron DeSantis of Florida is doing a great job. Our great Governor of Ohio or our great governor of any state can call up and buy the drugs directly from Canada at sometimes 50 percent less. So we'll be buying from Canada.

Now what the drug companies are going to do, maybe they'll raise them, maybe they'll lower them or maybe they'll just give up and sell them to us directly, much cheaper.

So a lot of things are happening. Also the rebate, we have people that are very wealthy that nobody ever heard of them. Nobody knows who they are.

I guess in some cases, they can be pharmacies, in some cases, they are individuals. We're doing a rebate and the rebate goes to the people at the lowest price of drugs.

So we have a series of four things that we signed and you will see over a period of a fairly short period, drug prices are going to be tumbling down at numbers that nobody would have ever believed possible.

We have in 51 years, the only time prices came down was during this administration. It was last year. Fifty one years, it went up. But that was just a small decline. This is a massive decline. This is a decline that nobody can believe.

I was called by senators. I was called by congressmen. Please don't do this. But Big Pharma doesn't mean anything to me other than we want them to do a great job. We want them to get their vaccines. We want them to do what has to be done.

So I think you're going to see drug price reductions over the next four or five or six months, probably take a little while to kick in that are going to be at numbers that you wouldn't believe.

But in the meantime, they called on Friday afternoon. They want to meet, see if they can do something else. They don't like favored nations clauses, I understand that.

We vastly expanded coverage allowing Medicare to cover more than 135 new services through telehealth, by the way, including Physical Therapy, Emergency Department visits, home visits, mental health counseling, substance abuse treatment, which is a very big priority.

We brought the substance abuse at least prior to the China plague, whatever you want to call it, we brought it down very substantially. Pediatric critical care and much more.

Thanks to our actions, an estimated $2 billion of additional funding will support Medicare patients receiving telehealth services. So a very, very big priority on telehealth.

As part of the CARES Act, we secured $200 million to help healthcare providers and hospitals expand their telehealth and they're all doing it. They're doing it gladly.

Prior to the epidemic, or the pandemic, whatever you want to say and how you want to refer to it, but prior to the pandemic, the telehealth was fine, but it wasn't anything raging. And I guess one of the only good things that we've gotten out of this whole horrible situation is telehealth has been incredible.

And again, the increases are, you know, many hundreds of times greater than it was before. Do you have a number? It's like 2,000 percent or something like that. It's an incredible -- it's an incredible increase. You'll get the number, but it's -- I think they have it now finally, and it's really an incredible -- thank you, Kayleigh.

We work with the leaders of major health insurance companies to ensure coverage for the telehealth visits related to coronavirus. We cut red tape to allow many services to be conducted by phone rather than video, which is much simpler, providing a much easier option for many seniors in particular, 35 percent of the Medicare beneficiaries who received telehealth services were over 3.6 million seniors did so over the phone.

So you're talking about 3.6 million seniors -- that's something -- 10.1 million Medicare beneficiaries have access care through telehealth since the beginning of the pandemic. So you're talking there 10.1 million people.

In April, over 43 percent of all Medicare primary care visits were done via telehealth and compared to less than 0.1 percent in February. Those are part of the numbers that I think I'll have you get them, so this part you don't have to, you'll get the other -- the other section. Thank you.

So think of that. Compared to less than 0.1 percent -- 0.1 percent. That's an incredible number. So over 43 percent of all Medicare primary care visits were done via telehealth compared to -- so, it went from 0.1 percent to 43 percent. That's an incredible -- it's an incredible number.

The Executive Order I signed today will also expand healthcare access in rural America. We take care of rural America. It directs agencies to deploy strategic investments in our rural communications infrastructure and we're working very hard with all of the people in government that are involved with the communications infrastructure so that the telehealth gets very quick and easy access.

Additionally, revenue for rural providers vary significantly from month to month making it difficult for many to stay in business. Many, many are having a very difficult time to help fix this problem. My order will create a voluntary Medicare payment system that will give rural hospitals flexibility, really great flexibility, and a more consistent income stream to better serve their patients.

Furthermore, I'm directing the Department of Agriculture, Department of Health and Human Services and the Federal Communications Commission, we were just with the heads of each one in the Oval Office just before I came up to the podium to form a Taskforce that will break down barriers to expanding rural healthcare.

This Order continues my administration's focus on rural healthcare. We allocated nearly $165 million through the CARES Act to support nearly 1,800 small rural hospitals who have done an incredible job, as well as $11.5 million to expand technical assistance for rural and underserved areas.

We allocated another $10 billion to 2,000 rural hospitals and more than 2,400 rural health clinics. We waived burdensome licensing certification and registration requirements which took tremendous amounts of time, and these are people that have great reputations and great track records, for practitioners that serve on the frontlines in rural areas, allowing more medical personnel to serve their wonderful patients.

We're also -- in terms of PPE ensuring that the state and local areas have the supplies they need. We've been supplying hospitals and cities and states. Governors helping governors at a number that nobody has ever heard of before with 15,440 nursing homes that have received a second shipment of personal protective equipment. They're very much stocked up. They're in great shape.

They all have the ventilators, all the ventilators they need. They have actually more than they need, and their equipment -- medical equipment -- is in very, very good shape. They are full.

My administration has worked with the private sector to deliver over 100 million N-95 respirators, 85 million gloves and nearly 250 million face coverings nationwide.

We continue to make the extraordinary progress that we've been talking about together on vaccines and treatments under Operation Warp Speed, which is very exciting, most exciting.

Last week, we distributed 2,979 cases of remdesivir which is proving to be extremely powerful and good, enough to treat more than 19,000 patients. It had great results. This includes 500 cases for Florida, 500 for Texas, 300 for California, 200 for Ohio, and 150 for Arizona and Georgia and those numbers will be going up rapidly as we move along.

Hospitals are reporting an adequate supply of steroids such as dexamethasone that are used successfully in late stage illness. They've been very good.

We're also very encouraged about the prospects for plasma therapies and that we're working on and that's a brilliant art. It's really an art. And we launched a national plasma drive last week. I was at the Red Cross building with the American Red Cross and 13 other healthcare organizations.

I urge everyone who has recovered from the virus to go to coronavirus.gov, coronavirus.gov and donate plasma today. We would really appreciate it. This really makes people better. But we need -- what we need is, we need that beautiful ingredient that you that got better seemed to have in your veins, you have to go to coronavirus.gov and donate plasma today. It will be tremendous. We really appreciate it if you do it because we're low. We are low. We can help a lot more people and it would be a terrific thing.

It'll take an hour, maybe a little bit more than an hour, but everybody will be very appreciative. It makes people better and you know you have something very special. You have something that knocked it out. So we want to be able to use it, so whatever you can do, coronavirus.gov.

As a result of improvements we've made in treatment for Americans over the age of 18, the mortality rate has declined 85 percent from its April peak, 85 percent decline.

On vaccines, last week, we announced the $2.1 billion partnership with Sanofi and GSK to purchase and produce 100 million doses of their coronavirus vaccine, 100 million doses. This is the sixth vaccine candidate we are proactively supporting.

We're supporting numerous companies that are doing very well or having wonderful results, and they are in final stages of testing.

There are now two vaccines in that final stage of clinical trials in America with a third vaccine likely to begin Phase 3 almost immediately.

And we have additional clinical trials scheduled over the next few weeks for a couple of the other companies. These are great companies. These are companies that are not only well-known, they are well-respected, most importantly.

We are balancing speed and safety and we're on pace to have a vaccine available this year, maybe far in advance of the end of the year and we're mass producing the most promising candidates in advance so that we're ready immediately upon approval. We have our military lined up. It's logistics. It's all about logistics.

They deliver a lot of things including soldiers, but now there'll be doing vaccine. Our General is all ready to go and he is very excited and once we have the vaccine approved, fully approved, he will start the process. They will start the process and they'll get it out very, very quickly all over the country and maybe beyond if it works as we think it probably will.

By unleashing America's technical and scientific brilliance, we will end this pandemic and we will hopefully end it very quickly.

The therapeutics are very exciting to me where you can go into a hospital and whether it's through a shot or a transfusion, you take care of somebody and they get better. That's something to me. It is very important. And we're doing really well on therapeutics and really well on vaccine.

So thank you all very much for being here. We'll take a couple of questions.

DOBBS: President Trump in the White House announcing his Executive Order to improve rural access to health and telehealth care, updating us on the fight against the China virus.

Join us tomorrow night for my exclusive interview with President Trump right here on the Fox Business Network.

And a reminder of my new book, "The Trump Century: How Our President Changed the Course of History," available for preorder right now at thetrumpcentury.com and amazon.com.

Thanks for being with us. Good night from Sussex.
