urn:contentItem:5P3P-5H51-JBHT-D3F5-00000-00President Trump is Asking the Republicans to Vote on Obamacare Before the August Recess; Google's Parent Company Alphabet Had a Huge Drop2017-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:27ZLexisNexisPresident Trump is Asking the Republicans to Vote on Obamacare Before the August Recess; Google's Parent Company Alphabet Had a Huge DropLanhamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The American people have waited long enough, there's been enough talk, and no action. Now is the time for action. Every pledge that Washington democrats made, to pass that bill, turned out to be a lie. It was a big, fat, ugly lie.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: President Trump fighting for a victory against the D.C. swamp still, President Trump just calling out republican senators saying now is the time to get things done after meeting with victims of Obamacare earlier today. Senate republicans expected to vote sometime this week, perhaps as early as tomorrow to begin debate on Obamacare reform.

Welcome to Risk & Reward. I'm Liz MacDonald in for Deirdre Bolton.

The Dow closing down 66 points today, the NASDAQ ending at an all-time high with big tech earnings. But Alphabet, the parent of the search giant Google just reported a drop in second quarter profit. It was hurt by more than $2.7 billion fine from European antitrust regulators.

Now let's get back to the president, speaking on healthcare reform this afternoon pushing to get Obamacare reform through before the August recess. He issued a warning yesterday, saying "If republicans do not repeal and replace Obamacare the disastrous Obamacare, the repercussions will be far greater than any of them understand."

This as new CBO numbers demolish the democrat fear mongering, the analysis showing nearly three quarters of the 22 million estimated who will drop coverage under Obamacare reform, will do so voluntarily, they'll choose to drop it when the individual mandate tax goes away. That's according to the CBO analysis brought to us by the National Review.

In other words, 16 million will voluntarily drop out of the market by 2026 because it will no longer face a financial penalty for doing so. No talk of that in Congress, instead of the democrats like Chuck Schumer they say they want to buy partisan fix with the GOP.

But behind the scenes, democrats now in both the House and the Senate, they see a jackpot pass to victory in winning back Congress next year, their big plan is big government health Medicare for all, which in theory provides nearly universal coverage through the government rather than private insurer.

Bow Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said on ABC on Sunday that quote, "We are going to look at broader things for the nation's healthcare system, singer payer is one of them."

Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren already mapping out victory next year on single payer. Jimmy Carter just moments ago saying the U.S. eventually will have single payer, and the CEO of one of five largest public insurers in the U.S. he is a CEO, he is Mark Bertolini, though he's not for single payer he reportedly recently did say at a private conference that U.S. should start considering it.

And business titan Warren Buffet and Charlie Munger are also recently supporting the single payer idea.

Let's take it to former Florida Congressman, he is retired lieutenant colonel Allen West. He joins me now. Colonel, what do you think of this democrat momentum behind single payer and Medicare for all?

ALLEN WEST, FORMER UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE: Well, it's good to be with you, Liz. And first of all, that has always been the intention for the Democrat Party. If you really look at Obamacare the Patient Protection Affordable Care Act was doomed to fail. When we look at co-ops when we look at the exchanges, we look at the lack of insurance coverage out there this is all resolved.

It is not affordable. We know that. It is not protective patients. And I find it very interesting that Jimmy Carter would come out and speak about a single pair system because it was in 1978 that President Carter said that every American had the right to own a home with his Community Reinvestment Act.

And 30 years later we had a financial collapse that was due to the mortgage crisis here in the United States of America which began with his logic. So here once again we're going to try to have a Medicaid or Medicare for all, when the almost 66 percent of federal budget right now, Medicare, Medicaid, and social security that interest of the debt is consumed by these mandatory spending programs, that means that we're not going to be able to afford.

MACDONALD: Yes. Irving Institute, to your point, says that Medicare for all will cost $32 trillion over 10 years, the first is cost alone, Colonel, $2.5 trillion, that's more than the market value of Google, Apple, Microsoft, AT, and Facebook combined.

WEST: No, you're absolutely right. And so it ends up consuming, which is one-sixth of our economy healthcare, it will end up consuming our entire budget. And it's interesting that recently out in California they tried to go with a single payer system there, and they pulled the legislation because it will cost too much. What does that tell you?

MACDONALD: Yes, we're going to get to that in a second. But first this, sir. Minnesota democrat and deputy chair of the DNC, he is Keith Ellison he is now pushing for America to become like Cuba when it comes to healthcare. Let's take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEITH ELLISON, (D) UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE: Why is it the countries like Cuba or Canada or Russia or a lot of places in this world spend half of what we spend per capita and they got better health outcomes than we do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Canada, I mean, they are flying here for their health outcomes.

WEST: Yes.

MACDONALD: And does this show the ignorance of democrats like Keith Ellison. I mean, in Cuba it's been showing time and again that party elites, the military foreign tourists, they get the best medical care while the Cuban workers and the Cuban people are left with dirty hospitals and disarray and shortages of medicine.

WEST: You're absolutely right. And you know, when I represented the people down in South Florida, I never saw any boats leaving South Florida to go to Cuba for healthcare. Just the same as when we have these snowbirds that came down from Canada, they would have an incredible influx of Canadians coming in for healthcare appointments, things that they could not get done because of the single payer system in Canada.

So, I think he fells and if he really thinks socialize medicine is so great maybe he can go down to Venezuela and get a, you know, a medical appointment there.

MACDONALD: Yes, it's an interesting point. You know, Colonel, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders t what you were just noting earlier, he is ripping into California democrats for pulling back on a $400 billion single payer healthcare bill, they are worried in California about cost concerns, that's 400 billion is more than double the size of California's budget. And didn't Bernie Sanders home State of Vermont single payer almost bankrupt the state? I mean 400 billion quickly becomes 800 billion, right?

WEST: No, you're absolutely right. And when you think about the CalPERS the pension plan out there for the government bureaucracy and the union that they have in California, you talk about a state that's going bankrupt. We see cities in the State of California that are going bankrupt.

And so they know that this is a failing system. Single payer does not work. Ask the parents of Charlie Gard over in England how they feel about the single payer system when the government is making the decisions about whether or not their child can live.

MACDONALD: It's a good point. Meantime, the president's son-in-law, he is White House senior adviser, Jared Kushner, he was on Capitol Hill testifying behind closed-doors. He was not under oath on the investigation of Russia's involvement in the 2016 election. Let's take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JARED KUSHNER, PRESIDENT TRUMP'S SON-IN-LAW: I did not collude with Russia, nor do I know of anyone else in the campaign who did so. I had no improper contacts. I have not relied on Russian funds for my businesses. And I have been fully transparent in providing all requested information. Donald Trump had a better message and ran a smarter campaign and that is why he won.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: You know, Mr. Kushner also said he did not read e-mails that showed the president's eldest son Donald Trump, Jr. accepted this June 2016 meeting with the idea that he would get damaging information about Hillary Clinton. Colonel, what do you think of Mr. Kushner today?

WEST: Well, I think that he did what was the right thing, to go and put this to rest, but it's never going to be put to rest. You know, we need the people there on Capitol Hill the House and Senate republicans who are in charge to say enough of this already, enough of taxpayer funds that have been wasted on this witch-hunt that is a conviction that is looking for evidence. That's basically what it is.

Let's talk about Hillary Clinton and her uranium deals. Let's talk about the fact that we are going to have more flexibility after our reelection with Russia with what President Obama said. let's talk about the leaks that are emanating out of Washington, D.C. of classified information. That's where the focus should be.

MACDONALD: Yes. Mr. Kushner is expected to basically testify before a House panel, House intelligence tomorrow. We believe it's not under oath that it could be behind closed. It's not going to be held public.

To your point, President Trump tweeting out, "So why aren't the committees investigators and of course, our beleaguered A.G. Jeff Sessions looking into crooked Hillary's crimes and Russia relations." Another shot Jeff Sessions there. What do you think of President Trump's tweet right there?

WEST: You know, if this one thing you never want to criticize a member of your team, especially an attorney general. And I think that that does not do bode well for bolstering his position of influence and his position of power as the attorney general when you have the president that is putting out those types of tweets. Or when you have the interview that he did last week in New York Times. If you got a problem with Attorney General Sessions you need to do it off line behind closed doors.

MACDONALD: You know, Kushner said that raising questions about Russian election activity ridicules people who voted for Trump, saying Donald Trump had a better message and ran a smatter campaign, and that is why he won. He is saying suggesting otherwise, ridicules those who voted for him.

I mean, here is the thing, Colonel, we have a number of probes into Russia, including Robert Mueller, they'll get to the bottom of it. Do you agree with Jared Kushner on that point?

WEST: Well, I think that this is a big distraction, when you look at the polling out there the American people are not concerned about Russia. The American people are concerned about getting back to work. The American are concerned about affordable healthcare. The American people are concerned about economic growth and they are concerned national security.

But you see once again, the Democrat Party is becoming a party of distractions not even resistance. So I think we need to get discipline, we need to get focused and someone needs to tell Mr. Mueller, you got 30 days or 60 days whatever, if you don't come up with something based upon your original guidance and the purpose, then you should be -- this thing should be ended.

MACDONALD: Thank you, Colonel. Good to see you. Come back soon.

WEST: Always a pleasure, Liz.

MACDONALD: Search giant Google's parent company Alphabet reporting a second quarter profit that dropped sharply versus a year before. It was hurt by a big $2.74 billion anti-trust fine out of Europe. Shares off almost 3 percent in after-hours trading despite being up more than 25 percent year-to-date.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer taking a page from President Trump's playbook, and now the democrats now plan to focus on jobs. The man who confronted Hillary for killing coal jobs during the election is here. He is West Virginia coal miner Bo Copley, he will respond.

Also later in show, a musician calling out millennials with a parody song, he is here to talk about it later in the show, so stick around, it's pretty funny.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHUCK SCHUMER, (D) UNITED STATES SENATOR: When you lose an election with someone who has a 40 percent popularity, you look in the mirror and say what did we do wrong. And the number one things that we did wrong is we didn't have -- we didn't tell people what we stood before, even today. Week after week, month after month, we're going to roll out specific pieces here that are quite different than the Democratic Party you head in the past, we were too cautious, we were too namby-pamby.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Well, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer now acknowledging that democrats have a big brand image problem. He is now trying to argue that the democrats lost the last election, well, they lost four elections since 2010 because the democrats did not tell the working voter what the democrats stand for.

Polls show that majority think democrats stand for just opposing Trump. But now Schumer said democrats are trying to sell a better deal for the American worker. Let's listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SCHUMER: We're going to raise people's wages and create better paying jobs. We're going to cut down on their everyday expenses they have to pay. And we're going to give them the tools they need to compete in the 21th century.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: No details on exactly how the democrats' plan to do that. U.S. voters saw what the democrats stood for going back to 2010. They rejected their big tax, big government spending big government regulation back -- starting in 2010 through 2016.

And despite all of this attack even Chuck Schumer himself said a few years ago, that Obama should not have focused on big government spending on that $800 billion stimulus plan, instead he should have focused on jobs and growth.

And we just showed you government data showing 863,000 jobs have been added since President Trump took office. The U.S. labor market rebounded in June ending 222,000 jobs.

Let's go to West Virginia coal miner who confronted Hillary Clinton about trying to get rid of coal jobs during the last election, he is Bo Copley, he joins me now. Good to see you, Bo. What do you think of what Chuck Schumer is now saying?

BO COPLEY, COAL MINER: Thanks for having us on, Liz.

I think it's interesting that I guess they see now that, you know, the working class people were a huge factor in what got Donald Trump elected as president. I don't think that -- I don't think their message was not what we stand for, you know, not telling people what we stand for is how we lost the election. I think they told people what they stood for. And I think it was a complete paradox to what the working class American is.

I think what they telling people that they stood for was handouts and a lot of free things that they were promising that came off of the backs of the working class.

MACDONALD: That's a good point. I mean, the democrats have been saying, you know, you didn't build that. The government helped you build that, you're too stupid to understand Obamacare, that was Jonathan Gruber, the economist who said that.

And Schumer is now saying, Bo, that Trump actually used, he used American workers to get elected. Do you agree with that?

COPLEY: Absolutely, he used them. He told us what we wanted to hear, and we put him into office. And so far he is trying very hard to deliver on the promises that he made us. So, you know, I don't know if use is the right word, but he told us what we wanted to hear, and so far he is working very hard to make that happen.

MACDONALD: All right. So, I mean, it's been eight years where I think the American voter has seen what the democrats are about. And I think it's really about, you know, incumbency is the problem. I mean, Nancy Pelosi has been around since the Reagan era, Chuck Schumer has been around for 30 years.

And what they're suggesting, Bo is it looks like more big government Bernie Sanders ideas and small government pro-growth tax cut like JFK. What do you think?

COPLEY: Well, you know, if you look at our state, Liz, our state is predominantly been a democratic state, and that's one of the reasons why we're doing what we're doing. I'm a firm believer in term limits, and that's one of the reasons why we're running for Senate.

You know, we have a democratic representative in Joe Manchin who as you know was for Hillary Clinton and was opposed to President Trump. And you know, his alliance with Democratic Party -- our state has turned completely around so much so that we haven't carried a democratic president since Bill Clinton a second term.

And you know, I think the people of this state have realized that how far that the Democratic Party has shifted over the last 20 to 30 years, and that they are starting to see that you know, they're not the party that they should be and they're not representing the state the way that they should.

MACDONALD: You know, so we had Hillary Clinton and the democrats going after coal jobs, and now Chuck Schumer saying he wants to go after the big companies and the grocery business and healthcare, and the cable business. I mean, to that end, the democrats have also reportedly settled on a new slogan and tag line for next year's elections, Bo.

And it sound really familiar, Bo. I want you to take a listen to the democrat -- what the democrat's new slogan sound like. Let's listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Better ingredients, better pizza, Papa John's.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Yes, Bo, they are being made fun of for their new slogan. What do you think? Their new slogan by the way, Bo, is a better deal, let's show it. A better jobs, better wages, better future. I mean, let's see, make America great again versus that, what do you think?

COPLEY: Well, I am all for making America great again for sure. You know, you can slice things up the way you want to and serve it the way that you want to. But ultimately, you have to know what kind of substance is behind this kind of promises; you can't just throw those out there.

So they may be able to make a better wage or whatever the rest of that tag is. But we need to see how they plan on doing it and see if it's something that's viable to the American people.

MACDONALD: Yes, they're making it like there is a big government pizza pie of income that the government get the slice up at hands out, but that's not how it works, right, Bo? You've seen that.

COPLEY: Well, I know for us, in any thin we've ever wanted we had to go out and work for it. So I'm not sure that, I'm not sure how much the government is slicing up and handing out, I'm sure we are to a plenty of people.

MACDONALD: Yes.

COPLEY: And I think that's a -- I think those are the kind of people that we have to kind of trying wean off of the kinds of the programs that we have right now.

MACDONALD: Bo Copley, it's good to see you. Thanks so much for coming on. We love having you on.

COPLEY: Thanks for having us on, Liz. And if you don't care, go out and take a look at boforw.com.

MACDONALD: OK.

COPLEY: And check out our policies.

MACDONALD: Sure. Thank you, Bo. Thanks again.

Now this, even as gas prices drop to a 12-year low, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer claiming the prices have only gone up. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SCHUMER: People hate it when their cable bills go up, their airline fees. They know that gas prices they're sticky, you know, when the domestic price goes -- when the price for oil goes up on the market. It goes right up but it never goes down.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Well, national average price of gas settling today $2.28 a gallon of regular, down from $2.32, per gallon when President Trump took office. Gas prices actually going down.

Next, newly minted White House Communications Director Anthony Scaramucci taking on CNN for the first time. We've got the highlights.

Also a musician deciding to write a song, calling out today's millennial, his video now going viral, he is here talk about it later in the show, so stick around

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Newly minted White House Communications Director Anthony Scaramucci taking on CNN for the first time in his official role.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAKE TAPPER, HOST, CNN: A lot of people, Anthony, will read that op-ed, they'll read the tweets that you spent the weekend deleting that were pro- gun control.

ANTHONY SCARAMUCCI, WHITE HOUSE COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR: Yes.

TAPPER: Pro-action on climate change and they all think, wowm this guy is willing to suppress everything he believes in order to get close to power. What is your answer?

SCARAMUCCI: That's true.

TAPPER: What is your answer to that?

SCARAMUCCI: That's totally -- especially that's a ridiculous Washington sort of narrative. Let me tell you something about demagoguery that I don't like, OK? Demagoguery, OK, creates a lot of nonsense like this. He's going to win again, Jake, he's going to win again. I will bring a box of Kleenex over here to CNN.

(CROSSTALK)

TAPPER: You don't -- we don't need Kleenex.

SCARAMUCCI: He will win in 2020. He is going to win, Jake.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Let's take a look at Time Warner stock, the parent company of CNN closing slightly in the green for the day. The stock is up year over year.

Joining me now Donald J. Trump for president advisory board member, he is Jeff DeWit. Good to see you, Jeff.

JEFF DEWIT, FORMER ARIZONA STATE TREASURER: Great to see you, Liz. Thanks for having me.

MACDONALD: It looks like you are already working on President Trump's next election, right?

DEWIT: Well, you know, there are a lot of people out there that can't wait to support him in all the upcoming elections. And he know he's going to have a lot to say even over the midterms because he does control a big voting block of patriotic Americans.

MACDONALD: Yes.

DEWIT: They are going to support the candidates that support him.

MACDONALD: Well, you see what Jake tapper was asking Scaramucci, you deleted tweets, you know, he's just trying to get close to power, you did not support President Trump, you're for other candidates. What did you think of that interview there?

DEWIT: I thought Anthony handled himself very well, you know, he is very, very sharp, he's very capable and he's very popular within the campaign. He is a doer and I think he brings an authentic voice to this. I don't want to saying about Sean, he's a great guy. But Anthony really brings that business minded voice that really speaks more for Donald Trump I think.

I thought Anthony handled himself very well. So far everything he has done has been great. You know, look, people have evolve from their views, and so if you're looking for something from a long time with some things he said, yes, things are different as they evolve.

MACDONALD: Yes.

DEWIT: You know, there is a famous quote in politics that it says, if you're not a democrat in your 20s you don't have a heart, and if you haven't turn a republican by your 30s you don't have a brain. So, people have evolved in their views. But I know where Anthony stands now and he aligns wholly with Donald Trump's agenda.

MACDONALD: You see, it's interesting throughout this whole process you see whether it's a democrat or a republican guest, the journalists asking the question, doesn't like to be asked questions back or challenge, that's clear here in what we're seeing unfold in Washington, the D.C. beltway and the media coverage.

You know, Anthony Scaramucci also vowed to take drastic action to stop White House leaks. Let's listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SCARAMUCCI: If the leaks don't stop, I'm going to pare down the staff because it's just not right for us. I think it's not fair to the president; it's actually not fair to America or the people in the government. But something is going on inside the White House that the president does not like and we're going to fix it.

I would like to reset the culture inside that commerce department so that people recognize that I'm actually there to serve them.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Jeff, where are the leaks coming from?

DEWIT: You know, the leaks are from people that have their own political agenda.

MACDONALD: Who?

DEWIT: Either they're leftover from Obama.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Is it just Obama?

DEWIT: I don't know. Personally, I can't name names.

MACDONALD: Is it just Obama officials? Well, who...

DEWIT: No, you know, there are people in there that seem to have their own agenda, but what they don't realize they're not just trying -- thwarting the Donald Trump agenda. But they are actually causing harm for our country. I mean, this puts our country at risk.

The fact that Russia knows now that we can listen to the conversations between, you know, Putin and his ambassador, I don't -- that was because of a leak. Now Russia obviously is going to scramble their communications or do something different, that's something that should never be out there.

But it's also dragging good people through the mud. You look at Jared Kushner who on his own, he went down, he has to go down, he shows everything. But this is someone who is a patriotic American, a hardworking very successful man, who is a great dad and a great husband, but now has to go down and have all his business looked into because of these leaks...

MACDONALD: Yes.

DEWIT: ... for people just trying to thwart it. So these are great people that are getting drag to the mud and they shouldn't be. And again, go back to Comey hearings.

MACDONALD: Yes.

DEWIT: There is no evidence that Russia did anything in the campaign. I can tell you as the COO of the campaign, there was no involvement with other countries.

MACDONALD: Right. And to your point, Susan Rice is no longer expected to testify about unmasking. She's no longer expected to testify for lawmakers.

We did have President Trump's son-in-law, White House senior adviser, Jared Kushner, as you point out, Jeff. He met with Senate intelligence committee today. He said he did not collude with Russians. He is expected to speak to House intelligence tomorrow, where is this headed?

DEWIT: Well, it's headed nowhere, because we all inside the campaign know that there is nothing there. We won because Donald Trump is a great candidate with a superior message that resonated to all the hardworking patriotic Americans in the Midwest that were sick of the politicians shipping their jobs overseas. That's why Donald Trump won.

And if the race were held again today, he would beat Hillary Clinton by a bigger margin. So it's going nowhere. I think what the best thing was Chuck Schumer yesterday, basically and the Democratic Party admitting why they lost, as you point out, which is because they don't have a message anymore.

They don't have an economic platform, and now they're adapting Donald Trump's message to try to promote that. So it's going to go nowhere. And to see good people like Jared get dragged through the mud, it's not fair. It's not fair to him and it's not fair to America.

MACDONALD: OK.

DEWIT: Let's move on, let's get down to the business of fixing our country.

MACDONALD: Jeff DeWit, good to see you. Thanks for coming on the show.

DEWIT: Always great, Liz. Thank you.

MACDONALD: Next up, the wildfires in Canada pushing up the price of lumber as that fire threatens the supply to U.S. homebuilders.

Canada's wildfires it turned out to be the toughest on the lumber industry in over a decade. Homebuilders in the U.S. now fear that prices might climb even higher as wholesalers try to restock in the midst of this price surge due to the really just destructive fire. It's real tragedy going on there.

We have a New York Times reporter feeling the heat after accusing white women of showing racism on sidewalks. Coming up, hear how he thinks white women show racism. Also, you know, getting a better education -- is getting a better education for your children is that racist? Is school choice racist?

The American Federation of Teachers president, Randi Weingarten seems to think so. We're going to have her comments after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Is getting a better education for your children racist? The American Federation of Teachers president, Randi Weingarten think that school choice is racist. She also said that's a movement to give parents more say over where their children go to school has its roots in, not just racism but also sexism, classism, xenophobia and homophobia. Calling the programs, quote, polite cousins of segregation.

Let's look at education stocks like Strayer Education and American Public closing in the red today.

Joining me now, Independent Women's Forum, Patrice Onwuka, and democrat strategist, Danielle McLaughlin. First to you, Patrice. Randi Weingarten continues to say quote, "This privatization and this investment are only slightly more polite cousins of segregation." Is that a little over broad?

PATRICE LEE ONWUKA, SENIOR FELLOW, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S FORUM: It absolutely is. It's a great way of trying to whip up some support by claiming racism when, in fact, when we look at the most segregated schools and district they happened to be in democratically controlled cities.

MACDONALD: You know, Danielle, school choice, doesn't actually help low income minority children? I mean, Florida's private school choice program the largest in the nation, 68 percent of the scholarship recipients are minorities, right?

DANIELLE MCLAUGHLIN, DEMOCRAT STRATEGIST: Sure. And there is a place for charter schools. I think we can all agree upon that public schools have allowed just some educated in this country 90 percent of children go to public schools.

So, I think what critics are saying is that we need the funding, we need to make sure that those public schools are taken care of because public schools means community and that's a very important part of just our society in general.

MACDONALD: And reform, right? So, we have a New York Times reporter, let's switch gears now, you guys, the New York Times reporting now facing a blow back for an essay calling out white women saying white women are racist. In the piece titled was that racist. Greg Howard writes, quote, "When white women are in my path on the street, they almost always continue straight, forcing me to one side without changing their course. Why only and specifically white women, do they refuse to acknowledge me, because they have been taught that they should fear black men. And that any acknowledgment of black men can invite danger."

Let's just take a quick check on New York Times stock closing the day in the green of about 5 bucks year over year. Patrice, is what he's describing is that racism?

ONWUKA: No, I think it's looking for racism where it isn't. I mean, certainly, there is a sense of entitlement that's replaced common courtesy, but you know, when you're looking for racism in every single place, you become kind of a chicken little, and then the real instances where it does occur become, you know, it look absurd. People don't believe them anymore.

And I talked to a black man who happens to be my husband about this issue, and he said, you know what? I think it has a lot more to do with people not being courteous than it is for some sort of targeting by this, by white women against black men.

MACDONALD: You know, Danielle, another quote from that piece read quote. "As a black man, I learned that body checking, bumping or even rubbing against a random white woman can be personally hazardous." What did you make of the piece, is this race basing what he is describing?

MCLAUGHLIN: I didn't think it was race basing. I thought it was certainly provocative and that's what this is meant to be if the call and states it very clearly that this is what this is meant to be about. Challenging, I'm a white woman, I walk the streets of New York City, I'm not engaging in any of these behaviors.

And I think it's problematic when you take your own personal experience and you expand it out to an entire population. And actually I agree that this - - I don't think this is an instance of racism. We should be focused on the real instances of racism with the institutional or otherwise.

MACDONALD: That's a good point. So, Patrice, if this column this story was edited before publication, why do you supposed the New York Times did not pull the story and instead chose to ran with it?

NWUKA: Because it's provocative, it gets people talking about it. I mean, we've seen on Twitter how it blew up as a good way of drawing people into this whole discussion. Apparently they are soliciting stories from people talking about the question was this racist. You know, what's my, somebody calling out tall, black marquees at Starbucks, an example of racism. When in fact it was just, the guy was tall, and black and his copy was tall and black and his name was Marquee (Ph).

So, it's another way of just kind of seeding racism where it doesn't necessarily need to be, and again, attracting readers and viewership.

MACDONALD: Patrice and Danielle, thanks so much for your thoughts there. Good to see you, guys.

MCLAUGHLIN: Thank you.

MACDONALD: KKR betting big on healthy living. Now the private equity giants plans to buy WebMD health corp for 2.8 billion bucks. KKR will combine WebMD's web site with its internet brand Unit which own sites like Dentalplans.com and allaboutcounselling.com extending its footprints in the web health market.

Next up, ruthless human smugglers blamed for the deaths of now 10 people left in a truck in 100-degree Texas in San Antonio at a Wal-Mart. My next guest says, sanctuary city are partly to blame. Former Immigration and Customs agent, he is also border patrol agent, he is David Ward. He joins me next. Don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: The death toll now rising to 10 in what police are calling a horrific human smuggling case where people died inside a sweltering 18- wheelering in San Antonio, about 150 miles from the U.S./Mexico border. Two died after the incident. Eight died inside the truck. A total of 39 people were inside the tractor.

At one point it was estimated 100 people were there in. At least two of those who were injured were 15-year-old school age children. The driver now in federal custody he is facing criminal charges, federal charges filed today in federal court.

Joining me now, former Immigration and Customs agent and former U.S Border Patrol agent, he is David Ward. David, one of the immigrant passengers said people took turns breathing through a hole in the wall of the tractor trailer. Now, sir, we know that border crossings are down under President Trump, but what needs to be done to stop awful crimes like this?

DAVID WARD, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF FORMER BORDER PATROL AGENTS: Look, they are going to continue smuggling until we curtail the sanctuary cities and until we put a secure border on our -- a secure fence on our border. The cartels thrive on alien smuggling in addition to narcotics trafficking. And both issues involve sanctuary cities. We have a huge opioid problem. We have a huge alien smuggling problem and it all revolves around sanctuary cities.

MACDONALD: How do we know that this case of the 10 who are now dead and the 39 injured, how do you know that this is connected to sanctuary cities?

WARD: By the statements that were made that they were going to Houston, and I believe there were other statements made in another sanctuary city, those are sanctuary cities in the United States, the smugglers have opened up their operations there. There is over 500 sanctuary cities in the United States, but there is also over 500 cities that are influenced by Mexican cartels and also the same cities.

If you got the DEA map of the drug cartel cities in the United States, and the DEA just map of all the sanctuary city they are one and the same. So any time you have a large operation like this it's going to have involve sanctuary cities.

MACDONALD: And sir, in response to this incident, Texas lieutenant governor, he is Dan Patrick, he applauded laws against sanctuary cities in a Facebook post. Writing quote, "Today's tragedy is why I made passing Texas Senate bill 4 to ban sanctuary cities in the state a top priority. Now sanctuary cities entice to believe they can come to America in Texas and live outside the law. Sanctuary cities also enable human smugglers and cartels."

What is your reaction to that?

WARD: Well, I absolutely agree with the governor. In fact, I don't understand a lot of these chiefs of police in the sanctuary cities who come out and state that if they enforce immigration law that they wouldn't have witnesses to testify in their cases, criminal cases.

The thing of it is that the same people that are witnesses are actually the ones committing the crimes. And until they got a hand on the sanctuary cities our crime is going to continue to go up. Look at the opioid problem, we have thousands of people dying now. It's so bad that the Reagan they put opioid treatment into the new healthcare bill. That's how bad it is.

If they would address the illegal alien population in these cities they would take that attraction away.

MACDONALD: You know, sir, the acting head of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement basically agency, naming the worst sanctuary cities in the country as Chicago, New York City and San Francisco, he is calling them quote, "un-American," do you agree with that?

WARD: Absolutely. All these officials have taken an oath to our U.S. Constitution to support and defend all the laws of this country. And yet, here they are pushing away the immigration law, making it difficult for immigration agents to even operate in those city, turning their backs on our officers and in fact, they even are endangering our officers who are out there trying to do their job in the sanctuary cities, but not getting the support they needed from their local counterparts.

MACDONALD: Mr. Ward, thank you for coming on the show. We really appreciate it.

WARD: You're quite welcome, Liz. Have a good day.

MACDONALD: We're awaiting President Trump's speech at the National Boy Scout jamboree in West Virginia. We will bring it to you when the president arrives.

Next up, we have this story for you. Millennials often criticized as spoiled and bratty, lazy. Maybe that's unfair, not very nice. But we've got one musician he decides to write a song about that. He is musician Micah Tyler, he is here to talk about the motivation beyond -- behind his millennial parody, it's now going viral. You're going to stay for this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Pretty funny. Millennials often criticized as spoiled, entitled even lazy. That inspired my next guest to write a song. Musician Micah Tyler has a new album coming out called different, it's debuting October 20th.

Music industry sellers, streamers, producer like Sony, Apple, Sirius. Let's take a look at their stock, they're closing the day mixed today. Amazon is hitting a new all-time high.

Let's bring in Micah Tyler to talk about his song. Good to see you, Micah.

MICAH TYLER, MUSICIAN: Hey, good to see you, guys too. Thanks for having me.

MACDONALD: How did come up with the song? It's pretty funny.

TYLER: Well, it's one of those things. The little inspiration probably came from the mirror, I'm actually a millennial myself. And I got a call from a church conference. The church that I parody with over in Dallas, the church it's called Watermark Church. And they had called me and asked me if I would bring up and make up some different songs.

I've appeared for them before, kind of interim people but they want the intros in different topics that have some stigmas that have some stereotypes attach to them, one of the topics was millennials. They asked me to make a song that would kind of intro the topic, and in context it made a lot more sense.

The video played listing every stereotype that I could find that I could or think of that they've given me, and then we made the song, it was followed by this talk about how millennials are more in the stereotypes that are attached to them, that were a generation that history hope to be looked back on us being -- trying to explore new things and dream really big and go out there and make a difference with this growing up and not be, you know, held to our coffee and Instagrams.

MACDONALD: I think you just have -- yes, that's a good point. You just have a line in the song, I think that millennial could be our next president. But here is another part of the song that is funny. Let's -- it's at the end. Let's take a listen.

(MUSIC PLAYING)

MACDONALD: So you took that into a funeral dirge there, Micah. You agree that we are going to have a millennial president. What are you worried about?

TYLER: Listen, the thing is if we want to live up to the generalities that have been in place on your generation, then yes. We're in for quite four years one day. But you know, this is all totally done, tongue in cheek, it must be something really fun. It was just done for this conference, we didn't even know that it was going to be put up on Facebook, we did it last April.

The church posted it and it kind of went nuts and the last year it had over 100 million views. It got (Inaudible) research and someone posted it last week it has another, you know, 15 million view this week. But again, the context of it was to be something fun, to kind of just laugh at ourselves a little bit, some of the labels that have been attached to us. But you know, I'm hoping we can get it together. I had hope for our generation.

MACDONALD: You know, one of my Twitter followers, what song is Micah parodying? What's the name of it? Tweet me your answer.

TYLER: Fine.

MACDONALD: College students in Berkeley and NYU burned things down to block conservative speakers from speaking. So, what is -- when you those stories what was your reaction?

TYLER: Here's the deal. We -- it would be really hard thing if every time that some one person did something we would completely blanket an entire generation, and entire people group, an entire age whatever, with some decisions that people have their own freewill to be able to make. All I can do...

MACDONALD: OK.

TYLER: ... is try to be encouraging and try to be positive out there.

MACDONALD: There you go, Micah, your new album, Different, out October 20th. We wish you good luck, sir. Thanks for coming on.

Donald Trump just tweeting out any senator who votes again starting debate is telling America that you are fine with the Obamacare nightmare. The president also posted of his remarks echoing that earlier today.

This follows Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell saying on the floor that the vote to proceed on debating health reform will start tomorrow. Senate majority whip John Cornyn says Senate John McCain diagnosed with brain cancer, he is trying to get approval for his travel arrangements to possibly show up for a vote. We're on that story for you. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: President Trump about to speak to the boy scouts in West Virginia at the National Boy Scouts jamboree. Fox Business will bring it to you live when the president speaks.

That does it for us tonight. Thank you for having us in your homes. Melissa Francis with Making Money next.

END

urn:contentItem:5P3P-5H51-JBHT-D3FM-00000-00President Trump is Asking the Republicans to Vote on Obamacare Before the August Recess; Google's Parent Company Alphabet Had a Huge Drop2017-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:28ZLexisNexisPresident Trump is Asking the Republicans to Vote on Obamacare Before the August Recess; Google's Parent Company Alphabet Had a Huge DropLanhamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The American people have waited long enough, there's been enough talk, and no action. Now is the time for action. Every pledge that Washington democrats made, to pass that bill, turned out to be a lie. It was a big, fat, ugly lie.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: President Trump fighting for a victory against the D.C. swamp still, President Trump just calling out republican senators saying now is the time to get things done after meeting with victims of Obamacare earlier today. Senate republicans expected to vote sometime this week, perhaps as early as tomorrow to begin debate on Obamacare reform.

Welcome to Risk & Reward. I'm Liz MacDonald in for Deirdre Bolton.

The Dow closing down 66 points today, the NASDAQ ending at an all-time high with big tech earnings. But Alphabet, the parent of the search giant Google just reported a drop in second quarter profit. It was hurt by more than $2.7 billion fine from European antitrust regulators.

Now let's get back to the president, speaking on healthcare reform this afternoon pushing to get Obamacare reform through before the August recess. He issued a warning yesterday, saying "If republicans do not repeal and replace Obamacare the disastrous Obamacare, the repercussions will be far greater than any of them understand."

This as new CBO numbers demolish the democrat fear mongering, the analysis showing nearly three quarters of the 22 million estimated who will drop coverage under Obamacare reform, will do so voluntarily, they'll choose to drop it when the individual mandate tax goes away. That's according to the CBO analysis brought to us by the National Review.

In other words, 16 million will voluntarily drop out of the market by 2026 because it will no longer face a financial penalty for doing so. No talk of that in Congress, instead of the democrats like Chuck Schumer they say they want to buy partisan fix with the GOP.

But behind the scenes, democrats now in both the House and the Senate, they see a jackpot pass to victory in winning back Congress next year, their big plan is big government health Medicare for all, which in theory provides nearly universal coverage through the government rather than private insurer.

Bow Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said on ABC on Sunday that quote, "We are going to look at broader things for the nation's healthcare system, singer payer is one of them."

Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren already mapping out victory next year on single payer. Jimmy Carter just moments ago saying the U.S. eventually will have single payer, and the CEO of one of five largest public insurers in the U.S. he is a CEO, he is Mark Bertolini, though he's not for single payer he reportedly recently did say at a private conference that U.S. should start considering it.

And business titan Warren Buffet and Charlie Munger are also recently supporting the single payer idea.

Let's take it to former Florida Congressman, he is retired lieutenant colonel Allen West. He joins me now. Colonel, what do you think of this democrat momentum behind single payer and Medicare for all?

ALLEN WEST, FORMER UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE: Well, it's good to be with you, Liz. And first of all, that has always been the intention for the Democrat Party. If you really look at Obamacare the Patient Protection Affordable Care Act was doomed to fail. When we look at co-ops when we look at the exchanges, we look at the lack of insurance coverage out there this is all resolved.

It is not affordable. We know that. It is not protective patients. And I find it very interesting that Jimmy Carter would come out and speak about a single pair system because it was in 1978 that President Carter said that every American had the right to own a home with his Community Reinvestment Act.

And 30 years later we had a financial collapse that was due to the mortgage crisis here in the United States of America which began with his logic. So here once again we're going to try to have a Medicaid or Medicare for all, when the almost 66 percent of federal budget right now, Medicare, Medicaid, and social security that interest of the debt is consumed by these mandatory spending programs, that means that we're not going to be able to afford.

MACDONALD: Yes. Irving Institute, to your point, says that Medicare for all will cost $32 trillion over 10 years, the first is cost alone, Colonel, $2.5 trillion, that's more than the market value of Google, Apple, Microsoft, AT, and Facebook combined.

WEST: No, you're absolutely right. And so it ends up consuming, which is one-sixth of our economy healthcare, it will end up consuming our entire budget. And it's interesting that recently out in California they tried to go with a single payer system there, and they pulled the legislation because it will cost too much. What does that tell you?

MACDONALD: Yes, we're going to get to that in a second. But first this, sir. Minnesota democrat and deputy chair of the DNC, he is Keith Ellison he is now pushing for America to become like Cuba when it comes to healthcare. Let's take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEITH ELLISON, (D) UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE: Why is it the countries like Cuba or Canada or Russia or a lot of places in this world spend half of what we spend per capita and they got better health outcomes than we do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Canada, I mean, they are flying here for their health outcomes.

WEST: Yes.

MACDONALD: And does this show the ignorance of democrats like Keith Ellison. I mean, in Cuba it's been showing time and again that party elites, the military foreign tourists, they get the best medical care while the Cuban workers and the Cuban people are left with dirty hospitals and disarray and shortages of medicine.

WEST: You're absolutely right. And you know, when I represented the people down in South Florida, I never saw any boats leaving South Florida to go to Cuba for healthcare. Just the same as when we have these snowbirds that came down from Canada, they would have an incredible influx of Canadians coming in for healthcare appointments, things that they could not get done because of the single payer system in Canada.

So, I think he fells and if he really thinks socialize medicine is so great maybe he can go down to Venezuela and get a, you know, a medical appointment there.

MACDONALD: Yes, it's an interesting point. You know, Colonel, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders t what you were just noting earlier, he is ripping into California democrats for pulling back on a $400 billion single payer healthcare bill, they are worried in California about cost concerns, that's 400 billion is more than double the size of California's budget. And didn't Bernie Sanders home State of Vermont single payer almost bankrupt the state? I mean 400 billion quickly becomes 800 billion, right?

WEST: No, you're absolutely right. And when you think about the CalPERS the pension plan out there for the government bureaucracy and the union that they have in California, you talk about a state that's going bankrupt. We see cities in the State of California that are going bankrupt.

And so they know that this is a failing system. Single payer does not work. Ask the parents of Charlie Gard over in England how they feel about the single payer system when the government is making the decisions about whether or not their child can live.

MACDONALD: It's a good point. Meantime, the president's son-in-law, he is White House senior adviser, Jared Kushner, he was on Capitol Hill testifying behind closed-doors. He was not under oath on the investigation of Russia's involvement in the 2016 election. Let's take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JARED KUSHNER, PRESIDENT TRUMP'S SON-IN-LAW: I did not collude with Russia, nor do I know of anyone else in the campaign who did so. I had no improper contacts. I have not relied on Russian funds for my businesses. And I have been fully transparent in providing all requested information. Donald Trump had a better message and ran a smarter campaign and that is why he won.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: You know, Mr. Kushner also said he did not read e-mails that showed the president's eldest son Donald Trump, Jr. accepted this June 2016 meeting with the idea that he would get damaging information about Hillary Clinton. Colonel, what do you think of Mr. Kushner today?

WEST: Well, I think that he did what was the right thing, to go and put this to rest, but it's never going to be put to rest. You know, we need the people there on Capitol Hill the House and Senate republicans who are in charge to say enough of this already, enough of taxpayer funds that have been wasted on this witch-hunt that is a conviction that is looking for evidence. That's basically what it is.

Let's talk about Hillary Clinton and her uranium deals. Let's talk about the fact that we are going to have more flexibility after our reelection with Russia with what President Obama said. let's talk about the leaks that are emanating out of Washington, D.C. of classified information. That's where the focus should be.

MACDONALD: Yes. Mr. Kushner is expected to basically testify before a House panel, House intelligence tomorrow. We believe it's not under oath that it could be behind closed. It's not going to be held public.

To your point, President Trump tweeting out, "So why aren't the committees investigators and of course, our beleaguered A.G. Jeff Sessions looking into crooked Hillary's crimes and Russia relations." Another shot Jeff Sessions there. What do you think of President Trump's tweet right there?

WEST: You know, if this one thing you never want to criticize a member of your team, especially an attorney general. And I think that that does not do bode well for bolstering his position of influence and his position of power as the attorney general when you have the president that is putting out those types of tweets. Or when you have the interview that he did last week in New York Times. If you got a problem with Attorney General Sessions you need to do it off line behind closed doors.

Donald Trump just tweeting out any senator who votes again starting debate is telling America that you are fine with the Obamacare nightmare. The president also posted of his remarks echoing that earlier today.

This follows Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell saying on the floor that the vote to proceed on debating health reform will start tomorrow. Senate majority whip John Cornyn says Senate John McCain diagnosed with brain cancer, he is trying to get approval for his travel arrangements to possibly show up for a vote. We're on that story for you. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: President Trump about to speak to the boy scouts in West Virginia at the National Boy Scouts jamboree. Fox Business will bring it to you live when the president speaks.

That does it for us tonight. Thank you for having us in your homes. Melissa Francis with Making Money next.

END
